Quiz Results

Part 52 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 511-520)

Quiz Attempt #119462

Total Questions: 16
Question 1
Match the List-I with List-II(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)LIST I (Trade Agreement Types)A. Early Harvest Scheme (EHS)B. Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA)C. Preferential Trade AgreementD. Free Trade AgreementLIST II (Description)I. Two or more parties give right of entry to certain products by reducing duties on an agreed number in tariff linesII. In which two or more countries agree to provide trade terms, tarrif concession to partner countriesIII. A Precursor of CECA, thus a step towards enhanced engagement and confidence buildingIV. Looks into the regulatory aspect of trade and encompasses an agreement on customs, competition & IPRChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- III, B- IV, C- I, D-II
  • B.A- IV, B- III, C- II, D-I
  • C.A- I, B- III, C- II, D-IV
  • D.A- II, B- I, C- IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A- III, B- IV, C- I, D-II

The correct answer is (A) A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

Explanation:

A. Early Harvest Scheme (EHS) – III: EHS is a preliminary step towards a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA), used for building confidence and enhancing engagement.

B. Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) – IV: CEPA looks into regulatory aspects like customs, competition, and intellectual property rights (IPR).

C. Preferential Trade Agreement – I: In a PTA, parties reduce tariffs on an agreed number of products, providing preferential treatment.

D. Free Trade Agreement – II: FTAs involve trade terms and tariff concessions between two or more countries to facilitate free trade.

Thus, the correct matching is A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

Question 2
Arrange the following levels of economic integration in increasing order.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. Political UnionB. Free Trade AreaC. Customs UnionD. Common MarketE. Economic UnionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, D, E, A
  • B.B, A, C, D, E
  • C.B, A, D, C, E
  • D.E, D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: B, C, D, E, A

Economic integration refers to the process where countries coordinate and link their economic policies, trade, and markets to reduce trade barriers and increase cooperation. The levels of integration range from least integrated to most integrated.

 

Levels of Economic Integration in Increasing Order:

 

Free Trade Area (B) → Least Integrated

Countries remove tariffs and trade restrictions among themselves but maintain their own policies toward non-member countries.

 

Customs Union (C)

In addition to a free trade area, countries adopt a common external tariff on imports from non-member countries.

 

Common Market (D)

Goes beyond a customs union by allowing free movement of labor and capital between member countries.

 

Economic Union (E)

A common market with harmonized economic policies, including taxation, monetary policy, and currency union in some cases.

 

Political Union (A) → Most Integrated

Countries fully integrate their economic and political policies under a single government or authority.

Question 3
Match the following: (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)List - I (Statements)I. Countries which follow a unified informal tariff but different external tariff.II. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff system.III. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff and allows free movement of factors of production.IV. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff and allows free movement of factors of production plus having common economic and monitoring policy and common currency.List - II (Terms)i. Customs Unionii. Common marketiii. Free trade areaiv. Economic unionCodes :
  • A.I-iii, II-i, III-iv, IV-ii
  • B.I-iii, II-ii, III-iv, IV-i
  • C.I-iii, II-ii, III-i, IV-iv
  • D.I-iii, II-i, III-ii, IV-iv
Correct Answer: I-iii, II-i, III-ii, IV-iv

Here's an explanation of the matching terms in List I and List II:

 

I. Countries which follow a unified informal tariff but different external tariff - Matched with (iii) Free Trade Area (FTA)

In a Free Trade Area (FTA), member countries eliminate trade barriers among themselves, such as tariffs, quotas, and non-tariff barriers. However, each member retains the freedom to set its own trade policies with non-member countries. This can lead to the issue of trade deflection, where non-member countries reroute their exports to the FTA member with the lowest external trade barriers. Rules of origin are often specified in FTAs to prevent trade deflection by defining whether a product is classified as a member good or a non-member good.

 

II. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff system - Matched with (ii) Customs Union (CU)

A Customs Union (CU) combines the elimination of internal trade barriers among its member countries with the adoption of a common external trade policy towards non-member countries. This means that member countries not only trade freely with each other but also apply the same external tariffs and trade regulations to goods from non-member countries. This uniform treatment of non-member products helps avoid trade deflection issues.

 

III. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff and allow free movement of factors of production - Matched with (iv) Common Market

A Common Market represents a deeper level of economic integration. In addition to eliminating internal trade barriers and adopting a common external trade policy, it also allows for the free movement of factors of production like labor, capital, and technology among its member countries. This promotes economic efficiency and productivity.

 

IV. Countries which follow a unified internal and external tariff and allow free movement of factors of production plus have a common economic and monitoring policy and common currency - Matched with (i) Economic Union

An Economic Union represents the highest level of economic integration. It includes the characteristics of a Customs Union and a Common Market but goes further by requiring member countries to coordinate their macroeconomic and exchange rate policies. This level of integration aims to create a single economic entity with a high degree of policy coordination, including a common currency and economic policies.

 

So, the correct matching of List I to List II is (D) I-iii, II-i, III-ii, IV-iv.

Question 4
In the context of economic groupings, which among the following, is not applicable to common market? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Removal of tariff barriers on Intra-trade
  • B.Harmonisation of economic policies
  • C.Free movement of labour and capital
  • D.Common external tariff
Correct Answer: Harmonisation of economic policies

A common market represents a deeper stage of economic integration than a customs union. In a common market, member countries eliminate internal trade barriers among themselves and adopt a common external trade policy toward nonmembers. Additionally, they go further by removing barriers that inhibit the movement of factors of production, including labor, capital, and technology, among member nations. This means that workers can freely move from one member country to another and engage in their professions or trades. Companies can establish production facilities, invest in other member businesses, and utilize their technologies anywhere within the common market. This promotes productivity because factors of production can relocate where their returns are highest, leading to economic growth and efficiency.

 

However, a common market does not necessarily require the harmonization of economic policies among its member countries. The harmonization of economic policies, which involves coordinating macroeconomic policies, exchange rate policies, monetary policies, fiscal policies, taxation, and social welfare programs, is a feature of an "Economic Union," which represents the highest level of economic integration.

 

In summary, option (B) is not applicable to a common market but rather corresponds to the characteristics of an economic union.

Question 5
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Growing proportion of the world output is traded internationally, causing faster growth of trade among nations.Reason “R”:This situation is bringing world economic integration, which is reinforced by cross-border capital flows and regional blocs.Codes:
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.
  • B.“A”is correct, but“R”is incorrect.
  • C.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
  • D.Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”.
Correct Answer: Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”.

Assertion "A" states that a growing proportion of the world output is traded internationally, leading to faster growth in trade among nations. This statement is correct because globalization and advancements in trade technology have indeed led to an increase in international trade, and a significant portion of the world's economic output is now exchanged across borders.

 

Reason "R" states that this situation is bringing world economic integration, which is reinforced by cross-border capital flows and regional blocs. This statement is also correct and provides a valid explanation for Assertion "A." The growing international trade has contributed to increased economic integration among countries, facilitated by cross-border capital flows (investments) and the formation of regional economic blocs (such as the European Union, NAFTA, etc.). These factors reinforce and support the trend of growing international trade, making "R" a suitable explanation for "A."

 

Therefore, the correct answer is (D) Both "A" and "R" are correct, and "R" is the right explanation of "A."

Question 6
In the context of regional economic integration, which of the following equations is not correct? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Common Market = Customs Union + NTBs + Factor mobility
  • B.Customs Union = Free trade area + Common external tariff
  • C.Free Trade Area = Customs Union - Common external tariff
  • D.Economic Integration = Common market + Fixed exchange rate + Macro economic co-ordination
Correct Answer: Common Market = Customs Union + NTBs + Factor mobility

Let's clarify the equations provided:

 

(A) Common Market = Customs Union + NTBs + Factor mobility

This equation is not correct. The correct equation is

Common Market = Customs Union + Factor mobility

 

(B) Customs Union = Free Trade Area + Common external tariff

This equation is correct. A customs union includes the characteristics of a free trade area (elimination of internal trade barriers), but it goes further by adopting a common external tariff, meaning that member countries have a unified trade policy toward non-members.

 

(C) Free Trade Area = Customs Union - Common external tariff

This equation is also correct. This is same as Option B

 

(D) Economic Integration = Common market + Fixed exchange rate + Macro economic co-ordination

This equation is correct.

Question 7
Which of the following integrations is related to supernational organizational structure? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Free Trade Area
  • B.Economic Union
  • C.Common Market
  • D.Economic Integration
Correct Answer: Economic Integration

Economic Integration is a comprehensive form of regional economic cooperation that involves various stages of cooperation among countries or regions. It typically includes elements like a free trade agreement (FTA), a common external tariff (CET), the free mobility of factors of production (including labor and capital), harmonized economic and social policies to facilitate the flow of capital, labor, goods, and services across borders, and importantly, a supranational organizational structure.

 

The term "supranational" refers to a level of authority or decision-making that transcends the sovereignty of individual nations. In the context of economic integration, a supranational organizational structure is designed to bring together independent political states into a single political framework. This structure allows for coordinated decision-making and policy implementation at a higher level than individual member countries.

 

Examples of supranational organizations in the context of economic integration include the European Union (EU) and its various institutions like the European Commission and the European Central Bank. These institutions have authority over certain aspects of economic and political governance that member countries have delegated to them, contributing to the supranational character of the EU.

Question 8
Grouping of countries committed to remove all the barriers to the free flow of goods and services between themselves and also pursue independent external trade policies is called (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Free trade area
  • B.Custom union
  • C.Common market
  • D.Economic union
Correct Answer: Free trade area

In international trade and economic integration, there are several levels of cooperation and collaboration among countries, each with its own characteristics. Let's explain the terms mentioned in the question:

 

A. Free Trade Area: A free trade area is a group of countries committed to removing all barriers to the free flow of goods and services between themselves. However, each member country maintains its independent external trade policies. In essence, within a free trade area, countries can trade with each other without tariffs or quotas, but they can have different trade policies when dealing with countries outside the group.

 

B. Customs Union: A customs union is a step beyond a free trade area. In addition to removing internal barriers to trade (like tariffs and quotas), member countries of a customs union adopt a common external trade policy. This means that they collectively set common tariffs on imports from countries outside the union. However, within the customs union, trade among member countries remains free.

 

C. Common Market: A common market goes even further in economic integration. In addition to the features of a customs union, a common market allows for the free movement of not only goods and services but also factors of production like labor and capital among member countries. This deeper integration aims to create a unified economic space where resources can move freely.

 

D. Economic Union: An economic union is the highest level of economic integration among countries. It includes all the features of a common market, but it also requires a higher degree of coordination and integration of economic policies, including monetary and fiscal policies. Economic unions often involve a common currency and a central authority overseeing economic matters.

 

In this context, the correct answer is (A) Free trade area because it refers to a group of countries committed to removing barriers to the free flow of goods and services among themselves while maintaining independent external trade policies.

Question 9
Sequence the following in increasing order of integration of member economies. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. Free Trade Area2. Economic Union3. Custom Union4. Preferential Trade Agreements5. Common MarketChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.1, 3, 5, 2, 4
  • B.2, 5, 3, 1, 4
  • C.4, 1, 3, 5, 2
  • D.3, 5, 2, 4, 1
Correct Answer: 4, 1, 3, 5, 2

The increasing order of integration of member economies can be categorized as follows:

 

(i) Preferential Trade Agreements: This term refers to trade preferences that a member country may unilaterally offer to its trade partner, such as reduced or zero tariffs.

 

(ii) Free Trade Area: A free trade area is a regional agreement among a group of countries that have signed a pact for trade liberalization. Within this area, member nations maintain minimal or no trade barriers, such as tariffs or quotas, when trading with each other.

 

(iii) Customs Union: A customs union represents an agreement between two or more countries to eliminate trade barriers and reduce or abolish tariffs. Members of a customs union often apply a uniform external tariff on imports from non-member countries. An example is the European Union (EU).

 

(iv) Common Market: A common market is a formal arrangement where multiple countries come together to adopt a unified external tariff. In addition to the common external tariff, countries in a common market allow for the free movement of goods, labor, and capital among member nations. This trade arrangement aims to enhance economic benefits for all participating countries.

 

(v) Economic Union: An economic union is an agreement between two or more nations that enables the free flow of goods, services, capital, and labor across borders. In addition to the economic aspects, countries in an economic union may coordinate their social and financial policies to support the functioning of a common market. The European Union (EU) serves as an example of an economic union.

Question 10
Arrange the following levels of economic integration, from least integrated to the most integrated: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) Customs Union(2) Free Trade Area(3) Economic Union(4) Common Market(5) Political UnionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.5, 4, 3, 1, 2
  • B.2, 1, 4, 3, 5
  • C.4, 3, 1, 2, 5
  • D.1, 2, 3, 4, 5
Correct Answer: 2, 1, 4, 3, 5

Levels of economic integration are:

 

1. Preferential Trade Area (PTA): Parties to this economic integration arrangement trade on preferential terms. Parties reduce tariff rates on agreed list of goods they trade between themselves. They are unilateral trade preferences. It is the first stage of economic integration. 

 

2. Free Trade Area (FTA): A free trade area encourages trade among its members by eliminating trade barriers (tariffs, quotas, and other non-tariff barriers) among them. Although a free trade area reduces trade barriers among its members, each member is free to establish its own trade policies against non-members. 

 

3. Customs Union (CU): Parties to the economic integration agreement trade on duty and quota free basis and also agree on a common external tariff. They agree on common regulations and measures of trade to apply on goods from third parties. 

 

4. Common Market: A common market goes a step further by eliminating barriers that inhibit the movement of factors of production labor, capital, and technology among its members. Productivity within the common market is expected to rise because factors of production are free to locate where the returns to them are highest. 

 

5. Economic Union: This is the highest level of the stages of economic integration. Member countries coordinate macro-economic and exchange rate policies. An economic union represents full integration of the economies of two or more countries. In addition to eliminating internal trade barriers, adopting common external trade policies, and abolishing restrictions on the mobility of factors of production among members, an economic union requires its members to coordinate their economic policies (monetary policy, fiscal policy, taxation, and social welfare programs) to blend their economies into a single entity.

 

6. Political Union: A political union is the complete political as well as economic integration of two or more countries, thereby effectively making them one country. An example of a political union is the integration of the 13 separate colonies operating under the Articles of Confederation into a new country, the United States of America.

Question 11
Match the items of List - I with the List - II and choose the correct code of combination: (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)List - I(a) It abolishes all restrictions on trade among the members(b) It not only eliminates all restrictions on trade among members but also adopts a uniform commercial policy against the non-members(c) It allows free movement of labor and capital within the common market(d) It achieves some degree of harmonization of national economic policies, through a common central bank, unified monetary and fiscal policy, etc.List - II(i) Common Market(ii) Economic Union(iii) Free Trade Area(iv) Customs UnionCodes:
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct code of combination for matching List - I with the List - II is (C):

(a) It abolishes all restrictions on trade among the members: Free Trade Area (iii)

(b) It not only eliminates all restrictions on trade among members but also adopts a uniform commercial policy against the non-members: Economic Union (iv)

(c) It allows free movement of labor and capital within the common market: Common Market (i)

(d) It achieves some degree of harmonization of national economic policies, through a common central bank, unified monetary and fiscal policy, etc.: Customs Union (ii).

Question 12
Match the items of List – I and items of List – II and select the correct answer:List – I(i) Free Trade Area(ii) Customs Union(iii) OEEC(iv) Common MarketList – II(a) MERCOSUR(b) European Union(c) EFTA(d) Marshall PlanCodes:
  • A.i-(a) ii-(b) iii-(c) iv-(d)
  • B.i-(b) ii-(d) iii-(a) iv-(c)
  • C.i-(c) ii-(a) iii-(d) iv-(b)
  • D.i-(d) ii-(c) iii-(b) iv-(a)
Correct Answer: i-(c) ii-(a) iii-(d) iv-(b)

The matching of List - I with List - II refers to various regional trade agreements and organizations. Here's an explanation of each term:

 

Free Trade Area: This refers to regions or agreements where a group of countries has eliminated or greatly reduced trade barriers (such as tariffs and quotas) among themselves. While they enjoy free trade within the area, they maintain individual trade policies with non-member countries. An example is the European Free Trade Association (EFTA).

 

Customs Union: A customs union is a trade agreement where member countries charge a common set of tariffs to non-member countries while allowing free trade among themselves. In addition to reduced trade barriers, they also share a common external trade policy. An example is MERCOSUR, which includes countries like Argentina and Brazil.

 

OEEC (Organisation for European Economic Co-operation): OEEC emerged from the Marshall Plan and the Conference of Sixteen, aiming to promote economic cooperation and recovery in Europe after World War II. It focused on various aspects of economic collaboration, including reducing trade barriers, developing trade, and coordinating recovery efforts.

 

Common Market: A common market goes beyond a customs union by not only allowing free trade in goods and services but also permitting the free movement of labor and capital among member countries. It represents a higher degree of economic integration. An example is the European Common Market within the European Union (EU).

 

Now, let's match these terms with their respective organizations:

(i) Free Trade Area (c) EFTA (European Free Trade Association)

(ii) Customs Union (a) MERCOSUR (Southern Common Market)

(iii) OEEC (d) Marshall Plan (Organization emerged from the Marshall Plan)

(iv) Common Market (b) European Union (EU) - The EU includes a Common Market

 

So, the correct matching is (C), where each term is associated with its respective regional trade agreement or organization.

Question 13
A common market is one where: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.all the trading nations agree commonly to levy a common and uniform tariff rate for all goods.
  • B.all the trading nations agree commonly to rationalize tariff and non-tariff barriers mutually to promote intra-region trade.
  • C.there is a customs union along with free intra - union movement of factors of production.
  • D.there is an economic union along with free intra-union movement of residents.
Correct Answer: there is a customs union along with free intra - union movement of factors of production.

The answer (C) is correct. In a common market, there is indeed a customs union along with free intra-union movement of factors of production. This means that member countries not only eliminate internal tariffs and trade barriers but also allow the free movement of labor, capital, and other production factors among themselves. This higher degree of economic integration enhances economic cooperation and collaboration among member nations.

Question 14
What is the situation referred to as, amongst the following, when intra-region trade is duty free but there is variation in tariff structure for import from a third country? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Customs Union
  • B.Common Market
  • C.Free Trade Area
  • D.Economic Union
Correct Answer: Free Trade Area

Free Trade Areas are regions in which a group of countries have signed a free trade agreement, and invoke little or no price control in the form of tariffs or quotas between each other. Free trade areas allow the agreeing nations to focus on their competitive advantage and to freely trade for the goods they lack the experience at making, thus increasing the efficiency and profitability of each country. Under this agreement intra-region trade is duty free but there is variation in tariff structure for import from a third country.

Question 15
Which of the following is not a form of economic integration in the context of intra-regional trade? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Customs Union
  • B.European Union
  • C.Economic Union
  • D.African Union
Correct Answer: African Union

Intra-regional trade refers to trade which focuses on economic exchange primarily between countries of the same region or economic zone.

 

Economic Integration is an agreement among countries in a geographic region to reduce and ultimately remove, tariff and non-tariff barriers to the free flow of goods or services and factors of production among each other’s; any type of arrangement in which countries agree to coordinate their trade, fiscal, and/or monetary policies are referred to as economic integration.

 

African Union (AU), earlier (1963–2002) known as Organization of African Unity, intergovernmental organization, established in 2002, to promote unity and solidarity of African states, to spur economic development, and to promote international cooperation. The African Union (AU) replaced the Organization of African Unity (OAU). The AU’s headquarters are in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

 

Here we see that African Union was not formed with the motive of increasing intra-regional trade or for economic integration where as other given organisations does.

Question 16
Assertion ‘A’:Economic integration abolishes cross national economic discrimination.Reason ‘R’:Geographical proximity is an important reason for economic integration.Codes:
  • A.‘R’ does explain ‘A’.
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.
  • C.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are not correct.
  • D.‘A’ is correct, but ‘R’ is not correct.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.

Both assertion 'A' and reason 'R' are correct, and reason 'R' explains assertion 'A'. Economic integration aims to reduce or eliminate economic discrimination and barriers among member countries within a particular region. Geographical proximity can indeed be an important factor in the decision to pursue economic integration, as countries that are geographically close often have a greater incentive to collaborate economically. Therefore, option (B) is the correct choice.

Quiz Attempt #119463

Total Questions: 40
Question 1
To comply with the requirement of TRIPS agreement and to protect products of Indian origin, which one of the following was enacted? (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.WTO Compliance Act 1999
  • B.Geographical Indication of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act 1999
  • C.The Patents Act
  • D.The Copyright Act
Correct Answer: Geographical Indication of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act 1999

The TRIPS agreement is a part of the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework and sets minimum standards for the protection of various forms of intellectual property rights (IPRs). It aims to protect and enforce intellectual property rights internationally, including patents, copyrights, trademarks, and geographical indications.

 

Geographical Indications (GIs) are a type of intellectual property right that identifies products as originating from a specific geographical location and possessing qualities or characteristics that are attributable to that location. GIs are used to protect traditional knowledge and cultural heritage associated with products from specific regions.

 

In line with the TRIPS agreement, many countries, including India, have enacted legislation to protect geographical indications. In India, the Geographical Indication of Goods (Registration and Protection) Act 1999 was enacted to provide legal protection to products with unique qualities or reputation originating from specific geographical regions within India.

Question 2
Sequence the conduct offollowingtrade negotiation and facilitation round in chronological order.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)A. Kennedy roundB. Doha roundC. Geneva roundD. Tokyo roundE. Uruguay roundChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.B, D, C, A, E
  • B.C, A, D, E, B
  • C.A, B, D, C, E
  • D.D, C, A, E, B
Correct Answer: C, A, D, E, B

The correct answer is (B) C, A, D, E, B

A. Kennedy round – 1964-1967

B. Doha round - 2001

C. Geneva round - 1955-1956

D. Tokyo round - 1979

E. Uruguay round - 1986

Question 3
Arrange the following rounds for multilateral trade negotiations under GATT/WTO in a chronological order.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Kennedyb. Dohac. Annecyd. Torquaye. TokyoChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.C, D, A, E, B
  • B.D, C, E, A, B
  • C.B, A, E, C, D
  • D.B, E, A, D, C
Correct Answer: C, D, A, E, B

During the GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) years, eight rounds of tariff negotiations were held between 1947 and 1994: Geneva (1947), Annecy (1949), Torquay (1950-51), Geneva (1956), Geneva (1960-61) - also known as the Dillon Round, the Kennedy Round (1964-67), the Tokyo Round (1973-79) and the Uruguay Round (1986-94).

Question 4
In WTO terminology, subsidies in general are identified by "boxes". Domestic support measure considered to distort production and trade, which is defined in Article 6 of the Agriculture Agreement falls into which box?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Amber Box
  • B.Jumbo Box
  • C.Greenfield Box
  • D.Black Box
Correct Answer:

In WTO terminology, the Amber Box includes domestic support measures that are considered to distort production and trade. These subsidies are subject to reduction commitments under Article 6 of the Agriculture Agreement because they can influence market prices and production levels.

Question 5
WTO in its 8th Ministerial conference adopted a decision allowing members to waive the provisions of Article II (mostfavored-National Treatment) of the GATS to allow the granting of preferential treatment to services and service supplies to which countries?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Adjacent Countries
  • B.Non-Nuclear Countries
  • C.Least-Developed Countries
  • D.SAARC Countries
Correct Answer: Least-Developed Countries

The WTO's 8th Ministerial Conference allowed members to waive Article II of the GATS to grant preferential treatment to services and service suppliers from Least-Developed Countries (LDCs), aiming to support their integration into the global economy.

Question 6
After 10 years of deadlock, European Union (EU) is ready to negotiate with India in WTO on which issue related to food security?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.Public Stockholding Norms
  • B.Climate Change
  • C.Non-tariff barriers to trade
  • D.Sanitary & Phytosanitary measures
Correct Answer: Public Stockholding Norms

Option A is the correct answer.

The issue related to food security that the European Union (EU) is ready to negotiate with India in the WTO (World Trade Organization) after 10 years of deadlock is option (A) - Public Stockholding Norms.

Public stockholding norms refer to government programs that involve the purchase and maintenance of food stocks to support food security objectives, such as ensuring adequate food supplies and stabilizing food prices. These programs are particularly important for developing countries like India, where large populations depend on affordable food supplies. However, such programs can sometimes be challenged under WTO rules, particularly regarding their potential impact on international trade. Therefore, negotiations on public stockholding norms are significant for addressing food security concerns while ensuring compliance with international trade regulations.

Question 7
Which among the following are true about World Trade Organization (WTO)?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. The WTO is a simple extension of General AgreementofTariffs and Trade (GATTB. The WTO is a permanent institution with its own secretariatC. The agreements which constitute the WTO are almost all plurilateral and thus involve commitments for the entire membersD. The WTO includes Trade in Services and trade-related aspects of intellectual property rightsE. The WTO dispute settlement system is faster, more automatic and thus much less susceptible to blockages, than old GATT systemChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.B, C, D and E only
  • B.A, B, and C only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.B, C and D only
Correct Answer: B, C, D and E only

The correct answer is (A) B, C, D and E only.

B. The WTO is a permanent institution with its own secretariat: True. The WTO is a permanent organization that has its own secretariat to handle administrative tasks.

C. The agreements which constitute the WTO are almost all plurilateral and thus involve commitments for the entire members: True. Many agreements under the WTO involve multiple member countries and require commitments from all members.

D. The WTO includes Trade in Services and trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights: True. The WTO covers not just goods but also services (through the General Agreement on Trade in Services, or GATS) and intellectual property rights (through the Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights, or TRIPS).

E. The WTO dispute settlement system is faster, more automatic and thus much less susceptible to blockages, than the old GATT system: True. The WTO’s dispute settlement mechanism is designed to be more efficient and effective compared to the GATT system.

A. The WTO is a simple extension of General Agreement of Tariffs and Trade (GATT): This statement is False. The WTO is not an extension of GATT but new organization.

Question 8
Arrange the following Trade Negotiation Rounds of World Trade Organisation in the order of their occurrence from oldest to latest:(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Bali ConferenceB. Geneva ConferenceC. Hong Kong ConferenceD. Cancun ConferenceE. Doha ConferenceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, E, D
  • B.B, C, D, E, A
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.E, D, C, B, A
Correct Answer: E, D, C, B, A

The Correct order is:

E. Doha Conference

D. Cancun Conference

C. Hong Kong Conference

B. Geneva Conference

A. Bali Conference

 

 

Question 9
Which of the following facts are not correct in the context of India’s relations with the WTO? (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)i. India has been the founder member of the GATT.ii. India has agreed to abide by the arrangement on the intellectual property rights.iii. Under the trade-related investment measures, India has already notified its stand.iv. India has agreed to allow entry to foreign service providers.v. The Indian government has amended the Civil Procedure Code for the benefit of foreign service providers.Choose from the options given below:
  • A.iand ii
  • B.ii and iii
  • C.ivonly
  • D.v only
Correct Answer: v only

In the context of India's relations with the World Trade Organization (WTO), the incorrect fact is option D - v only.

 

i. India has been the founder member of the GATT.

This statement is correct. India was one of the founding members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which was established in 1948. GATT eventually evolved into the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995.

 

ii. India has agreed to abide by the arrangement on intellectual property rights.

This statement is correct. As a member of the WTO, India is bound by the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS), which sets minimum standards for intellectual property protection and enforcement.

 

iii. Under the trade-related investment measures (TRIM), India has already notified its stand.

As per the provisions of Art. 5.1 of the TRIMs Agreement India had notified three trade related investment measures as inconsistent with the provisions of the Agreement:

Local content (mixing) requirements in the production of News Print,

Local content requirement in the production of Rifampicin and Penicillin – G, and

Dividend balancing requirement in the case of investment in 22 categories consumer goods.

Such notified TRIMs were due to be eliminated by 31st December, 1999. None of these measures is in force at present. Therefore, India does not have any outstanding obligations under the TRIMs agreement as far as notified TRIMs are concerned.

 

iv. India has agreed to allow entry to foreign service providers.

This statement is correct. As a member of the WTO, India has agreed to liberalize its services sector, including allowing entry to foreign service providers in certain industries, subject to specific regulations and commitments.

 

v. The Indian government has amended the Civil Procedure Code for the benefit of foreign service providers.

This statement is incorrect. There is no evidence or information given to support this statement. The Civil Procedure Code is primarily concerned with the procedural rules and conduct of civil cases within India's legal system, and there is no indication of it being amended for the benefit of foreign service providers.

Question 10
The Most Favoured Nation status doesn’t necessarily refer to:( UGCNET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Non-discriminatory treatment
  • B.Same and equal economic treatment
  • C.Same tariff rates applicable
  • D.Uniform civil code
Correct Answer: Uniform civil code

The Most Favoured Nation status is a principle in international trade that pertains to non-discriminatory treatment among trading partners. According to this principle, if a country grants certain favorable treatment, privileges, or concessions to one trading partner, it must extend the same treatment to all other trading partners that are members of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The MFN status ensures that a country does not discriminate between its trading partners and provides them with the same and equal economic treatment.

 

Options A, B, and C are all related to the concept of MFN status:

 

(A) Non-discriminatory treatment - This is correct. The MFN status ensures that a country does not discriminate against any of its trading partners and provides them with the same treatment.

 

(B) Same and equal economic treatment - This is also correct. The MFN status requires a country to treat all its trading partners equally and extend the same economic treatment to all.

 

(C) Same tariff rates applicable - This is also correct. The MFN status implies that if a country applies certain tariff rates to a specific product or service from one trading partner, it must apply the same tariff rates to the same product or service from all other trading partners.

 

Option (D) - Uniform civil code, however, is not related to the concept of Most Favoured Nation status in the context of international trade. A uniform civil code pertains to a set of laws that govern personal matters like marriage, divorce, inheritance, and property rights, which are usually based on religious or cultural practices. It is a separate legal and social issue and not directly related to trade principles like the Most Favoured Nation status.

Question 11
As a part of WTO guidelines, Agreement on Agriculture (AOA) doesn’t consider (UGC NETManagement Jun 2015)
  • A.Direct payments to farmers are permitted.
  • B.Indirect assistance and support to farmers including R&D support by Govt. are not permitted.
  • C.Domestic policies which directly effect on production and tradehave tobe cut back.
  • D.Least developed countries do not need to make any cuts.
Correct Answer: Indirect assistance and support to farmers including R&D support by Govt. are not permitted.

  • Option A – True:
    Direct payments to farmers that meet specific conditions (like being decoupled from production) are allowed under the Green Box.

  • ❌ Option B – False:
    Indirect support such as research, training, pest control, and infrastructure is permitted under Annex 2 (Green Box) of the Agreement. These are considered to have minimal trade-distorting effects.

  • Option C – True:
    Trade-distorting domestic support (classified under the Amber Box) must be reduced as per WTO commitments.

  • Option D – True:
    Least-developed countries (LDCs) are exempt from making any reductions in domestic support or export subsidies under the AOA.

Question 12
WTO come into being in the year: (UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.1975
  • B.1985
  • C.1995
  • D.2001
Correct Answer: 1995

The World Trade Organization (WTO) came into being on January 1, 1995. It was established as a result of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations that took place between 1986 and 1994. The Uruguay Round was the eighth round of trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

 

The WTO replaced the GATT and expanded its scope and authority. While GATT primarily focused on reducing tariffs and trade barriers for goods, the WTO covers a broader range of trade-related issues, including services, intellectual property rights, and investment. It also has a more effective dispute settlement mechanism to address trade disputes between member countries.

The establishment of the WTO marked a significant milestone in international trade relations, providing a more comprehensive and rules-based framework to govern global trade and promote economic cooperation among member countries.

Question 13
Arrange the following steps of Dispute Settlement Mechanism under the WTO in the systematic order: (UGC NET Management Dec 2013)i. Panel Proceedingsii. Appellate Bodyiii. Consultationsiv. Compliance Panelv. Arbitration PanelCodes:
  • A.iii,i, ii, iv, v
  • B.v, iv, iii, ii,i
  • C.iv, ii, iii, v,i
  • D.i, ii, iii, iv, v
Correct Answer: iii,i, ii, iv, v

The Dispute Settlement Mechanism (DSM) under the World Trade Organization (WTO) is a structured process for resolving trade-related disputes between member countries. It involves several stages and follows a systematic order. Here is an explanation of the steps involved in the DSM in the context of the provided content:

 

1. Consultations (iii): The first stage of the dispute settlement process is consultations between the disputing parties. Before pursuing formal legal actions, the countries in dispute are encouraged to engage in discussions to resolve the issue amicably. If one country requests consultations, the other has ten days to respond and thirty days to implement them. These consultations help clarify the nature of the dispute and may lead to a mutually acceptable solution. Third-party countries with a significant interest in the dispute can also participate in these consultations.

 

2. Panel Proceedings (i): If consultations fail to resolve the dispute, the complaining party can request the establishment of a panel of experts to examine the case. The Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) decides on the creation of the panel, usually consisting of three experts who review the case. Panel members are selected based on their expertise and must be impartial. The panel's mission is to determine whether the challenged measures are consistent with WTO rules. They may also seek additional information or technical opinions if necessary.

 

3. Appellate Body (ii): If either party is dissatisfied with the panel's findings and conclusions, they can appeal the decision to the Appellate Body. The Appellate Body is a permanent body composed of seven members who serve four-year terms. Its role is to review panel reports on legal issues and interpretations of WTO agreements. While it cannot interfere with the descriptive part of the panel report, it can challenge the legal reasoning and arguments presented in the report. The Appellate Body aims to ensure the consistency and correctness of legal interpretations.

 

Implementation of the Report: After the panel or appellate body issues a report, the Dispute Settlement Body adopts the report within a specific timeframe, typically twenty to sixty days, unless there is a consensus against it. The losing party is expected to comply with the recommendations and rulings in the report within a reasonable period of time, usually agreed upon by both parties or determined by the DSB. If compliance is not achieved, further negotiations or arbitration may be pursued.

 

4. Compliance Panel (iv): In cases where there is a dispute regarding compliance with the panel or appellate body's report, a compliance panel can be established to address these issues. The compliance panel assesses whether the member has implemented the required changes to conform with WTO rules. If there are continued challenges or disputes over compliance, this panel plays a role in ensuring that the decisions are enforced.

 

5. Arbitration Panel (v): Arbitration panels may be involved if disputes arise during the process of finding mutually acceptable solutions or implementing recommendations. These panels provide a mechanism for resolving specific issues or conflicts that may emerge during the dispute settlement process.

Question 14
Which of the following is not a subsidiary body of General counsel of WTO? (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)
  • A.Council for trade in goods
  • B.Council for trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights
  • C.Council for trade in services
  • D.Council for settlement of disputes
Correct Answer: Council for settlement of disputes

The Council for settlement of disputes is not a subsidiary body of the General Council of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The General Council is the highest-level decision-making body of the WTO, responsible for overseeing the functioning of the organization and its various agreements.

 

The subsidiary bodies of the General Council include:

(A) Council for trade in goods: This body deals with matters related to the implementation and operation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and other agreements on trade in goods.

(B) Council for trade-related aspects of intellectual property rights (TRIPS): This body deals with the implementation and operation of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS).

(C) Council for trade in services: This body deals with matters related to the implementation and operation of the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS).

Question 15
From the following statements relating to WTO agreements, choose the statements that are correct: (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)Statement I: Diversity in technical regulations and industrial standards among countries leads to the introduction of TBT (Technical Barriers to trade) Agreements.Statement II: The aim of WTO agreements on customs valuation is to ensure a fair, uniform and neutral system for the valuation of goods for customs purposes.Statement III: The agreement on Trade Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) applies only to measures that affect trade in goods.Codes:
  • A.Statements I and II only are correct.
  • B.Only statement I is correct.
  • C.Only statements II and III are correct.
  • D.All the statements are correct.
Correct Answer: All the statements are correct.

Statement I: Diversity in technical regulations and industrial standards among countries leads to the introduction of TBT (Technical Barriers to Trade) Agreements.

This statement is correct. Technical barriers to trade (TBT) agreements are established under the World Trade Organization (WTO) to address issues related to technical regulations, standards, and conformity assessment procedures that may create obstacles to international trade. The existence of diverse technical regulations and standards among countries can hinder trade by creating unnecessary barriers and compliance challenges for exporters.

 

Statement II: The aim of WTO agreements on customs valuation is to ensure a fair, uniform, and neutral system for the valuation of goods for customs purposes.

This statement is correct. The WTO's Agreement on Customs Valuation, also known as the WTO Customs Valuation Agreement or the Agreement on Implementation of Article VII of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), establishes rules for the valuation of goods for customs purposes. The aim is to ensure a fair, uniform, and neutral system for determining the customs value of imported goods, which is essential for the assessment of customs duties and other taxes on imports.

 

Statement III: The agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) applies only to measures that affect trade in goods.

This statement is correct. The Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) is limited to measures that affect trade in goods alone. This Agreement, negotiated during the Uruguay Round, applies only to measures that affect trade in goods. This doesn’t apply to service trade.

Question 16
Which of the following statements are true? Select the correct code. (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)(a) WTO rules are mainly applied to trade in goods but other areas such as services, intellectual property, etc., are not covered by them.(b) GATT had contracting parties, whereas WTO has members.(c) The dispute settlement system under WTO is much more efficient, speedy and transparent unlike the GATT system which was highly susceptible to blockages.Choose the correct option:
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b) and (c)
  • D.(a) and (c)
Correct Answer: (b) and (c)

The correct answer is (B) (b) and (c).

 

(a) WTO rules are mainly applied to trade in goods but other areas such as services, intellectual property, etc., are not covered by them.

This statement is false. WTO covers a broader range of trade-related issues, including services, intellectual property rights, and investment. It also has a more effective dispute settlement mechanism to address trade disputes between member countries.

 

(b) GATT had contracting parties, whereas WTO has members.

This statement is true. GATT, which stands for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, had contracting parties, while the WTO, which replaced GATT, has members. The change from contracting parties to members was a significant shift, reflecting the broader scope and responsibilities of the WTO compared to GATT.

 

(c) The dispute settlement system under WTO is much more efficient, speedy, and transparent, unlike the GATT system, which was highly susceptible to blockages.

This statement is true. The dispute settlement system under the WTO is known for its efficiency, speed, and transparency compared to the GATT system. The WTO's Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) provides a structured and timely process for resolving trade disputes among member countries. The DSB's dispute resolution mechanism ensures that cases are handled more efficiently and effectively, reducing the likelihood of blockages and delays in resolving disputes.

Question 17
The Uruguay round provided 'Sunset' clause to control: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Customs valuation
  • B.Dumping
  • C.Technical barriers to trade
  • D.Dispute settlement
Correct Answer: Dumping

The "Sunset clause" is a provision that was introduced during the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations conducted under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). The Uruguay Round was a significant multilateral trade negotiation that took place between 1986 and 1994, resulting in the establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995.

 

The "Sunset clause" was included in the agreement to control the practice of "Dumping." Dumping refers to the act of exporting a product to another country at a price lower than its normal value or the price charged in the domestic market of the exporting country. This can harm domestic industries in the importing country as it creates an unfair competitive advantage for the foreign exporters.

 

The "Sunset clause" sets a specific time limit on the application of anti-dumping duties or measures. It means that the imposition of anti-dumping duties on certain products will automatically expire after a predefined period, unless the importing country decides to extend these measures after conducting a review to assess their impact.

Question 18
Statement I:Trade Policy Review Body is a forum for the entire membership to review the trade policies of all WTOmembers.(UGC NET Management Nov 2017)Statement II:The WTO administers the “Trade Review Mechanism”.Codes:
  • A.Statement I is correct but II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement II is correct but Iisincorrect.
  • C.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

Both statements I and II are correct.

 

Statement - I: Trade Policy Review Body is a forum for the entire membership to review the trade policies of all WTO members.

This statement is correct. The Trade Policy Review Body (TPRB) is a part of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and serves as a forum where all WTO members can review and discuss the trade policies and practices of other member countries. The purpose of these reviews is to promote transparency and facilitate a better understanding of each member's trade policies, which helps to ensure that countries are adhering to their WTO commitments and obligations.

 

Statement - II: The WTO administers the "Trade Review Mechanism."

This statement is also correct. The "Trade Review Mechanism" is a process that falls under the purview of the WTO's Trade Policy Review Body. It involves conducting periodic reviews of the trade policies and practices of WTO members. During these reviews, the member's trade policies are assessed, and other members can ask questions and seek clarifications about any specific trade-related issues. The reviews aim to encourage open dialogue and promote a more transparent and predictable trading environment.

Question 19
Agreement on Trade Related Investment Measures (TRIMS) under WTO regime aims to address which one of the following measures? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Protection of investment in creation of Intellectual Property Rights (IPRs)
  • B.No member shall apply any measures in violation of the national treatment principles of GATT and discriminate against foreigners or foreign products
  • C.It does not prohibit investment measures that place a restriction on quantities and measures requiring a certain percentage of local procurement
  • D.It encourages measures which limit imports or set targets for exports and trade balancing
Correct Answer: No member shall apply any measures in violation of the national treatment principles of GATT and discriminate against foreigners or foreign products

The Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMS) under the WTO regime aims to address (B) No member shall apply any measures in violation of the national treatment principles of GATT and discriminate against foreigners or foreign products.

 

TRIMS is an international agreement that is part of the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework. It primarily focuses on trade-related investment measures that affect international trade and investment. The agreement seeks to promote fairness, non-discrimination, and transparency in the treatment of foreign investments.

 

Specifically, TRIMS prohibits certain investment measures that are considered trade-distorting or discriminatory against foreign products and investors. It aims to prevent WTO members from applying measures that violate the national treatment principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). National treatment means that foreign products and domestic products should be treated equally once they have entered a country's market.

 

TRIMS does not prohibit all investment measures; rather, it addresses those that are inconsistent with the principles of non-discrimination and equal treatment of foreign and domestic goods.

Question 20
In dispute resolution mechanism of the WTO regime, the collapse of the Doha Round talks at Cancun in September 2003 has been attributed to which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Subsidies in agriculture and agricultural domestic support policies of developed nations
  • B.Measures on protecting intellectual property rights of innovators
  • C.Agreement on Textiles and Clothing (ATC) under Multi-Fibre Arrangement
  • D.Trade in the shape of individuals travelling to foreign countries to supply services
Correct Answer: Subsidies in agriculture and agricultural domestic support policies of developed nations

The Doha Development Round, also known as the Doha Round, was a series of trade negotiations conducted under the World Trade Organization (WTO) with the goal of promoting global trade liberalization and economic development, particularly in developing countries.

 

During the Doha Round talks held in Cancun, Mexico, in September 2003, one of the major sticking points and causes of disagreement between the developed and developing nations was related to agricultural subsidies and domestic support policies of developed countries. Many developing countries were advocating for substantial reductions in agricultural subsidies provided by developed nations to their farmers, which they believed were distorting international agricultural trade and causing harm to their domestic agricultural sectors.

 

However, developed countries were reluctant to make significant reductions in their agricultural subsidies, leading to a deadlock in the negotiations and ultimately causing the collapse of the talks in Cancun.

Question 21
An efficient dispute settlement mechanism under WTO was brought in by which one of the following: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)
  • A.The Uruguay Round Agreement
  • B.Doha Round
  • C.UNDP Human Development Report 2000
  • D.The Uruguay and Geneva Round of Negotiation
Correct Answer: The Uruguay Round Agreement

The dispute settlement mechanism of the World Trade Organization (WTO) was significantly strengthened and made more efficient as a result of the Uruguay Round Agreement. The Uruguay Round was a series of negotiations that took place from 1986 to 1994, resulting in the establishment of the WTO in 1995.

 

One of the major achievements of the Uruguay Round was the creation of the WTO's Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU). The DSU is a set of rules and procedures that govern the settlement of disputes between member countries of the WTO. It provides a clear and structured process for resolving trade disputes and ensures that WTO rules and agreements are effectively enforced.

 

The dispute settlement mechanism under the DSU is known for its efficiency and transparency, providing a multilateral forum for resolving trade disputes and ensuring fair and equitable outcomes. It has played a vital role in maintaining the stability and predictability of the international trading system.

Question 22
The member countries of WTO have moved to “Product Patent Regime” under (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.TRIMs
  • B.TRIPs
  • C.SAPTA
  • D.BOP
Correct Answer: TRIPs

TRIPs stands for Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights, and it is an agreement under the World Trade Organization (WTO). The TRIPs agreement sets out minimum standards for the protection of various forms of intellectual property rights (IPRs) on a global scale.

 

One of the significant aspects of the TRIPs agreement is the provision related to patents. Before the TRIPs agreement, some countries operated under a "Process Patent Regime," which allowed patents only for the processes of manufacturing a product, not the product itself. However, the TRIPs agreement mandated that member countries move towards a "Product Patent Regime" for all fields of technology, including pharmaceuticals.

 

Under the "Product Patent Regime," patents are granted for the end product, allowing companies to have exclusive rights over the manufacturing, sale, and distribution of the patented product. This change was particularly relevant in the pharmaceutical industry, where it has significant implications for research, development, and access to essential medicines.

Question 23
World Trade Organisation provides (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.Rule based multilateral trading system.
  • B.Equity and social justice to the people.
  • C.Rule based regional trading system
  • D.All ofthe above
Correct Answer: Rule based multilateral trading system.

The correct answer is (A) Rule based multilateral trading system.

 

The World Trade Organization (WTO) primarily provides a rule-based multilateral trading system. It sets rules and regulations governing international trade and provides a forum for member countries to negotiate and resolve trade-related disputes. The WTO's main goal is to promote free and fair trade among its member countries by establishing a transparent and predictable framework for international trade.

Question 24
Which of the following invalidates informal persuasions to boycott China imported goods? [UGC NET Management Jun 2019]
  • A.Plurilateral agreement
  • B.Protection through tariffication
  • C.National treatment rule
  • D.Most favoured nation principle
Correct Answer: National treatment rule

The national treatment rule is a principle in international trade that requires countries to treat foreign goods, services, and investors no less favorably than their domestic counterparts once they have entered the domestic market. It ensures that foreign products are not subject to discriminatory treatment compared to domestically produced goods.

 

When a country attempts to informally persuade its citizens to boycott imported goods from another country, such as China, it can be seen as a form of discriminatory treatment against those foreign goods. This violates the national treatment rule, as it is imposing unfavorable treatment on foreign goods in the domestic market.

 

The other options do not specifically address informal persuasions to boycott China imported goods:

 

(A) Plurilateral agreement: A plurilateral agreement is a trade agreement between a specific group of countries, rather than being open to all members of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

 

(B) Protection through tariffication: Tariffication refers to the process of converting non-tariff barriers into tariffs. While it can be used as a trade policy tool to protect domestic industries.

 

(D) Most favored nation principle: The Most Favored Nation (MFN) principle requires a country to extend to other countries the same trade advantages and benefits that it provides to its most favored trading partner. It is a fundamental principle in the WTO.

Question 25
Match List I with the List II.List I – Trade concepts and terminologyA. GATSB. TRIPSC. TRIMSD. MFNList II – DescriptionI. Extends multilateral rules and disciplines to service.II. The agreement requires compliance with the provisions of Bern convention of 1886 to which India is a signatory.III. Refers to certain conditions imposed by a government in respect of foreign investment in the country.IV. Prevents countries from the discriminating among foreign suppliers of services.Choose the correct answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Management Jun 2022)
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV

Here's an explanation of the matching between List I and List II:

 

A. GATS - General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS) extends multilateral rules and disciplines to services. It is an international treaty that establishes a framework for the liberalization of trade in services among member countries.

 

B. TRIPS - Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) is an agreement that requires compliance with the provisions of the Bern Convention of 1886, to which India is a signatory. TRIPS sets out the minimum standards for various forms of intellectual property rights protection and enforcement in international trade.

 

C. TRIMS - Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMS) refers to certain conditions imposed by a government in respect of foreign investment in the country. TRIMS are trade-distorting measures that can affect the terms and conditions under which foreign investors can operate in a country.

 

D. MFN - Most-Favoured Nation (MFN) status prevents countries from discriminating among foreign suppliers of services. It means that if a country grants MFN status to one trading partner, it must extend the same favourable treatment to all other WTO (World Trade Organization) member countries.

 

So, the correct matching is (A) A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV, as each concept in List I corresponds to its respective description in List II.

Question 26
Various bodies in the organizational structure of WTO are given below.On the basis ofdecision-making authority, arrange them from top to bottom and indicate the correct code. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)1.General Council2.Ministerial Conference3.Specialised Committees4.Council for Trade in GoodsChoose the correct answer from the code given below:Codes:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iv), (iii)
  • B.(ii), (i), (iv), (iii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • D.(iv), (i), (ii), (iii)
Correct Answer: (ii), (i), (iv), (iii)

Here's the arrangement of these bodies in the organizational structure of the WTO from top to bottom based on decision-making authority:

 

Ministerial Conference (ii) - The Ministerial Conference is the highest decision-making body of the WTO, and it meets periodically to make key decisions regarding the organization's policies and objectives.

 

General Council (i) - The General Council acts on behalf of the Ministerial Conference when it is not in session and carries out the day-to-day work of the WTO. It has a significant role in decision-making and coordination.

 

Council for Trade in Goods (iv) - The Council for Trade in Goods is one of the specialized councils responsible for matters related to trade in goods. While it plays a crucial role, it is below the General Council in decision-making authority.

 

Specialized Committees (iii) - Specialized Committees are subordinate bodies responsible for specific issues or sectors within the WTO. They have a lower level of decision-making authority compared to the bodies listed above.

 

So, the correct code is (B) (ii), (i), (iv), (iii), as it arranges these bodies in the order of their decision-making authority within the WTO's organizational structure.

Question 27
Which one of the following does not fall within the ambit of WTO operations? (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)
  • A.Antidumping measures, industrial and export subsidies of trading nations.
  • B.Trade in service, intellectual property protection, multifibre agreement.
  • C.Supplementing balance of trade deficit and helping a nation to overcome balance of payment crisis.
  • D.Redressal and settlement of tariff disputes.
Correct Answer: Supplementing balance of trade deficit and helping a nation to overcome balance of payment crisis.

Let's review each option and rewrite the explanation accordingly:

 

(A) Antidumping measures, industrial and export subsidies of trading nations - This option does fall within the ambit of WTO operations. The WTO addresses antidumping measures, which are measures taken by countries to counteract the impact of imported goods sold at lower-than-normal prices, and it also regulates industrial and export subsidies to ensure fair competition among trading nations.

 

(B) Trade in service, intellectual property protection, multifibre agreement - This option also falls within the ambit of WTO operations. The WTO covers trade in services through the General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS), provides intellectual property protection through the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS), and has abolished the Multifibre Agreement to liberalize trade in textiles and clothing.

 

(C) Supplementing balance of trade deficit and helping a nation to overcome balance of payment crisis - This option does not fall within the ambit of WTO operations. The WTO primarily focuses on trade-related issues and does not directly involve itself in supplementing balance of trade deficit or addressing balance of payment crises in member nations. These matters are usually dealt with by respective governments in coordination with international financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

 

(D) Redressal and settlement of tariff disputes - This option falls within the ambit of WTO operations. The WTO provides a dispute settlement mechanism that helps member countries resolve tariff disputes and other trade-related conflicts through a structured legal process.

Question 28
Which one of the following institutions is NOT a part of the World Bank Group? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
  • B.International Development Association (IDA)
  • C.Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
  • D.The Bank for International Settlements (BIS)
Correct Answer: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS)

International organization that serves as a bank for central banks. Its main purpose is to foster international monetary and financial cooperation and to serve as a forum for central banks and other financial authorities.

 

The World Bank Group, on the other hand, is a collection of five international organizations that work together to promote economic development and reduce poverty around the world. The 5 institutions that make up the World Bank Group are:

  • International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
  • International Development Association (IDA)
  • International Finance Corporation (IFC)
  • Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)

International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)

Question 29
Sequence the following different settlement stages of the WTO dispute settlement System. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)A. RetaliationB. ImplementationC. Panel ReviewD. AppellateE. ConsultationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes :
  • A.D, E, A, C, B
  • B.E, D, C, A, B
  • C.E, C, D, B, A
  • D.D, E, C, A, B
Correct Answer: E, C, D, B, A

The correct sequence of different settlement stages in the WTO dispute settlement system is (C) E, C, D, B, A

 

1. Consultations: This is the first stage where countries try to resolve their disputes through negotiations and consultations with each other.

 

2. Panel Review: If consultations do not lead to a resolution, the complaining party can request the establishment of a panel to review the case and make recommendations.

 

3. Appellate: Either party can appeal the panel's ruling, and this stage involves the Appellate Body reviewing the legal aspects of the panel report and issuing a final decision.

 

4. Implementation: After the dispute settlement process is complete, the losing party is expected to bring its measures into compliance with the WTO rules and recommendations.

 

5. Retaliation: If the losing party fails to comply with the recommendations and rulings, the prevailing party can seek authorization from the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) to impose trade sanctions or retaliate against the non-complying party.

Question 30
Match List I with the List II (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022) (UGC NET Commerce July 2018)List I (Tariff/ Subsidy)A. TarifficationB. Prohibited subsidies.C. Actionable subsidiesD.Non-actionablesubsidiesList II (Explanation)I. They have demonstrably adverse effects on other member countries.II. They act on goods which are contingent upon export performance.III. Replacement of existing non-tarrifrestrictions.IV. For industrial research in disadvantaged regions.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV
  • B.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
  • D.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV

Explanation:

List I represents different types of Tariff/ Subsidy measures, and List II provides their corresponding explanations.

A. Tariffication - III. Replacement of existing non-tariff restrictions.

B. Prohibited subsidies - II. They act on goods which are contingent upon export performance.

C. Actionable subsidies - I. They have demonstrably adverse effects on other member countries.

D. Non-actionable subsidies - IV. For industrial research in disadvantaged regions.

 

Prohibited Subsidies

Prohibited subsidies, also known as "red light" or "red" subsidies, are subsidies that are considered harmful to international trade and are prohibited based on their presumed adverse effects on trade. There are two types of prohibited subsidies:

a. Export Subsidies: These subsidies are contingent, in law or in fact, upon export performance. In other words, they are provided to domestic industries with the condition that they meet certain export targets.

b. Import Substitution or Local Content Subsidies: These subsidies are contingent upon the use of domestic goods over imported goods. They encourage domestic industries to use domestic inputs instead of imported ones.

 

Prohibited subsidies are subject to special and additional dispute settlement rules within the WTO. If a challenged subsidy is found to be prohibited, the remedy is that the subsidy must be withdrawn immediately. This is because these subsidies are designed to distort trade and are not allowed under WTO rules.

 

Actionable Subsidies

Actionable subsidies, also referred to as "yellow light" or "amber" subsidies, are subsidies that are subject to challenge based on evidence that they have caused specified adverse effects in particular cases. There are three types of adverse effects on the basis of which a WTO member country can bring a dispute against another member's subsidies:

(i) Serious Prejudice: This can take various forms, including displacement of imports, price undercutting, or lost sales, among others.

(ii) Injury: Injury to the domestic industry producing the same or similar product in the importing country, caused by subsidized imports.

(iii) Nullification or Impairment of Benefits: When the effect of the subsidy prevents trading partners from enjoying the benefits of market access concessions they received from the subsidizing member.

 

Unlike prohibited subsidies, there is no presumption of adverse effects in respect of actionable subsidies. The complaining country must provide evidence of these adverse effects.

 

If a subsidy is found to have an adverse effect, the subsidizing country is required to either withdraw the subsidy or remove its adverse effects. Countervailing duties can also be imposed as a countermeasure if domestic producers are harmed by imports of subsidized products.

 

Non-Actionable Subsidies (No Longer in Existence):

Non-actionable subsidies were a category of subsidies that existed for a limited period, from 1995 to 1999, under the WTO's subsidy and countervailing measures agreement. The purpose of this category was to address certain types of subsidies that were considered less likely to significantly distort international trade. Non-actionable subsidies are no longer in existence, as this category expired on December 31, 1999, and was not extended.

Question 31
Which one of the following is not the basic function of WTO? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.To facilitate the implementation, administration and operation of trade agreements
  • B.To settle differences and disputes among its member countries
  • C.To facilitate the expansion and balanced growth of international trade
  • D.To carry out periodic reviews of the trade policies of its member countries
Correct Answer: To facilitate the expansion and balanced growth of international trade

The World Trade Organization (WTO) deals with the global rules of trade between nations. Its main function is to ensure that trade flows as smoothly, predictably and freely as possible.

 

Functions of WTO are as follows:

(i) It shall facilitate the implementation, administration and operation of the WTO trade agreements, such as multilateral trade agreements, plurilateral trade agreements.

(ii) It shall provide forum for negotiations among its members concerning their multilateral trade relations.

(iii) It shall administer the ‘Understanding on Rules and Procedures’ so as to handle trade disputes.

(iv) It shall monitor national trade policies.

(v) It shall provide technical assistance and training for members of the developing countries.

(vi) It shall cooperate with various international organisations like the IMF and the WB with the aim of achieving greater coherence in global economic policy-making.

Question 32
Which of the following are the function of WTO? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)(a) To facilitate the implementation, administration and operation of trade agreement(b) To carry out periodic reviews of the trade policies of its member countries(c) To assist in the establishment of a multilateral system of payments(d) To promote international monetary cooperationChoose your answer from the following options:
  • A.(a) and (d)
  • B.(b) and (c)
  • C.(c) and (d)
  • D.(a) and (b)
Correct Answer: (a) and (b)

The WTO’s overriding objective is to help trade flow smoothly, freely and predictably. Its functions are enlisted below:

(i) administering trade agreements

(ii) acting as a forum for trade negotiations

(iii) settling trade disputes

(iv) reviewing national trade policies

(v) building the trade capacity of developing economies

(vi) cooperating with other international organizations

 

Let’s have look at functions of IMF too. The purposes of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) are clearly expressed in Article I of its constitution, the Articles of Agreement:

(i) To promote international monetary cooperation through a permanent institution which provides the machinery for consultation and collaboration on international monetary problems.

(ii) To facilitate the expansion and balanced growth of international trade, and to contribute thereby to the promotion and maintenance of high levels of employment and real income and to the development of the productive resources of all members as primary objectives of economic policy.

(iii) To promote exchange stability, to maintain orderly exchange arrangements among members, and to avoid competitive exchange depreciation.
