(iv) To assist in the establishment of a multilateral system of payments in respect of current transactions between members and in the elimination of foreign exchange restrictions which hamper the growth of world trade.

(v) To give confidence to members by making the general resources of the Fund temporarily available to them under adequate safeguards, thus providing them with opportunity to correct maladjustments in their balance of payments without resorting to measures destructive of national or international prosperity.

(vi) In accordance with the above, to shorten the duration and lessen the degree of disequilibrium in the international balances of payments of members.

 

Clearly (c) and (d) are function of IMF and not the functions of World Bank.

Question 33
Which of the following institutions are included in the “World Bank Group”? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. International Finance Corporation2. International Monetary Fund3. World Trade Organization4. Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency5. International Development AssociationChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.1, 2 and 3 only
  • B.1, 2 and 4 only
  • C.1, 2, 4 and 5 only
  • D.1, 4 and 5 only
Correct Answer: 1, 4 and 5 only

The World Bank Group consists of 5 organizations:

1. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) lends to governments of middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries.

 

2. The International Development Association (IDA) provides interest-free loans called credits and grants to governments of the poorest countries. Together, IBRD and IDA make up the World Bank.

 

3. The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is the largest global development institution focused exclusively on the private sector. We help developing countries achieve sustainable growth by financing investment, mobilizing capital in international financial markets, and providing advisory services to businesses and governments.

 

4. The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) was created in 1988 to promote foreign direct investment into developing countries to support economic growth, reduce poverty, and improve people’s lives. MIGA fulfills this mandate by offering political risk insurance (guarantees) to investors and lenders.

 

5. The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) provides international facilities for conciliation and arbitration of investment disputes.

Question 34
Match List I with the List II (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List I (Events)a. Bretton Woods Conferenceb. GATT establishedc. Multi Fiber Agreementd. WTO replaced GATTList IIi. 1948ii. 1974iii. 1944iv. 1995Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • B.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv

Here's an explanation of the events and their chronological order:

 

1. Bretton Woods Conference (1944): This conference, officially known as the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, took place in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, USA, in July 1944. The conference aimed to establish a new international monetary order after World War II. It led to the creation of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), which later became part of the World Bank Group. These institutions were established to promote international monetary cooperation and provide financial assistance for post-war reconstruction and development.

 

2. GATT Established (1948): The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was established in 1948 as an international treaty aimed at reducing trade barriers and promoting free trade among member countries. GATT provided a framework for negotiating and reducing tariffs on traded goods. It played a crucial role in the post-war period in promoting international trade and economic cooperation.

 

3. Multi Fiber Agreement (1974): The Multi-Fiber Agreement (MFA) was a textile trade agreement that was negotiated in 1974. It allowed developed countries to impose quotas on imports of textiles and clothing from developing countries. The MFA was designed to protect the textile industries of developed countries by limiting competition from low-cost producers in developing nations. It remained in effect until it was eventually phased out in the context of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

 

4. WTO Replaced GATT (1995): The World Trade Organization (WTO) was established on January 1, 1995, to replace the GATT. The WTO is a more comprehensive and robust organization that not only deals with trade in goods (like GATT) but also covers trade in services and intellectual property rights. It provides a forum for member countries to negotiate and resolve trade disputes, and it sets rules and agreements to govern international trade. The WTO represents a significant step in the evolution of global trade governance.

Question 35
Identity the principles of trade policy framework from the followings under the WTO: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) Reciprocity and transparent(2) Benefactory and resilient(3) Non - discriminatory(4) Binding and enforceable commitments(5) Protective and benevolentChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1, 2 and 3 only
  • B.3, 4 and 5 only
  • C.1, 3 and 4 only
  • D.2, 4 and 5 only
Correct Answer: 1, 3 and 4 only

Five principles are of particular importance in understanding both the pre-1994 GATT and the WTO:

 

1. Non-Discrimination: This principle comprises two key elements - the Most Favoured Nation (MFN) rule and National Treatment Policy. The MFN rule mandates that a WTO member must apply uniform trade conditions to all interactions with other WTO members. In essence, this means that a WTO member must extend the most favorable trade conditions granted to one member to all others, ensuring equal treatment. Essentially, "Grant someone a special favor, and you have to do the same for all other WTO members."

 

National treatment stipulates that imported goods must receive treatment no less favorable than domestically produced goods, especially once the foreign goods have entered the market. This principle was introduced to counter non-tariff barriers to trade, such as discriminatory technical standards or security regulations against imported goods.

 

2. Reciprocity: Reciprocity signifies a desire to both restrict the potential for free riding resulting from the MFN rule and secure improved access to foreign markets. It underscores that for a nation to engage in negotiations, the benefits derived must exceed those attainable through unilateral liberalization. Reciprocal concessions aim to guarantee the realization of such gains.

 

3. Binding and Enforceable Commitments: Tariff commitments made by WTO members during multilateral trade negotiations and upon accession are documented in schedules that enumerate concessions. These schedules establish "ceiling bindings," meaning that a country can modify its bindings, but only after engaging in negotiations with its trade partners. Such negotiations may necessitate compensating partners for potential trade losses. If a satisfactory resolution cannot be reached, the aggrieved country may resort to the dispute settlement procedures.

 

4. Transparency: WTO members are obligated to publish their trade regulations, maintain institutions that allow for the review of administrative decisions affecting trade, respond to information requests from other members, and notify the WTO of any changes in trade policies. These internal transparency requirements are complemented by periodic country-specific reports known as trade policy reviews, facilitated by the Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM).

 

5. Safety Valves: In certain situations, governments retain the ability to restrict trade. The WTO's agreements grant members the authority to take measures to protect not only the environment but also public health, animal health, and plant health when specific circumstances warrant such actions. These safety valves serve as mechanisms to address critical issues beyond mere trade considerations.

Question 36
Arrange the following countries in the ascending order of their contribution to the WTO budget 2022: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)(1) China(2) Japan(3) Germany(4) United States of America(5) United KingdomChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1, 2, 4, 5 and 3
  • B.4, 1, 2, 5 and 3
  • C.5, 2, 3, 1 and 4
  • D.4, 1, 2, 3 and 5
Correct Answer: 5, 2, 3, 1 and 4

Countries in the ascending order of their contribution to the WTO budget 2022 are:

United Kingdom – 3.77%

Japan – 3.83%

Germany – 7.16%

China – 10.5%

United States of America – 11.8%

 

Hence the correct answer is C.

Question 37
Match List I with the List II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022) (UGC NET Commerce July 2018)List I (Type of Agreement)a. NAMAb. GATTsc. TRIMsd. TRIPsList II (Explanation)i. Liberation of International Investments.ii. Includes industrial goods, textile,jewellery, fish and fisheries products and manufacturing industries.iii.Liberalisationof trade in goods and services.iv. Provides monopoly power to owners of intellectual property.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a- ii, b-i, c- iv, d- iii
  • B.a- iv, b- ii, c- iii, d-i
  • C.a- ii, b- iii, c-i, d- iv
  • D.a- iii, b- ii, c- iv, d-i
Correct Answer: a- ii, b- iii, c-i, d- iv

List I represents different types of agreements, and List II provides their corresponding explanations.

a. NAMA (Non-Agricultural Market Access): Includes industrial goods, textiles, jewelry, fish and fisheries products, and manufacturing industries.

b. GATTs (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade): Liberalization of trade in goods and services.

c. TRIMs (Trade-Related Investment Measures): Liberation of International Investments.

d. TRIPs (Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights): Provides monopoly power to owners of intellectual property.

Question 38
Arrange the following negotiation rounds of WTO (World TradeOrganisation) in reverse chronological order: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)(a) Uruguay Round(b) Geneva Round(c) Kennedy Round(d) Doha Round(e) Tokyo RoundChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c, d, b, e
  • B.d, a, e, c, b
  • C.b, a, c, e, d
  • D.d, e, a, c, b
Correct Answer: d, a, e, c, b

The negotiation rounds of the World Trade Organization (WTO) took place in the following order:

 

(d) Doha Round: The Doha Round of negotiations began in 2001 and was aimed at addressing various trade issues, including agriculture, services, and intellectual property rights. However, it faced several challenges and was not successfully concluded.

 

(a) Uruguay Round: The Uruguay Round was held from 1986 to 1994 and resulted in the creation of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995. It led to significant reforms in international trade, including the establishment of the WTO and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

 

(e) Tokyo Round: The Tokyo Round of negotiations took place from 1973 to 1979 and focused on reducing tariffs and non-tariff barriers to trade. It was named after the host city, Tokyo, where the negotiations were conducted.

 

(c) Kennedy Round: The Kennedy Round of negotiations was held from 1964 to 1967 and was the sixth round of multilateral trade negotiations. It aimed to liberalize trade in manufactured goods.

 

(b) Geneva Round: The Geneva Round was one of the early rounds of multilateral trade negotiations conducted under the auspices of the GATT. The specific years for this round are not mentioned in the options, but it occurred before the Kennedy Round in the 1960s.

Question 39
Statement I:TRIMS agreement refers to conditions or restrictions imposed on foreign investors.Statement II:TRIMS agreement specifically forbids imposing restrictions on operations of an enterprise which result in protecting domestic products and making imports disadvantageous.Codes:(UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Statement II is correct, but Iisincorrect.
  • C.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are incorrect
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

Both the statements I and II are correct.

 

The Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMs) agreement, part of the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework, recognizes the influence of investment measures on trade. WTO members are prohibited from implementing measures that discriminate against or lead to quantitative restrictions, both of which violate fundamental WTO rules. The agreement includes a list of restricted TRIMs, overseen by the TRIMs Committee, which facilitates consultation among members on relevant issues.

 

The TRIMs agreement, resulting from the Uruguay Round of negotiations, acknowledges that certain investment measures can have restrictive effects on international trade in goods.

 

The TRIMs agreement directly restricts the following practices:

 

1. Local Content Requirement: This measure requires that a developed country trading with a developing country must use domestic components in their products. This encourages the growth of domestic products but can affect the profit margins of foreign companies.

 

2. Trade Balancing Requirements: This measure mandates that the value or quantity of imported products must match the value or quantity of exported products. It ensures a balance in trade but restricts businesses.

 

3. Foreign Exchange Restrictions: These measures limit access to foreign exchange, thereby restricting imports.

 

4. Domestic Sales Requirements: Some nations use domestic sales requirements to restrict the export of domestic products, leading to market saturation and reduced product value.

Question 40
Which among the followings are not guiding fundamental principles of World Trade Organization? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)(a) Non-discrimination(b)Free-trade(c) Social-Welfare(d) Fair competition(e) Market Access Commitment(f) Human Rights(g) Multilateral Trading SystemCodes:
  • A.a, b and c
  • B.c, e and f
  • C.c, f and g
  • D.c and f
Correct Answer: c and f

The World Trade Organization (WTO) is an international organization that primarily focuses on facilitating and regulating international trade among its member countries. Its guiding fundamental principles revolve around promoting and facilitating trade, ensuring fair competition, and expanding market access.

 

These principles include:

 

1. Non-Discrimination: The WTO promotes the principle of non-discrimination in international trade. This means that member countries should not discriminate between their trading partners and should treat all WTO members equally. Two key components of non-discrimination are:

(a) Most-Favored-Nation (MFN) Treatment: WTO members are required to extend the same trade preferences and treatment to all other WTO members. Any trade advantage granted to one member must be offered to all members.

(b) National Treatment: WTO members must treat foreign and domestic goods and services equally once they enter the domestic market. This ensures that imported products are not subjected to unfair treatment or discrimination.

 

2. Free Trade: The WTO promotes the reduction of trade barriers, such as tariffs and quotas, to facilitate the free flow of goods and services across borders. The goal is to create an environment where trade can occur with minimal hindrances.

 

3. Fair Competition: Fair competition is a core principle of the WTO. Member countries are expected to maintain and enforce fair competition policies to prevent anti-competitive practices, such as monopolies and unfair subsidies, which can distort international trade.

 

4. Market Access Commitment: WTO members commit to providing market access to foreign goods and services on a non-discriminatory basis. This means that countries should not impose unjustified trade restrictions or barriers that hinder market access for foreign products.

 

However, the WTO does not explicitly address principles related to social welfare or human rights as its core mandate. While some discussions within the WTO may touch on issues related to social and environmental concerns, the organization's primary focus remains on trade-related matters and the promotion of economic cooperation among its member states.

Quiz Attempt #119464

Total Questions: 30
Question 1
Which of the following intellectual properties were covered under the Uruguay Round Agreement on TRIPS?(i) Copyrights(ii) Trademarks(iii) Industrial designs(iv) Undisclosed information, including trade secretsCodes:
  • A.(i) and (ii) only
  • B.(i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)

The Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPs) sets down minimum standards for many forms of intellectual property (IP) regulation. It was negotiated at the end of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1994, where following were included in TRIPS:

Copyright and Related Rights

Trademarks

Geographical Indications

Industrial Designs

Patents

Layout-Designs (Topographies) 

 

On 20 December 1991 the Director-General Arthur Dunkel produced a compromise legislative draft, the ‘Draft Final Act embodying the result of the Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations’. It became known as the Dunkel Draft or the DFA. The Dunkel Draft tried to draw the somewhat stalled IP talks towards a compromise agreement. Dunkel attempted to build consensus on contentious areas by awarding the major states each some success, while balancing it with the wishes of the others.

Question 2
As per WTO guidelines Agreement on Agricultural (AOA) is not considering which of following? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.R&D and any other indirect support and assistance to farmers by the government.
  • B.Direct payment to farmers.
  • C.Least development countries do not need to make cuts.
  • D.Cut back of domestic policies which directly affect production and trade.
Correct Answer: R&D and any other indirect support and assistance to farmers by the government.

  • Option A – Correct (Not considered for reduction):
    Government support for R&D, training, pest control, infrastructure, and advisory services is categorized under the Green Box in the Agreement on Agriculture. These are not subject to reduction commitments as they are considered to have minimal or no trade-distorting effects.

  • Option B – Incorrect:
    Direct payments to farmers are allowed only if decoupled from production. These are part of Green or Blue Box measures and are addressed in the AOA.

  • Option C – Incorrect:
    It is considered in AOA that Least Developed Countries (LDCs) do not need to make cuts. This is an explicit provision.

  • Option D – Incorrect:
    Domestic policies that distort production and trade are definitely considered under the AOA and are subject to reduction (Amber Box).

Question 3
Which combination of the following is correct with regard to World Trade Organization (WTO): (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)(a) WTO initiates peace process among the member countries to enhance international trade.(b) WTO avoids the task of “Settlement of Disputes” among the member countries.(c) WTO administers the “Trade Review Mechanism”.(d) WTO cooperates in an appropriate manner with the IMF and the World Bank.Codes:
  • A.b, c and d
  • B.a and c
  • C.c and d
  • D.a, b and d
Correct Answer: c and d

Let us look at all options.

 

(a) WTO initiates peace process among the member countries to enhance international trade. - This statement is not accurate. While the WTO aims to facilitate peaceful trade relations among member countries, it does not initiate a "peace process" in the traditional sense. Its primary focus is on trade agreements and dispute resolution related to trade issues.

 

(b) WTO avoids the task of "Settlement of Disputes" among the member countries. - This statement is incorrect. One of the core functions of the WTO is to provide a forum for the settlement of trade disputes among member countries through the Dispute Settlement Body (DSB).

 

(c) WTO administers the "Trade Review Mechanism." - This statement is correct. The Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM) is a process in which WTO members voluntarily submit their trade policies and practices for review by other members. It is administered by the WTO.

 

(d) WTO cooperates in an appropriate manner with the IMF and the World Bank. - This statement is correct. The WTO, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the World Bank often cooperate and coordinate their efforts, especially in areas where their work overlaps, such as trade and economic development.

 

The correct answer is option C.

Question 4
Possible impact of WTO on various aspects of the Indian economy: (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)(i) Quantitative restriction will be allowed.(ii) Second hand cars will be imported.(iii) There will be dumping of Chinese goods.(iv) Increase in population.(v) Child labour exploitation.(vi) Unemployment will increase.Which combination is appropriate?
  • A.i, ii, iii
  • B.iii, iv, v
  • C.ii, iii & vi
  • D.iv, v & vi
Correct Answer: ii, iii & vi

The impact of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on various aspects of the Indian economy can be analyzed as follows:

 

(i) Quantitative restriction will be allowed: With India's membership in the WTO, it became necessary to reduce or eliminate quantitative restrictions on imports, making trade more liberalized. Quantitative restrictions were phased out, allowing for a more open trading environment.

 

(ii) Second-hand cars will be imported: The reduction in trade barriers, including tariffs and quantitative restrictions, as a result of WTO membership, made it possible for second-hand cars to be imported into India. This change expanded the choices available to consumers.

 

(iii) There will be dumping of Chinese goods: The liberalization of trade under the WTO framework allowed for increased imports from various countries, including China. While it led to greater access to products, it also raised concerns about anti-dumping measures to protect domestic industries.

 

(iv) Increase in population: The WTO itself does not directly impact population growth in a country. Population growth is influenced by various socio-economic and demographic factors, but it is not a direct consequence of WTO membership.

 

(v) Child labor exploitation: The WTO has provisions that allow countries to impose trade restrictions on products produced with child labor. Therefore, WTO membership does not necessarily lead to child labor exploitation; rather, it provides tools to address this issue through trade measures.

 

(vi) Unemployment will increase: The impact of WTO membership on unemployment is a complex issue. While trade liberalization can create opportunities for job growth in export-oriented industries, it can also lead to job displacement in sectors that face increased competition. The effect on unemployment depends on various factors, including domestic policies and economic conditions.

 

Based on the above analysis, option (C) "ii, iii & vi" is the most appropriate combination as it reflects the impact of WTO on the import of second-hand cars, the possibility of goods dumping, and potential implications for unemployment.

Question 5
Concessions mainly multinational in character come under the principle of: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Non-discrimination
  • B.Reciprocity
  • C.Market Access
  • D.Fair Competition
Correct Answer: Reciprocity

The principle that deals with concessions mainly of a multinational nature is known as "Reciprocity."

 

In the context of international trade and trade agreements, reciprocity refers to the practice of granting similar or equivalent trade concessions, privileges, or benefits between countries. It involves mutual agreements where one country grants certain trade advantages to another country in exchange for receiving similar advantages in return. Reciprocity is a fundamental principle in international trade negotiations and trade agreements, ensuring that trade benefits are balanced and equitable among participating nations.

Question 6
Match the items of List- I with items of List- II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)List- Ia. Measures towards globalizationb. Off-shoringc. FERAd.Mr.AruthurDunkelList- IIi. Globalisationii. FEMAiii. Liberalise the inflow of FDIiv. Uruguay RoundCodes:
  • A.a- iii, b-i, c- ii, d- iv
  • B.a- ii, b-i, c- iii, d- iv
  • C.a- iv, b- ii, c-i, d- iii
  • D.a-i, b- ii, c- iv, d- iii
Correct Answer: a- iii, b-i, c- ii, d- iv

The correct matching of items from List I with items from List II is as follows:

a. Measures towards globalization - iii. Liberalize the inflow of FDI

b. Off-shoring - i. Globalization

c. FERA - ii. FEMA

d. Mr. Arthur Dunkel - iv. Uruguay Round

 

a. Measures towards globalization - iii. Liberalize the inflow of FDI

This matching suggests that measures towards globalization involve the liberalization of foreign direct investment (FDI), which means making it easier for foreign investors to invest in a country.

 

b. Off-shoring - i. Globalization

This matching indicates that off-shoring, which is the practice of moving certain business processes or activities to other countries, is a part of the broader process of globalization.

 

c. FERA - ii. FEMA

FERA stands for the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (1973), which was an older regulation in India governing foreign exchange transactions. FEMA stands for the Foreign Exchange Management Act (1999), which replaced FERA and is the current regulatory framework for foreign exchange management in India.

 

d. Mr. Arthur Dunkel - iv. Uruguay Round

Mr. Arthur Dunkel was a Swiss diplomat who chaired the Uruguay Round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). The Uruguay Round eventually led to the establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and various trade agreements.

Question 7
Match the following with the year of establishment: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2010)List- I(a) World Trade Organisation(b) Uruguay Round Negotiation(c) W.T.O. – Trade Policy Review Body(d) The Patents (Amendment) Act.List- IIi. 1993ii. 1995iii. 1997iv. 1999Codes:
  • A.a-i, b- iii, c- iv, d- ii
  • B.a-i, b- iv, c- iii, d- ii
  • C.a- ii, b-i, c- iii, d- iv
  • D.a- iv, b- ii, c-i, d- iii
Correct Answer: a- ii, b-i, c- iii, d- iv

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The World Trade Organization (WTO) is an international organization that deals with the global rules of trade between nations. It was established on January 1, 1995, as a successor to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

 

The Uruguay Round was a series of international trade negotiations that were conducted under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and led to the establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The Uruguay Round negotiations took place from 1986 to 1994 and were one of the most comprehensive and significant trade negotiations in history.

 

The Trade Policy Review Body (TPRB) is one of the subsidiary bodies of the World Trade Organization (WTO). Its primary function is to conduct regular reviews of the trade policies and practices of WTO member countries.

 

The Patents (Amendment) Act 1999 provided for filing of applications for product patents in the areas of drugs, pharmaceuticals and agro chemicals though such patents were not allowed.

Question 8
The WTO was born out of negotiations in which round of the GATT?
  • A.Geneva Round
  • B.Uruguay Round
  • C.Torquay Round
  • D.Tokyo Round
Correct Answer: Uruguay Round

Over the years, GATT evolved through 8 rounds of multilateral trade negotiations, the last and most extensive being the Uruguay Round (1986-1994). The WTO came into being at Marrakesh on 1 January 1995, following the conclusion of the Uruguay Round. GATT then ceased to exist, and its legal texts were incorporated into the WTO as GATT 1994.

Question 9
The current round of negotiation in the WTO is known as the:
  • A.Doha Development Round (DDA)
  • B.Cancun Meet
  • C.Torquay Round
  • D.Seattle Summit
Correct Answer: Doha Development Round (DDA)

The Doha Development Round or Doha Development Agenda (DDA) is the current trade-negotiation round of the World Trade Organization (WTO) which commenced in November 2001. Its objective is to lower trade barriers around the world, and thus facilitate increased global trade. Since 2008, talks have stalled over a divide on major issues. There are 4 major areas of negotiation in the Doha round are Agriculture, Non-Agricultural Market Access (NAMA), Services, and Trade Facilitation. The negotiations also include other areas such as Rules and Dispute Settlement.

Question 10
Which of the following Statements is true? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.GATT stands for Generalised Agreement on Trade and Transfer
  • B.WTO came into being in 1948
  • C.GATT was created in 1947
  • D.Council for settlement of disputes is a subsidiary body of General Council of WTO
Correct Answer: GATT was created in 1947

The correct statement is (C) GATT was created in 1947.

GATT stands for the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, and it was indeed created in 1947. It was an international treaty aimed at reducing trade barriers and promoting international trade. The World Trade Organization (WTO) came into being later, in 1995, as a result of the Uruguay Round of GATT negotiations.

Question 11
The General Agreement on Trade in Services, GATS entered into force on ___________.
  • A.January 1992
  • B.January 1993
  • C.January 1994
  • D.January 1995
Correct Answer: January 1995

Over the years, GATT evolved through 8 rounds of multilateral trade negotiations, the last and most extensive being the Uruguay Round (1986-1994). The WTO came into being at Marrakesh on 1 January 1995, following the conclusion of the Uruguay Round. GATT then ceased to exist, and its legal texts were incorporated into the WTO as GATT 1994.

Question 12
What are the principles of WTO (Trading Systems)?(i) Non-discrimination(ii) Reciprocity(iii) Binding and enforceable commitments(iv) Transparency(v) Safety valvesCodes:
  • A.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv)  only
  • B.(i) (ii) (iv) (v) only
  • C.(i) (ii) (iii) only
  • D.(i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v)
Correct Answer: (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v)

The correct answer is (D) (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) (v).

 

The principles of the World Trade Organization (WTO) trading system include:

 

1. Non-discrimination: This principle encompasses the Most Favoured Nation (MFN) rule and National Treatment Policy. MFN requires that WTO members grant the most favorable trade conditions to all other WTO members, ensuring that no member is given preferential treatment. National treatment means that imported goods should be treated no less favorably than domestically produced goods once they enter the market.

 

2. Reciprocity: Reciprocity is based on the idea of mutual concessions in trade negotiations. It aims to limit free-riding and encourages countries to negotiate trade agreements to gain better access to foreign markets.

 

3. Binding and enforceable commitments: WTO members make tariff commitments through negotiated schedules. These commitments are binding and enforceable, and any changes require negotiation with trading partners. Dispute settlement procedures can be invoked if disagreements arise.

 

4. Transparency: Members are required to publish their trade regulations, maintain institutions for reviewing administrative decisions affecting trade, respond to information requests from other members, and notify changes in trade policies to the WTO. Trade policy reviews through the Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM) facilitate transparency and peer assessments.

 

5. Safety valves: WTO agreements allow governments to implement trade restrictions in specific circumstances to protect public health, animal health, plant health, and the environment.

Question 13
Uruguay Round pertains to, which of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)
  • A.WTO
  • B.IMF
  • C.GATT
  • D.World Bank
Correct Answer: GATT

The Uruguay Round pertains to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). It was a series of trade negotiations that took place from 1986 to 1994 and resulted in the establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1995. The WTO is the successor organization to GATT and is responsible for overseeing international trade agreements and resolving trade disputes among its member countries.

Question 14
Statement I:Green Box subsidies include the amount spent on Government services such as research, disease control, and infrastructure and food security. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)Statement II:Blue Box subsidies are certain direct payments made to farmers, to limit production, and are certain government assistance programmes to encourage agriculture and rural development.Codes:
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is not correct.
  • B.Statement II is correct, but I is not correct.
  • C.Both statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both statements I and II are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both statements I and II are correct.

In WTO terminology, subsidies in general are identified by “boxes” which are given the colors of traffic lights. 

 

Nearly all domestic support measures considered to distort production and trade (with some exceptions) fall into the Amber box, which is defined in the Agriculture Agreement as all domestic supports except those in the blue and green boxes. These include measures to support prices, or subsidies directly related to production quantities.

 

Blue Box is the “amber box with conditions” conditions designed to reduce distortion. Any support that would normally be in the amber box, is placed in the blue box if the support also requires farmers to limit production. 

 

The Green Box is defined in the Agriculture Agreement as those subsidies that do not distort trade, or at most cause minimal distortion. They have to be government-funded (not by charging consumers higher prices) and must not involve price support.

 

The Red box are those subsidies, which are totally forbidden.

 

Therefore, both statements I and II are correct, and the correct option is (C).

Question 15
A situation where any advantage given by one member of the WTO to another member is extended to all WTO members is referred to as_______. (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)
  • A.Trade Diversion
  • B.Inter-Regional Principle
  • C.MostFavoredNation
  • D.Least Traded Nation
Correct Answer: MostFavoredNation

A situation where any advantage given by one member of the WTO to another member is extended to all WTO members is referred to as the "Most Favored Nation" (MFN) principle. This principle requires that a WTO member must apply the same trade conditions and advantages to all other WTO members, ensuring equal treatment among trading partners.

Question 16
Arrange the following in the correct sequence on the basis of chronological order from the earliest to the latest: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)(a) World Trade Organization(b)DunkelDraft(c) The Uruguay Round(d) General Agreement on Trade and TariffCodes:
  • A.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
  • B.(d), (c), (b) and (a)
  • C.(b), (a), (c) and (d)
  • D.(c), (d), (b) and (a)
Correct Answer: (d), (c), (b) and (a)

The correct chronological order of the given events is as follows:

1. General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs (GATT): 1947

2. The Uruguay Round: 1986-1994

3. Dunkel Draft: 1991

4. World Trade Organization (WTO): 1994

 

So, the correct sequence from the earliest to the latest is (B) (d), (c), (b), and (a).

Question 17
Which among the following is closely associated with intellectual property rights? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)
  • A.GATS
  • B.TRIMS
  • C.TRIPS
  • D.MFN
Correct Answer: TRIPS

The term closely associated with intellectual property rights is "TRIPS," which stands for Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights. TRIPS is an agreement under the World Trade Organization (WTO) that sets out the minimum standards for various forms of intellectual property protection that member countries must adhere to. Therefore, the correct answer is (C) TRIPS.

Question 18
Under TRIPS Agreement, the patent is granted subject to which of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)a. The product or process is a new one.b. It contains an inventive step.c. It is capable of industrial application for 15 years from the grant of the patent.d. It is capable of industrial application for 20 years from the grant of the patent.Codes:
  • A.Only a and b
  • B.Only a, b and c
  • C.Only a, b and d
  • D.Only a and d
Correct Answer: Only a, b and d

Under the TRIPS (Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights) Agreement, which is a part of the World Trade Organization (WTO), patents are granted based on specific conditions:

 

a. Novelty: The product or process for which a patent is sought must be new, meaning it should not have been publicly disclosed or used before.

 

b. Inventive Step: The invention should involve an inventive step or, in other words, it should not be obvious to someone skilled in the relevant field.

 

c. Industrial Application: The invention must be capable of industrial application. This means it should have practical utility and be useful in an industrial or commercial context.

 

d. Duration: Patents are typically granted for a specific period. Under the TRIPS Agreement, the standard duration of patent protection is 20 years from the date of filing the patent application.

 

These conditions are designed to ensure that patents are only granted for inventions that meet certain criteria of novelty, inventiveness, and practicality. Additionally, the TRIPS Agreement allows for limited exceptions to patent rights to ensure that they do not unreasonably conflict with the normal exploitation of the patent or prejudice the legitimate interests of third parties.

 

Overall, the TRIPS Agreement sets out international standards for the protection of intellectual property rights, including patents, with the aim of fostering innovation and ensuring fair competition in the global marketplace.

Question 19
The forum which reviews the trade policies of all WTO member countries is which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.DSB
  • B.TPRB
  • C.TRIPS
  • D.General Council
Correct Answer: TPRB

The purpose of the Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM) is to contribute to improved adherence by all Members to rules, disciplines and commitments made under the Multilateral Trade Agreements and, Plurilateral Trade Agreements. The reviews take place in the Trade Policy Review Body (TPRB) which is actually the WTO General Council comprising the WTO’s full membership operating under special rules and procedures. The reviews are therefore essentially peer-group assessments, although much of the factual leg-work is done by the WTO Secretariat.

Question 20
The three disciplines of WTO agreements are:(UGC NET MANAGEMENT SEP 2013)
  • A.International trade in goods, international transactions in services and protection of intellectual property rights.
  • B.International trade in goods, an international transaction in services and protection of interest of MNCs.
  • C.International trade in goods, an international transaction in services and protection of interest of P.S. units.
  • D.International trade in goods, an international transaction in services and protection of interest of Domestic Government.
Correct Answer: International trade in goods, international transactions in services and protection of intellectual property rights.

Most of the issues that the WTO focuses on, are derived from previous trade negotiations. The Agreement of 1994 focuses on 6 main parts:

1. Agreement establishing the WTO

2. Goods and investment: The Multilateral Agreements on Trade in Goods including the GATT 1994 and the Trade Related Investment Measures (TRIMs)

3. Services: The General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS)

4. Intellectual property: Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS)

5. Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU)

6. Reviews of governments’ trade policies through Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM)

 

Hence the correct answer is A.

Question 21
In the Dispute Settlement Mechanism of WTO how much maximum time is allowed for Appellate Review?
  • A.Up to 60 days
  • B.Up to 120 days
  • C.Up to 90 days
  • D.Up to 30 days
Correct Answer: Up to 90 days

Each appeal is heard by 3 members of a permanent 7 member Appellate Body set up by the DSB and broadly representing the range of WTO membership. Members of the Appellate Body have 4 year terms.  The appeal can uphold, modify or reverse the panel’s legal findings and conclusions. Normally appeals should not last more than 60 days, with an absolute maximum of 90 days.

Question 22
The components of W.T.O. are.
  • A.Ministerial Conference
  • B.Disputes Settlement Body
  • C.Director General
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

The WTO (World Trade Organization) consists of several key components:

 

A. Ministerial Conference: The highest decision-making body of the WTO, which typically convenes every two years. It brings together trade ministers from member countries to discuss and make decisions on various trade-related matters.

 

B. Dispute Settlement Body (DSB): This body has the authority to establish dispute settlement panels, refer matters to arbitration, adopt panel, Appellate Body, and arbitration reports, and oversee the implementation of recommendations and rulings contained in these reports. It also has the power to authorize the suspension of concessions in cases of non-compliance with these recommendations and rulings.

 

C. Director-General: The Director-General of the WTO is responsible for overseeing the administrative functions of the organization. While the Director-General does not have significant policymaking authority, their role is advisory and managerial in nature. The Director-General serves a term and is responsible for managing the day-to-day operations of the WTO.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) All of the above, as all these components play crucial roles in the functioning of the WTO.

Question 23
Which among the following are important bodies of WTO? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)i. Dispute Settlement Body.ii. NAFTAiii. Trade Policy Review Body.iv. ASEANv. Council for Trade in Goodsvi. IBRDvii. Council for Trade related aspects of Intellectual Property Rights.viii. GATTAn appropriate combination is
  • A.i, ii, iii, iv
  • B.ii, iii, iv, v
  • C.i, iii, v, vii
  • D.iv, v, vi, viii
Correct Answer: i, iii, v, vii

Important bodies within the WTO include:

 

1. The Dispute Settlement Body (DSB), which holds the authority to establish dispute resolution panels, refer cases to arbitration, adopt reports from panels, the Appellate Body, and arbitration, oversee the implementation of recommendations and rulings contained in these reports, and authorize the suspension of concessions in cases of non-compliance with such recommendations and rulings.

 

2. The Trade Policy Review Mechanism (TPRM), which was introduced in the GATT in 1989 after the Mid-Term Review of the Uruguay Round and was later confirmed as an integral part of the WTO in Annex 3 of the Marrakesh Agreement that established the World Trade Organization. The primary purpose of the TPRM is to enhance adherence by all WTO members to the rules, disciplines, and commitments outlined in the Multilateral Trade Agreements and, when applicable, Plurilateral Trade Agreements. It aims to achieve this by promoting greater transparency and understanding of the trade policies and practices of WTO members, thus contributing to the smoother operation of the multilateral trading system.

 

3. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), which governs international trade in goods. Oversight of the GATT agreement falls under the purview of the Council for Trade in Goods (Goods Council), composed of representatives from all WTO member nations.

 

4. The WTO Council for Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS Council), responsible for monitoring the implementation of the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (the TRIPS Agreement). Additionally, it serves as a platform for WTO members to consult on matters related to intellectual property and carries out specific responsibilities assigned to it within the TRIPS Agreement.

Question 24
The main features of TRIMS are:(i) All restrictions on foreign capital are imposed.(ii) No restriction is imposed on any area of investment.(iii) Restrictions on repatriation of dividend is eliminated.(iv) Imports of raw material is allowed freely.(v) No limit on the extent of foreign investment.Indicate the correct combination
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (v)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv) and (v)
  • C.(iii), (iv) and (v)
  • D.(iv) and (v)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iii), (iv) and (v)

The Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMS) are rules that apply to the domestic regulations a country applies to foreign investors, often as part of an industrial policy. TRIMs are rules that restrict preference of domestic firms and thereby enable international firms to operate more easily within foreign markets.

 

The key features of TRIM are:

1. Abolition of restriction imposed on foreign capital.

2. Offering equal rights to the foreign investor on par with the domestic investor

3. No restrictions on any area of investment.

4. No limitation or ceiling on the quantum of foreign investment.

5. Granting of permission of without restrictions to import raw material and other components.

6. No force on the foreign investors to use the total products and or materials

7. Export of the part of the final product will not be mandatory

8. Restriction on repatriation of dividend interest and royalty will be removed

9. Phased manufacturing programming will be introduced to increase the domestic content of manufacturer.

Question 25
Which of the following intellectual properties were covered under Uruguay Round Agreement on TRIPS? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)(i) Copy rights(ii) Trade marks(iii) Industrial designs(iv) Undisclosed information, including trade secretsCodes:
  • A.(i) and (ii) only
  • B.(i), (ii) and (iii)
  • C.(ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)

The areas of intellectual property covered under Uruguay Round Agreement are:

1. Copyright and related rights (i.e. the rights of performers, producers of sound recordings and broadcasting organizations); 

2. Trademarks including service marks; 

3. Geographical indications including appellations of origin; 

3. Industrial designs; 

4. Patents including the protection of new varieties of plants; 

5. The layout-designs of integrated circuits; and 

6. Undisclosed information including trade secrets and test data.

Question 26
The important objectives of WTO are:(i) To improve the quality of technology in the member countries.(ii) To improve the standard of living of people in the member countries.(iii) To ensure full employment and broad increase in effective demand.(iv) To enlarge production and trade of goods.(v) To increase trade of servicesCodes:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv) and (v)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii) and (v)
  • D.(i), (iii), (iv) and (v)
Correct Answer: (ii), (iii), (iv) and (v)

The WTO has six key objectives:

(1) to set and enforce rules for international trade,

(2) to provide a forum for negotiating and monitoring further trade liberalization,

(3) to resolve trade disputes,

(4) to increase the transparency of decision-making processes,

(5) to cooperate with other major international economic institutions involved in global economic management, and

(6) to help developing countries benefit fully from the global trading system.

Question 27
Which among the following are criticisms given against World Trade Organization (WTO)? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)(a) It is not a democratic and transparent institution.(b) It has domination of international trade by rich countries for the benefit of their individual interests.(c) It encourages a ‘race to the bottom’ in wages by pitting workers against each other rather than promoting internationally recognized labour standards.(d) It is seeking to privatize essential public services.Codes :
  • A.(b), (c) and (d)
  • B.(a), (b) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b) and (d)
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c) and (d)

The correct code is (D) (a), (b), (c), and (d).

 

here's an explanation of the criticisms against the World Trade Organization (WTO) as mentioned in the options:

 

(a) Lack of Democracy and Transparency

Critics argue that the WTO is not a democratic institution because its decision-making processes are often seen as opaque and not inclusive. Some argue that major decisions are made by a select few powerful member countries, excluding the voices of smaller or less economically developed nations. This lack of transparency and inclusivity can undermine the democratic principles that are typically expected from international organizations.

 

(b) Dominance of Rich Countries

Critics contend that the WTO tends to favor the interests of economically powerful and developed countries, often at the expense of less-developed nations. They argue that the rules and agreements within the WTO are structured in a way that benefits wealthy countries, allowing them to maintain their dominance in international trade while making it challenging for developing countries to compete on an equal footing.

 

(c) Race to the Bottom in Wages

Some critics assert that the WTO's focus on reducing trade barriers and promoting globalization can lead to a "race to the bottom" in wages and labor standards. This means that countries may lower labor standards and wages in an attempt to attract foreign investment and compete in global markets. Critics argue that the WTO does not do enough to enforce internationally recognized labor standards, potentially leading to exploitation of workers in pursuit of economic competitiveness.

 

(d) Privatization of Public Services

Another criticism leveled at the WTO is that it encourages the privatization of essential public services. This criticism is particularly directed at trade agreements and policies that may require countries to open up their public services, such as healthcare, education, and water supply, to foreign competition. Critics argue that this can lead to a loss of control over essential services and prioritize profit motives over the welfare of citizens.

Question 28
Assertion ‘A’:Amended Patent Act, in compliance with WTO, provides for grant of product patent as well as a process patent for a period of 20 years from the date of applicationReasoning ‘R’: Under the Act, patent may be granted to an invention which means a new product or process involving an inventive step and capable of industrial application, a technical advance over existing knowledge.Codes:
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are true but ‘R’, is not correct explanation to ‘A’.
  • B.‘A’ is false but ‘R’ is correct.
  • C.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are true but ‘R’, is correct explanation to ‘A’.
  • D.‘A’ is correct but ‘R’ is false.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are true but ‘R’, is correct explanation to ‘A’.

The assertion (A) states that the Amended Patent Act, in compliance with the WTO, provides for the grant of both product and process patents for a period of 20 years from the date of application. The Patents (Amendment) Act, 2005 is the amendment to the Patents Act of 1970, to bring India’s patent regime into compliance with the WTO TRIPS Agreement. It extends the product patent protection to the areas of pharmaceuticals and agricultural chemicals.

 

The reasoning (R) states that under the Act, a patent may be granted to an invention, which means a new product or process involving an inventive step and capable of industrial application, and it should represent a technical advance over existing knowledge.

 

Both the assertion and reasoning are true, and the reasoning explains why the assertion is true. The Amended Patent Act did indeed introduce provisions for the grant of both product and process patents for a period of 20 years from the date of application, and it requires inventions to meet specific criteria, including being new, involving an inventive step, being capable of industrial application, and representing a technical advance over existing knowledge.

Question 29
Which one among the following is not a part of TRIPS agreement? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.Industrial Design
  • B.Geographical Indications
  • C.Interior Design
  • D.Layout Designs of Integrated Circuits
Correct Answer: Interior Design

TRIPS stands for Trade Related Intellectual Property Rights and came into effect on 1st January, 1995. TRIPs provide minimum standards in the form of common set of rules for the protection of intellectual property globally under WTO system. Member countries have to prepare necessary national laws to implement the TRIPs provisions. TRIPs cover eight areas for IPRs legislation:  

1. Copyright and related rights (i.e. the rights of performers, producers of sound recordings and broadcasting organizations); 

2. Trademarks including service marks; 

3. Geographical indications including appellations of origin;

4. Industrial designs;

5. Patents including the protection of new varieties of plants; 

6. The layout-designs of integrated circuits; and 

7. Undisclosed information including trade secrets and test data.

Question 30
Match the items of List - II and with the items of List - I relating to WTO impact:List - I(a) NAMA(b) GATS(c) TRIMs(d) TRIPsList - II(i) Liberalization of international investments.(ii) Includes industrial goods, textile, jewellery,fishand fisheries product manufacturing industries.(iii) Liberalization of trade in services.(iv) Provides monopoly power to owners of intellectual property.Codes :
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(i)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)

The matching of items in List I with List II relating to the impact of the World Trade Organization (WTO) is as follows:

 

(a) NAMA (Non-Agricultural Market Access) refers to trade liberalization rules concerning major non-agricultural goods under the WTO. It includes industrial goods, manufacturing products, textiles, fuels and mining products, footwear, jewelry, forestry products, fish and fisheries, and chemicals. (ii) Liberalization of international investments.

 

(b) GATS (General Agreement on Trade in Services) aims to gradually remove barriers to trade in services and covers various modes of supplying services across borders. (iii) Liberalization of trade in services.

 

(c) TRIMs (Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures) recognizes that certain investment measures can restrict and distort trade. (i) Liberalization of international investments.

 

(d) TRIPs (Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights) provides standards of protection for various areas of intellectual property, granting monopoly power to owners of intellectual property. (iv) Provides monopoly power to owners of intellectual property.

 

So, the correct matching of items is (C) (ii) (iii) (i) (iv).

Quiz Attempt #119465

Total Questions: 39
Question 1
The tool that International Development Association (IDA) uses to address the impact of severe natural disasters, public health emergencies by providing extra finances is known as:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Emergency Response Fund (ERF)
  • B.Long term Lending system
  • C.Crisis Response Window (CRW)
  • D.Monetary Fund
Correct Answer: Crisis Response Window (CRW)

The Crisis Response Window (CRW) is a tool used by the International Development Association (IDA) to provide additional financial resources to countries affected by severe natural disasters, public health emergencies, and other crises. This helps affected countries recover and rebuild more effectively.

Question 2
Which of the following are the main objectives of establishment of International Monetary Fund (IMF)?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. To provide long-term funds at concession rates to the poorest member countries.B. To promote the development of Private enterprises in member countries.C. To regulate the exchange rates and enforce the rules.D. To promote exchange stability, maintaining orderly exchange arrangements and avoiding competitive exchange devaluation.E. To assist in establishment of a multilateral system of payments in respect of current transaction between members.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, C and E only
  • D.C, D and E only
Correct Answer: C, D and E only

The correct answer is (D) C, D, and E only

The main objectives of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) include:

C. To regulate the exchange rates and enforce the rules.

D. To promote exchange stability, maintaining orderly exchange arrangements, and avoiding competitive exchange devaluation.

E. To assist in the establishment of a multilateral system of payments in respect of current transactions between members.

Question 3
_____ is the result of the Bretton Woods Conference of nations held in 1944.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)1. WTO2. IMF3. IBRD4. ADBSelect the correct answer using the codes given below.
  • A.1 and 2
  • B.2 and 3
  • C.3 and 4
  • D.1, 3 and 4
Correct Answer: 2 and 3

On July 1, 1944, while World War II continued in Europe and the Pacific, delegates from forty-four nations gathered at the Mount Washington Hotel in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire. Their goal was to establish a framework for economic stability and international cooperation to aid post-war recovery and promote long-term global growth. The conference resulted in the creation of the Articles of Agreement for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) and the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

Question 4
Which of the following organizations play an active role to prevent the contagion situation of crisis, such as the Greek Sovereign debt crisis? (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.IMF
  • B.World Bank
  • C.WTO
  • D.UNCTAD
Correct Answer: IMF

The organization actively involved in preventing contagion situations during crises, such as the Greek Sovereign debt crisis, is the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

 

The Greek Sovereign debt crisis, which commenced in late 2009, revolved around Greece's severe debt issues and its government's financial challenges. During such financial crises, there is a risk of contagion, where the crisis can spread to other countries and regions, causing financial instability and impacting the global economy.

 

The IMF is an international organization with the primary goal of promoting global monetary cooperation, ensuring financial stability, facilitating international trade, promoting high employment, fostering sustainable economic growth, and reducing poverty worldwide. When a crisis like the Greek debt crisis emerges, the IMF intervenes to offer financial assistance and support to countries grappling with economic hardships.

 

The IMF provides financial programs and offers policy guidance to help countries stabilize their economies, rebuild investor confidence, and prevent the crisis from spreading to other nations. Through its financial assistance and close collaboration with affected countries, the IMF takes an active role in averting and managing contagion situations during financial crises.

Question 5
Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), an affiliate of World Bank, aims to address which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.To promote comparative advantage among the trading nations to foster international trade
  • B.To promote a platform for dispute settlement mechanism in world trade guarantee
  • C.To encourage foreign direct investment in developing countries by protecting investors from non-commercial risk
  • D.To promote international trade in goods and intelligence services
Correct Answer: To encourage foreign direct investment in developing countries by protecting investors from non-commercial risk

The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) is indeed an affiliate of the World Bank. It was established in 1988 with the goal of promoting foreign direct investment (FDI) in developing countries.

 

MIGA's primary objective is to encourage FDI by providing political risk insurance and credit enhancement guarantees to investors and lenders. The agency protects investors from various non-commercial risks that they may face when investing in developing countries. These risks can include political risks such as expropriation, currency inconvertibility, breach of contract by the host government, and other forms of political instability.

 

By offering insurance against these non-commercial risks, MIGA aims to attract more foreign investors to invest in developing countries and thereby support their economic development and growth. This helps create a more conducive environment for foreign investment, which can lead to increased capital inflows, job creation, technology transfer, and overall economic development in these countries.

Question 6
Which of the following institutions is known as the 'soft loan window' of the World Bank? [UGC NET Management Jun 2019]
  • A.International Monetary Fund
  • B.International Development Agency
  • C.International Finance Corporation
  • D.Asian Development Bank
Correct Answer: International Development Agency

A Soft Loan is a loan with a below-market rate of interest. This is also known as soft financing. Sometimes soft loans provide other concessions to borrowers, such as long repayment periods or interest holidays. Soft loans are usually provided by governments to projects they think are worthwhile. The World Bank and other development institutions provide soft loans to developing countries.

 

The International Development Association (IDA) is an international financial institution which offers concessional loans and grants to the world's poorest developing countries. The IDA is a member of the World Bank Group and is headquartered in Washington, D.C., United States.

Question 7
Which one of the following is not the guiding principle of World Bank regarding its lending operation? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022) (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Proper assessment of repayment prospects loan.
  • B.Lending should be only for specific projects which are economically and technically sound and of a high priority nature.
  • C.The lending should enable a country to foreign exchange content of the project cost.
  • D.The bank does expect the borrowing country to spend the loan in a particular country.
Correct Answer: The bank does expect the borrowing country to spend the loan in a particular country.

The World Bank has certain guiding principles and criteria for its lending operations to member countries. Let's break down each option to understand why option (D) is the correct answer:

 

(A) Proper assessment of repayment prospects: The World Bank is very concerned about the ability of the borrowing country to repay the loan. They conduct a thorough assessment to ensure that the borrowing country has the financial capacity to repay the loan, and they often work with the country to improve its creditworthiness.

 

(B) Lending for economically and technically sound projects: The World Bank aims to fund projects that are economically and technically viable and of high priority for the borrowing country. This ensures that the projects have a better chance of success and contribute to the country's development.

 

(C) Foreign exchange content of the project cost: The World Bank encourages projects that have a foreign exchange content, meaning that they help the country earn foreign currency through exports or other means. This helps the country's balance of payments and foreign exchange reserves.

 

(D) The bank does not expect the borrowing country to spend the loan in a particular country: This statement is inaccurate. The World Bank typically does not dictate how the borrowing country should spend the loan. Instead, it provides funding for specific projects and programs, and it is up to the borrowing country to manage and allocate those funds.

Question 8
Bretton Woods Conference resulted into the establishment of which of the following? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.IMF and IDA
  • B.IDA and ADB
  • C.IMF and IBRD
  • D.IBRD and IFC
Correct Answer: IMF and IBRD

The Bretton Woods Conference took place in July 1944 and led to the creation of two important international institutions:

 

1. IMF (International Monetary Fund): The IMF was established to promote international monetary cooperation, exchange rate stability, and provide temporary financial assistance to member countries facing balance of payments problems.

 

2. IBRD (International Bank for Reconstruction and Development): Also known as the World Bank, the IBRD was created to provide long-term loans and financial assistance to developing countries for projects that aim to reduce poverty and promote economic development.

Question 9
Which among the following institutions is NOT a part of World Bank group? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.International Development Association (IDA)
  • B.International Monetary Fund (IMF)
  • C.International Finance Corporation (IFC)
  • D.Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
Correct Answer: International Monetary Fund (IMF)

The World Bank Group consists of a unique global partnership comprising five distinct institutions, each with its specific focus and functions:

 

1. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD): IBRD provides loans to middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries for development projects and initiatives.

 

2. The International Development Association (IDA): IDA offers interest-free loans (credits) and grants to the poorest countries in the world to support their development efforts.

 

3. The International Finance Corporation (IFC): IFC is primarily focused on promoting sustainable private sector development by providing financing, mobilizing capital from international financial markets, and offering advisory services to businesses and governments.

 

4. The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA): MIGA was established to encourage foreign direct investment in developing countries by providing political risk insurance (guarantees) to investors and lenders.

 

5. The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID): ICSID facilitates the resolution of investment disputes through international conciliation and arbitration mechanisms.

 

The International Monetary Fund (IMF), while closely associated with international financial and economic cooperation, is a separate entity from the World Bank Group. The IMF primarily focuses on monetary cooperation, exchange rate stability, balanced growth of international trade, and the financial stability of its member countries.

Question 10
In which of the following years, the Bretton Woods Agreement was signed by the delegates from 44 nations which led to the establishment of the IMF? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.1940
  • B.1952
  • C.1944
  • D.1957
Correct Answer: 1944

The Bretton Woods Agreement was negotiated in July 1944 to establish a new international monetary system, the Bretton Woods System. The Agreement was developed by delegates from 44 countries at the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference held in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire.

 

Approximately 730 delegates representing 44 countries met with the principal goals of creating an efficient foreign exchange system, preventing competitive devaluations of currencies, and promoting international economic growth. The Bretton Woods Agreement and System were central to these goals. The Bretton Woods Agreement also created two important organizations—the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. While the Bretton Woods System was dissolved in the 1970s, both the IMF and World Bank have remained strong pillars for the exchange of international currencies.

Question 11
Bretton Woods resolutions led to the formation of:  (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.WTO
  • B.GATT
  • C.UNCTAD
  • D.IMF
Correct Answer: IMF

Bretton Woods resolutions in 1944 led to the formation of IMF (International Monetary Fund) and World Bank. While the Bretton Woods System was dissolved in the 1970s, both the IMF and World Bank have remained strong pillars for the exchange of international currencies.

Question 12
Match List I with the ListII :(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List Ia. International Finance Corporationb. International Development Associationc. World Intellectual PropertyOrganisationd. International Bank for Reconstruction and DevelopmentList IIi. 1944ii. 1967iii. 1956iv. 1960Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i

The correct matching is option (D) a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i.

 

a. The International Finance Corporation, founded in 1956, plays a crucial role in promoting private sector investment in developing countries, driving economic growth and reducing poverty worldwide. It is an integral part of the World Bank Group.

 

b. Established in 1960, the International Development Association (IDA) focuses on providing low-interest loans and grants to the world's poorest countries, supporting essential development projects in areas such as education, healthcare, and infrastructure.

 

c. The World Intellectual Property Organization, founded in 1967, is a specialized agency of the United Nations. It plays a pivotal role in safeguarding and promoting intellectual property rights globally, fostering innovation, and facilitating international cooperation in this crucial domain.

 

d. Since its inception in 1944, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, also known as the World Bank, has been dedicated to reducing poverty and promoting sustainable economic development in developing countries through loans, expertise, and financing for vital projects and initiatives.

Question 13
Assertion A’:International Finance Corporation (IFC) contributes to increase sustainable agriculture opportunities, improve health and education and increase access to financing for micro finance and business client.Reasoning ‘R’:The IFC has focused on a set of development goals to ensure that its projects are expected to achieve the target.Codes:(UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)
  • A.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct, but R is not the correct explanation of A.

Assertion A is correct because the International Finance Corporation (IFC) does indeed contribute to various development goals, including promoting sustainable agriculture, improving health and education, and increasing access to financing for microfinance and business clients. These are some of the key areas where the IFC focuses its efforts to support economic development and poverty reduction in the countries it operates in.

 

Reasoning R is correct because it accurately describes the IFC's approach to project development. The IFC sets specific development goals for its projects to ensure that they align with its mission of promoting economic growth and development. These development goals are designed to guide the IFC's investments and measure the impact of its projects.

 

Therefore, both Assertion A and Reasoning R are correct statements, but Reasoning R is not the direct explanation of Assertion A; rather, it provides additional context about how the IFC achieves its development goals.

Question 14
Consider the following statements with reference to International Development Association (IDA): (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)(a) IDA is the world’s largest source of concessional financial assistance for the poorest countries.(b) IDA is a leader among development institutions.(c) IDA advances loans to industries in exceptional cases.Codes:
  • A.a is correct but, b and c are incorrect.
  • B.a and b are correct but, c is incorrect.
  • C.a and c are correct but, b is incorrect.
  • D.b and c are correct but, a is incorrect.
Correct Answer: a is correct but, b and c are incorrect.

Let us look at all options:

 

(a) IDA is the world’s largest source of concessional financial assistance for the poorest countries. This statement is correct. IDA provides concessional loans and grants to the world's poorest countries to help them reduce poverty and promote sustainable development.

 

(b) IDA is a leader among development institutions. This statement is incorrect. While IDA plays a significant role in development finance, it is not typically described as a "leader" among development institutions. Institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) are more commonly associated with leadership in the field of international development.

 

(c) IDA advances loans to industries in exceptional cases. This statement is incorrect. IDA primarily provides financial assistance poorest countries.

 

Hence correct answer is A.

Question 15
Match the items of List- I with those of List- IIwith regard tointernational monetary fund’s various schemes: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)List- Ia. Extended Fund Facility (EFF)b. Stand by Arrangements (SBA)c. Supplemented Reserve Fund (SRF)d. Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF)List- IIi. Repayment period 4 to 10 yearsii. Repayment period 3 to 5 yearsiii. Repayment period 2 to 5 yearsiv. Repayment period 10 yearsCodes:
  • A.a-i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv
  • B.a- iv, b- iii, c- ii, d-i
  • C.a- iv, b- ii, c- iii, d-i
  • D.a-i, b- iv, c- ii, d- iii
Correct Answer: a-i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv

The correct answer is (A) a- i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv.

 

a. Extended Fund Facility (EFF) - Repayment period 4 to 10 years (i)

The EFF provides medium-term financial assistance to member countries facing balance of payments problems. The repayment period for EFF loans typically falls within the range of 4 to 10 years.

 

b. Stand-By Arrangements (SBA) - Repayment period 3 to 5 years (ii)

Stand-By Arrangements (SBAs) provide short to medium-term financial assistance to member countries in need of support for their balance of payments. The repayment period for SBAs usually ranges from 3 to 5 years.

 

c. Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF) - Repayment period 2 to 5 years (iii)

The Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF) was created to provide financial assistance to member countries facing exceptional balance of payments difficulties. The repayment period for SRF loans typically ranges from 2 to 5 years.

 

d. Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) - Repayment period 10 years (iv)

The Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) was designed to provide concessional financial assistance to low-income member countries. PRGF loans generally have a longer repayment period, often up to 10 years.

Question 16
Assertion ‘A’:The member nations, consistently finding balance of payments crisis, may approach the World Bank seeking financial accommodation to mitigate the crisis.Reasoning ‘R’:The member nations facing balance of payments crisis can approach the IMF seeking redressal of the BOP crisis. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)Codes:
  • A.A is correct and R is correct explanation of A.
  • B.A is correct but R is wrong.
  • C.R is correct and A is wrong.
  • D.Both A and R are wrong
Correct Answer: R is correct and A is wrong.

Reasoning 'R' is correct: Member nations facing balance of payments (BOP) crisis can approach the International Monetary Fund (IMF) seeking redressal and financial assistance to address their BOP crisis. The IMF provides financial assistance and policy advice to its member countries to help them overcome BOP problems and stabilize their economies.

 

Assertion 'A' is incorrect: The World Bank primarily focuses on providing financial assistance for development projects and programs rather than addressing short-term balance of payments crises. Member nations facing BOP issues would typically approach the IMF, not the World Bank, for assistance in managing and resolving their BOP problems.

 

Hence correct answer is option C.

Question 17
Out of the following, which are the important objectives of IMF? (UGC NET Commerce Sep 2013)(i) To promote exchange rate stability.(ii) To create standby reserves.(iii) To print international currency notes.(iv) To establish a multilateral system of payments.(v) To maintain orderly exchange rate stability.(vi) To create employment.Codes:
  • A.ii, iv, v, vi
  • B.iii, v, vi
  • C.i, ii, iv, v
  • D.i, ii, v, vi
Correct Answer: i, ii, iv, v

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has several important objectives.

 

Firstly, it aims to promote exchange rate stability, which is crucial for the smooth functioning of international trade and financial transactions.

 

Secondly, the IMF seeks to create standby reserves to help member countries in times of financial crisis or economic instability.

 

Thirdly, it plays a role in establishing a multilateral system of payments to facilitate international transactions.

 

Additionally, the IMF works to maintain orderly exchange rate stability, preventing excessive fluctuations. However, the IMF's primary focus is on economic stability and not on printing international currency notes or directly creating employment.

Question 18
Which of the following is also known as World Bank? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)
  • A.IMF
  • B.IBRD
  • C.ADB
  • D.IFC
Correct Answer: IBRD

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is one of the five member institutions that collectively make up the World Bank Group. While the term "World Bank" is often used to refer to the entire group, the IBRD is a key part of the World Bank and focuses on providing financial and technical assistance for development projects and reconstruction efforts in middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries.

Question 19
The SDR is a:
  • A.price escalation clause
  • B.hedging technique
  • C.composite currency unit
  • D.mixed currency invoicing
Correct Answer: composite currency unit

Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) are a composite currency unit used by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). SDRs are based on a basket of five major international currencies: the U.S. dollar, Euro, Chinese yuan, Japanese yen, and British pound. This basket is reviewed every 5 years to ensure its relevance.

 

SDRs were created by the IMF in 1969 to serve as an international reserve asset, supplementing the official reserves of member countries. Often referred to as "paper gold," SDRs are not physical currency but rather an accounting entry.
