A country's quota within the IMF is determined in terms of SDRs, and it plays a significant role in establishing the country's financial and organizational relationship with the IMF.

Question 20
Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) is a part of the—
  • A.World Economic Forum
  • B.World Trade Organization
  • C.United Nations
  • D.World Bank
Correct Answer: World Bank

The World Bank Group comprises 5 institutions managed by their member countries:

 

1. International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1944)

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) lends to governments of middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries.

 

2. International Development Association (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1960)

The International Development Association (IDA) provides interest-free loans (called credits) and grants to the poorest countries. It is also called Soft Loan Window. Together, IBRD and IDA make up the World Bank.

 

3. International Finance Corporation (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1956)

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is the largest global development institution focused exclusively on the private sector. We help developing countries achieve sustainable growth by financing investment, mobilizing capital in international financial markets, and providing advisory services to businesses and governments.

 

4. Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1988)

The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) was created in 1988 to promote foreign direct investment into developing countries to support economic growth, reduce poverty, and improve people’s lives. MIGA fulfills this mandate by offering political risk insurance (guarantees) to investors and lenders.

 

5. International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (Headquarters: Washington, Founded: 1966)

The International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID) provides international facilities for conciliation and arbitration of investment disputes.

Question 21
Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) and the Exogenous Shocks Facility (ESF) are part of which type of assistance provided by IMF?
  • A.surveillance
  • B.development assistance
  • C.financial assistance
  • D.technical assistance
Correct Answer: financial assistance

The Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility Trust (the PRGF Trust), for which the IMF is Trustee, was established in December 1987 to provide loans on concessional terms to qualifying low-income country members. Assistance under the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) is made available under three-year arrangements in support of macroeconomic and adjustment programs. Effective January 5, 2006, the PRGF Trust was renamed the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility and Exogenous Shocks Facility Trust (the Trust) to also support programs under the Exogenous Shocks Facility (ESF) to facilitate member countries’ adjustment to sudden and exogenous shocks. Programs under the ESF range from one to two years.

Question 22
Match the items of List – I with those of List – IIwith regard toInternational Monetary Fund: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)List – Ia. Stand-by Arrangement (SBA)b. Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF)c. Supplemented Reserve Facility (SRF)d. Contingent Credit Line (CCL)List – IIi. Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) was replaced by this scheme.ii. Exceptional balance of payments problems arising from a sudden loss of confidence in the currency.iii. Financial crisis causing capital outflow on capital account of balance of payments.iv. To meet balance of payments difficulties (most commonly usedfacility).Codes:
  • A.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • B.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii

The correct answer is B. Here's an explanation of the matching between List – I and List – II with regard to the International Monetary Fund (IMF):

 

a. Stand-by Arrangement (SBA) - To meet balance of payments difficulties (most commonly used facility).

The Stand-by Arrangement (SBA) is a lending instrument provided by the IMF to member countries facing balance of payments problems. It is the most frequently used facility and is designed to help countries address immediate external financing needs and implement policies to restore economic stability.

 

b. Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) - Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) was replaced by this scheme.

The Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) replaced the Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) as a concessional lending program aimed at providing financial assistance to low-income countries. The PRGF was introduced to support these countries in implementing policies that would reduce poverty and promote sustainable economic growth.

 

c. Supplemented Reserve Facility (SRF) - Solves the exceptional balance of payments problems arising from a sudden loss of confidence in the currency.

The Supplemented Reserve Facility (SRF) is designed to address exceptional balance of payments difficulties that occur when there is a sudden loss of market confidence in a country's currency. It provides financial assistance to member countries facing a crisis resulting from disruptive shifts in market sentiment and pressure on their reserves.

 

d. Contingent Credit Line (CCL) - Intended to provide a precautionary line of defense for members with sound policies, vulnerable to contagion effects from capital account crises in other countries.

The Contingent Credit Line (CCL) is a facility created by the IMF to offer precautionary financial support to member countries with strong economic policies. It is designed for countries that are not in the midst of a balance of payments crisis but may be vulnerable to external financial shocks, such as contagion effects from crises in neighboring countries. The CCL provides assurance of IMF support if needed.

Question 23
Match List-I with List-II and select the correct answer using the codes given below the lists:List- Ia. International Bank for Reconstruction and Developmentb. International Development Associationc. International Finance Corporationd. Multilateral Investment Guarantee AgencyList- III. 1944II. 1956III. 1960IV. 1988Codes:
  • A.a-I  b-II c-III d-IV
  • B.a-I b-III c-II d-IV
  • C.a-II b-I c-IV d-III
  • D.a-III b-I c-II d-IV
Correct Answer: a-I b-III c-II d-IV

The World Bank Group comprises 5 institutions managed by their member countries. Four of these 5 are given below.

 

International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) - Founded in 1944, the IBRD provides loans to middle-income and creditworthy low-income countries for development projects.

 

International Development Association (IDA) - Founded in 1960, IDA offers interest-free loans and grants to the world's poorest countries to support their development efforts.

 

International Finance Corporation (IFC) - Established in 1956, IFC is a global development institution that focuses on supporting the private sector in developing countries through investment, capital mobilization, and advisory services.

 

Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA) - Founded in 1988, MIGA's mission is to promote foreign direct investment in developing countries by providing political risk insurance to investors and lenders.

 

The correct answer is Option B.

Question 24
SDRs are popularly known as ______.
  • A.Currency Notes
  • B.Paper Gold
  • C.Silver Coin
  • D.Gold Coin
Correct Answer: Paper Gold

Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) are a form of international reserve asset created by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in 1969. They are not physical currency like traditional banknotes or coins. Instead, SDRs are often metaphorically called "Paper Gold" because they represent a claim on the freely usable currencies of IMF member countries. These SDRs are allocated to IMF member countries to supplement their official reserve holdings and provide liquidity. SDRs play a crucial role in international finance and are used as a means of exchange and settlement among member countries.

Question 25
Which of the following is not one of the components of Governance Structure of IMF?
  • A.Executive Board
  • B.International Monetary and Financial Committee
  • C.DevelopmentCommittee .
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: None of the above

The Board of Governors is advised by the International Monetary and Financial Committee and the Development Committee. The International Monetary and Financial Committee has 24 members and monitors developments in global liquidity and the transfer of resources to developing countries. The Development Committee has 25 members and advises on critical development issues and on financial resources required to promote economic development in developing countries. They also advise on trade and environmental issues.

 

The IMF has a Managing Director, who is head of the staff and Chairperson of the Executive Board. The Managing Director is appointed by the Executive Board for a renewable term of 5 years and is assisted by a First Deputy Managing Director and 3 Deputy Managing Directors. The Board of Governors reports directly to the Managing Director of the IMF.

 

Hence the correct answer is Option D.

Question 26
Which one is called the Bretton-Wood Twins? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.IBRD and IDA
  • B.IMF and IFC
  • C.IMF and IBRD
  • D.IDA and IFC
Correct Answer: IMF and IBRD

The Bretton Woods twins refers to the two multilateral organizations created at the Bretton Woods Conference in 1944. Both twin organizations functioned to enact and maintain the Bretton Woods system of proscribed international currency exchange rates. They are:

1. The World Bank IBRD

2. The International Monetary Fund

Question 27
Assertion ‘A’:  International Monetary Fund was set up in1944. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)Reason ‘R’: The objective was to promote international monetary cooperation through a permanent institution which provides machinery for consultation and collaboration on international monetary problems.Codes:
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are false.
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are true.
  • C.‘A’ is true, but ‘R’ is false.
  • D.‘R’ is true, but ‘A’ is false.
Correct Answer: Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are true.

The correct answer is (B) Both 'A' and 'R' are true.

 

Explanation: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) was indeed established in 1944 during the United Nations Bretton Woods Conference held in New Hampshire, United States. It currently has 190 member countries and plays a crucial role in ensuring the stability of the international monetary system. The reason provided is also accurate; the IMF's primary objective is to promote international monetary cooperation and provide a platform for member countries to collaborate on issues related to international monetary problems, exchange stability, trade expansion, and the provision of resources to countries facing balance-of-payments difficulties.

Question 28
Which one is not an objective of IMF? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.To promote international monetary co-operation
  • B.To ensure balanced international trade
  • C.To finance productive efforts according to peace-time requirement
  • D.To ensure exchange rate stability
Correct Answer: To finance productive efforts according to peace-time requirement

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has several key objectives, but financing productive efforts according to peace-time requirements is not one of them. The primary objectives of the IMF include promoting international monetary cooperation, facilitating balanced international trade, promoting exchange rate stability, assisting in the establishment of a multilateral system of payments, and making resources available to member countries facing balance-of-payments difficulties.

Question 29
Which of the following is not the agency of the World Bank? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.MIGA
  • B.ICSID
  • C.ADB
  • D.IDA
Correct Answer: ADB

The World Bank Group consists of five institutions managed by their member countries. These institutions include the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), International Development Association (IDA), International Finance Corporation (IFC), Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID). The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is a separate international financial institution and is not a part of the World Bank Group.

 

Hence the correct answer is C.

Question 30
The different forms of IMF assistance are given below. Identify the one which is mainly meant for Less Developed Countries (LDCs) (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Credit Tranche Drawing
  • B.Extended Fund Facility
  • C.Compensatory financing facility
  • D.Structural Adjustment Facility
Correct Answer: Compensatory financing facility

Non-concessional loans are provided through 5 main facilities: Stand-By Arrangements (SBA), the Extended Fund Facility (EFF), the Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF), the Contingent Credit Lines (CCL), and the Compensatory Financing Facility (CFF). Except for the PRGF, all facilities are subject to the IMF’s market-related interest rate, known as the ‘rate of charge’, and some carry an interest rate premium, a ‘surcharge’.

 

1. Stand-By Arrangements (SBA): The SBA is designed to address short-term balance of payments problems and is the most widely used facility of the IMF. The length of SBA is typically 12-18 months.

 

2. Extended Fund Facility (EFF): This facility was established to help countries address more protracted balance-of-payments problems with roots in the structure of the economy. Arrangements under the EFF are thus longer (3 years).

 

3. Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF): The SRF was introduced to meet a need for very short-term financing on a large scale. Countries must repay the loan after a maximum of 2.5 years, but are expected to repay one year earlier. All SRF loans carry a substantial surcharge of 3-5 percentage points.

 

4. Contingent Credit Lines (CCL): The CCL differs from other IMF facilities in that it aims to help members prevent crises. Established in 1997, it is designed for countries implementing sound economic policies, which may find themselves threatened by a crisis elsewhere in the world economy — a phenomenon known as “financial contagion”. The CCL is subject to the same repayment conditions as the SRF, but carries a smaller surcharge.

 

5. Compensatory Financing Facility (CFF): The CFF was established to assist countries experiencing either a sudden shortfall in export earnings or an increase in the cost of food imports caused by fluctuating world commodity prices. The financial terms are the same as those applying to the SBA, except that CFF loans carry no surcharge.

Question 31
Any country consistently facing balance of payment deficiency can approach: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.The World Bank
  • B.The Smithsonian Institute
  • C.IMF
  • D.The IMF and the IBRD
Correct Answer: IMF

The IMF’s fundamental mission is to ensure the stability of the international monetary system. It does so in 3 ways: 

 

1. Economic Surveillance: The IMF oversees the international monetary system and monitors the economic and financial policies of its member countries. As part of this process, which takes place both at the global level and in individual countries, the IMF highlights possible risks to stability and advises on needed policy adjustments. It also provides periodic assessments of global prospects in its World Economic Outlook, of financial markets in its 

Global Financial Stability Report, of public finance developments in its Fiscal Monitor, and of external positions of the largest economies in its External Sector Report, in addition to a series of regional economic outlooks.

 

2. Financial Assistance: Providing loans to member countries that are experiencing actual or potential balance of payments problems is a core responsibility of the IMF. Individual country adjustment programs are designed in close cooperation with the IMF.

 

3. Capacity Development: The IMF provides technical assistance and training to help member countries build better economic institutions and strengthen related human capacities. This includes, for example, designing and implementing more effective policies for taxation and administration, expenditure management, monetary and exchange rate policies, banking and financial system supervision and regulation, legislative frameworks, and economic statistics.

Question 32
Which one among the following is not correct? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.IMF’s headquarters is in Washington, D.C.
  • B.IMF has 198 countries as its members.
  • C.IMF is an outcome of the Bretton Woods Conference.
  • D.IMF was found on July 7, 1944.
Correct Answer: IMF has 198 countries as its members.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) was formed in July 1944 at the United Nations Bretton Woods Conference in New Hampshire, United States. As of now, it has 190 member countries. The IMF’s primary purpose is to ensure the stability of the international monetary system i.e., the system of exchange rates and international payments that enables countries (and their citizens) to transact with each other. The headquarters is in Washington, D.C.

Question 33
Match the items of List - I with those of List - II; and choose the correct code of combination: (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)List - I(a) Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF)(b) Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF)(c) Extended Fund Facility (EFF)List - II(i) 1997(ii) 1974(iii) 1999Code:
  • A.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(i)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iii)
  • D.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii)

Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) is the IMF's concessional facility for low income countries introduced in September 1999. PRGF-supported programs are framed around comprehensive, country-owned Poverty Reduction Strategy Papers (PRSPs). PRSPs are prepared by governments with the active participation of civil society and other development partners. PRGF loans carry an annual interest rate of 0.5 percent, and are repayable over 10 years with a 5.5-year grace period on principal payments.

 

Supplemental Reserve Facility (SRF) of IMF was established in 1997. This facility has been put in place to provide financial assistance to a member country experiencing exceptional balance of payments difficulties due to a large short-term financing need resulting from a sudden and disruptive loss of market confidence.

 

Extended Fund Facility (EFF) is a type of lending facility of IMF, established in 1974. It is a medium- term program generally for the period of three years to help the countries suffering from Balance of payment problem. It is done with the motive of bringing macroeconomic stability and solution to structural problems in an economy. EFF is limited upto 145% of a country’s IMF quota annually.

Question 34
The major outcome of the Bretton Woods Conference was: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Establishment of IMF and IFC
  • B.Establishment of IBRD and IFC
  • C.Establishment of IBRD and ADB
  • D.Establishment of IMF and IBRD
Correct Answer: Establishment of IMF and IBRD

The Bretton Woods Conference, officially known as the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference, was a gathering of delegates from 44 nations that met from July 1 to 22, 1944 in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, to agree upon a series of new rules for the post-WWII international monetary system. The two major accomplishments of the conference were the creation of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD).

Question 35
Which one of the following is an important activity of the World Bank borrowings? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.It borrows in the international capital market
  • B.It borrows on currency on swap agreements
  • C.It borrows under the discount net program
  • D.All ofthe above
Correct Answer: All ofthe above

Important activity of the World Bank includes:

1. It borrows in the international capital market

2. It borrows on currency on swap agreements

3. It borrows under the discount net program

4. To provide finance to projects from its own capital

5. To arrange loans made or guaranteed by it

Question 36
Which one of the following statements is false? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.IFC was established in July 1956
  • B.IFC encourages the growth and development of Public Sector Enterprises in member countries
  • C.IFC is an affiliate of the World Bank
  • D.IFC encourages the growth of productive private enterprises in member countries
Correct Answer: IFC encourages the growth and development of Public Sector Enterprises in member countries

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) was indeed established in July 1956. It is an affiliate of the World Bank and a member of the World Bank Group. However, the false statement is (B) because IFC's primary focus is not on the growth and development of Public Sector Enterprises (government-owned enterprises) but rather on promoting the growth of productive private enterprises in member countries. IFC provides support and financial assistance to private sector businesses to stimulate economic development and reduce poverty in developing countries. It offers loans and assistance for purposes such as establishing, expanding, and modernizing private enterprises, not public sector enterprises.

Question 37
Match the items in List-I with the items in List-II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)List-I(a) Bretton woods conference(b) Soft loan window(c) Geneva(d) Loan to private sectorList-II(i) WTO(ii) World Bank(iii) IFC(iv) IDACodes:
  • A.a-(i) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • C.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)

The correct answer is Option C.

 

(a) Bretton Woods conference - This conference refers to the historic Bretton Woods Conference held in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, United States, in July 1944. The primary outcome of this conference was the establishment of two major international financial institutions: the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), which is now part of the World Bank Group. So, (a) matches with (ii) World Bank because it was established as a result of this conference.

 

(b) Soft loan window - A soft loan is a loan with favorable terms, often provided at below-market interest rates and with extended repayment periods. Such loans are typically offered by international financial institutions to assist developing countries in their economic development efforts. The World Bank is known for providing soft loans to these nations. Therefore, (b) matches with (iv) IDA (International Development Association), which offers concessional loans and grants through a soft loan window to the world's poorest developing countries.

 

(c) Geneva - Geneva is a city in Switzerland and serves as the headquarters for several international organizations. In this context, (c) matches with (i) WTO (World Trade Organization) because the WTO has its headquarters in Geneva, Switzerland. The WTO is responsible for regulating international trade and resolving trade disputes among member countries.

 

(d) Loan to private sector - The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is an organization affiliated with the World Bank Group, and its primary focus is to provide financial support and loans to the private sector in developing countries. Therefore, (d) matches with (iii) IFC, which specializes in promoting private sector development and investment in these countries.

Question 38
Match the items of List-I with List-II and indicate the code of correct matching:(UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)List – Ia. Accommodating capital flowb. Autonomous capital flowc. SDR Allocationd. Statistical discrepancyList – IIi. Creation of international reserve assets by the IMF and their allocation among member countriesin order toimprove international liquidity.ii. Estimate of foreign exchange flow on account of either variations in the collection of related figures or unrecorded illegal transactions of foreign exchange.iii. Inflow of foreign exchange to meet the balance of payments deficit, normally from the IMF.iv. Flow of loans/investments in normal course of business.Codes:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • B.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

Gere's an explanation of the correct matching between List-I and List-II:

 

(a) Accommodating capital flow - This concept relates to the inflow of foreign exchange that is used to address a balance of payments deficit. It is often sourced from organizations like the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to help a country maintain balance in its balance of payments (BoP) account. The purpose is to ensure that a country's external payments and receipts remain in equilibrium. Therefore, (a) matches with (iii) - "Inflow of foreign exchange to meet the balance of payments deficit, normally from the IMF."

 

(b) Autonomous capital flow - Autonomous transactions are financial transactions motivated by profit rather than the need to balance the BoP account. These transactions are independent of a country's BoP status and are typically profit-driven. They include various capital flows like loans and investments that occur in the normal course of business. Therefore, (b) matches with (iv) - "Flow of loans/investments in normal course of business."

 

(c) SDR Allocation - The Special Drawing Right (SDR) is an international reserve asset created by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). SDRs are allocated among IMF member countries to supplement their existing reserve assets. This allocation is made to improve international liquidity and is distributed in proportion to each country's IMF quota. Therefore, (c) matches with (i) - "Creation of international reserve assets by the IMF and their allocation among member countries in order to improve international liquidity."

 

(d) Statistical discrepancy - The statistical discrepancy is an estimate used to account for foreign exchange flows that result from variations in data collection or unrecorded illegal foreign exchange transactions. It helps reconcile discrepancies in balance of payments data. Therefore, (d) matches with (ii) - "Estimate of foreign exchange flow on account of either variations in the collection of related figures or unrecorded illegal transactions of foreign exchange."

 

So, the matching code (B) iii iv i ii correctly pairs each concept in List-I with its corresponding explanation in List-II.

Question 39
Statement I:Developing countries can borrow more than their quota under Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of IMF. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)Statement II:The Extended Fund Facility (EFF) was created in 1984 to help the developing countries over longer periodupto3 years.Codes:
  • A.Statement I is correct but II is not correct.
  • B.Statement II is correct but Iisnot correct.
  • C.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are not correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct but II is not correct.

Statement I: Developing countries can borrow more than their quota under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of the IMF.

Statement II: The Extended Fund Facility (EFF) was created in 1984 to assist developing countries over a longer period of up to 3 years.

 

The provided statements are related to the IMF's Extended Fund Facility (EFF):

 

Statement I: This statement is correct. Developing countries, when facing balance of payments problems, can indeed borrow more than their regular quota allocation under the Extended Fund Facility (EFF) of the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The EFF provides financial assistance for longer durations and larger amounts compared to standard IMF programs like Stand-By Arrangements.

 

Statement II: This statement is not correct. The Extended Fund Facility (EFF) was actually established in 1974, not in 1984, as a medium-term program typically lasting up to three years. Its primary purpose is to provide support to countries facing balance of payments difficulties, with a focus on addressing structural problems in their economies.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) "Statement I is correct, but II is not correct."

Quiz Attempt #119466

Total Questions: 15
Question 1
UNCTAD compiled ‘Transnationality Index’ consists of which of the following3ratios?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)
  • A.Foreign assets/Total assets, Foreign Sales/Total sales and Foreign Employment/Total employment
  • B.Foreign assets/Total assets, Foreign Sales/Total output and Foreign Employment/Total employment
  • C.Foreign assets/Total GDP, Foreign sales. Total GDP and Foreign employment/Total GDP
  • D.Foreign assets/Total output, Foreign Sales/Total sales and Foreign Employment/Total GDP
Correct Answer: Foreign assets/Total assets, Foreign Sales/Total sales and Foreign Employment/Total employment

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Transnationality Index (TNI) is a means of ranking multinational corporations that is employed by economists and politician. It is calculated as the arithmetic mean of the following 3 ratios (where "foreign" means outside of the corporation's home country):

(i) the ratio of foreign assets to total assets

(ii) the ratio of foreign sales to total sales

(iii) the ratio of foreign employment to total employment

 

The Transnationality Index was developed by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

Question 2
G20 Summit (2023) Proposed which Economic corridor including shipping and rail lines?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.IMEE (India Middle East Europe Economic Corridor)
  • B.BRI (Bolt and Road Initiative)
  • C.CMREC (China Mongolia Russia Economic Corridor)
  • D.NELB (New Eurasian Land Bridge (Corridor))
Correct Answer: IMEE (India Middle East Europe Economic Corridor)

The India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor (IMEC) Project was signed at the G20 Summit in New Delhi, which holds significant geopolitical and economic implications for India.

 

The project forms part of the Partnership for Global Infrastructure and Investment (PGII). PGII is a values-driven, high-impact, and transparent infrastructure partnership to meet the enormous infrastructure needs of low and middle-income countries.

 

The proposed IMEC will consist of Railroad, Ship-to-Rail networks and Road transport routes extending across two corridors, that is,

  • The East Corridor – connecting India to the Arabian Gulf,
  • The Northern Corridor – connecting the Gulf to Europe.

 

The IMEC corridor will also include an electricity cable, a hydrogen pipeline and a high-speed data cable.

Question 3
Which among the following is not an international economic institution? (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)
  • A.IMF
  • B.IBRD
  • C.ADB
  • D.IFRS
Correct Answer: IFRS

IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standard) is not an international economic institution. Instead, it is a not-for-profit international organization responsible for developing a single set of high-quality global accounting standards, known as IFRS Standards. These standards are used by businesses and organizations worldwide to ensure consistency and transparency in financial reporting. The mission of the IFRS Foundation is to develop standards that enhance transparency, accountability, and efficiency in global financial markets. While it plays a crucial role in the financial world, it is not an international economic institution in the traditional sense. It collaborates with various international organizations and is supported by entities like the G20, the Financial Stability Board, and the World Bank, but its primary focus is on accounting and financial reporting standards rather than broader economic matters.

Question 4
Which among the following is associated with high-income economic and Human Development Index (HDI)? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.TRID
  • B.TRIM
  • C.GATT
  • D.OECD
Correct Answer: OECD

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) is associated with high-income economies and is known for its work on economic research and development. OECD member countries are typically high-income nations with advanced economies and high levels of human development, as measured by indicators such as the Human Development Index (HDI).

 

A. TRID: This is not associated with high-income economies or HDI. TRID (Transportation Research International Documentation) is related to transportation and infrastructure research and documentation.

 

B. TRIM: TRIM (Trade-Related Investment Measures) is a term related to trade and investment policies, but it is not specifically associated with high-income economies or HDI.

 

C. GATT: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was an international trade agreement that was in effect until the establishment of the World Trade Organization (WTO). GATT is related to international trade but does not focus on high-income economies or HDI.

Question 5
The following statements relate to trans-nationality. Choose the correct code for the statements being correct or incorrect. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Statement I: The UNCTAD developed an index to compare the transnationality of countries in which TNCs operate.Statement II: The UNCTAD followed parameters like FDI flow as a percentage of gross fixed capital formation, FDI inward stock, value added by foreign affiliates and jobs created by them.Codes:
  • A.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • B.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.
  • D.Both the statements I and II are correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.

Only Statement 2 is incorrect.

 

The Transnationality Index (TNI) is indeed a means of ranking multinational corporations (TNCs). It was developed by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) to assess and compare the degree of transnationality of countries where TNCs operate.

 

The TNI is calculated based on three key ratios: foreign assets to total assets, foreign sales to total sales, and foreign employment to total employment.

 

These parameters help evaluate the extent to which TNCs are engaged in international activities and their impact on host countries. Therefore, both statements accurately describe the development and parameters of the Transnationality Index, making option D the correct answer.

Question 6
Match List 1 with List II (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)List I (Trade and Finance Institution)(a) WTO(b) IMF(c) FAO(d) EUList II (Headquarters)(i) Brussels(ii) Geneva(iii) Washington(iv) RomeChoose the correct option from those given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii); (b)-(iii); (c)-(iv); (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(i); (b)-(ii); (c)-(iii); (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iii); (b)-(ii); (c)-(i); (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(i); (b)-(iii); (c)-(ii); (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii); (b)-(iii); (c)-(iv); (d)-(i)

Correct Matching is (A) (a)-(ii); (b)-(iii); (c)-(iv); (d)-(i).

 

(a) WTO – Geneva: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland. The WTO is responsible for dealing with international trade rules, negotiations, and agreements. It aims to ensure that global trade flows smoothly, predictably, and freely by establishing rules and resolving trade disputes among member nations.

 

(b) IMF – Washington: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has its headquarters in Washington, D.C., United States. The IMF is an international organization that focuses on fostering global monetary cooperation, maintaining financial stability, facilitating international trade, promoting high employment, supporting sustainable economic growth, and reducing poverty worldwide. It provides financial assistance and policy advice to member countries facing economic challenges.

 

(c) FAO – Rome: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) is based in Rome, Italy. FAO's primary mission is to lead international efforts to combat hunger, improve nutrition, and promote sustainable agriculture. It serves as a forum for member countries to address food security issues, improve agricultural practices, and share knowledge related to food and agriculture.

 

(d) EU – Brussels: The European Union (EU) has its main administrative center in Brussels, Belgium. The EU is a political and economic union of 27 member states (as of the time of this explanation) located primarily in Europe. It has established a single market, a common currency (the euro), and common policies in various areas, including trade, agriculture, and regional development. The EU aims to promote economic integration, free movement of people and goods, and cooperation among its member states.

Question 7
Match the items of List- I with the List- II and denote the code of correct matching. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)List- Ia. International Bank for Reconstruction and Developmentb. International Finance Corporationc. Asian Development Bankd. Export-Import Bank of IndiaList- IIi. 1945ii. 1956iii. 1966iv. 1981Codes:
  • A.a- i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv
  • B.a- iv, b- iii, c- ii, d- i
  • C.a- i, b- iii, c- ii, d- iv
  • D.a- ii, b- i, c- iv, d- iii
Correct Answer: a- i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is a global development cooperative owned by 189 member countries. It was created in 1944 to help Europe rebuild after World War II.

 

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is a member of the World Bank Group and is focused on promoting sustainable private sector investment in developing countries. The IFC was established in 1956 and is headquartered in Washington, D.C., USA.

 

The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is an international financial institution dedicated to promoting economic and social development in Asia and the Pacific region. ADB was established in 1966, and its headquarters is located in Manila, Philippines.

 

The Export-Import Bank of India, commonly known as EXIM Bank, is the official export credit agency of India. It is a financial institution that specializes in promoting and financing international trade, particularly Indian exports, and helping Indian businesses expand their global presence. EXIM Bank was established in 1982 and is headquartered in Mumbai, India.

Question 8
Which international organizations jointly oversee the operations of the International Trade Centre (ITC)?
  • A.United Nations and UNCTAD
  • B.UNCTAD and GATT
  • C.World Trade Organization and UNCTAD
  • D.United Nations and World Bank
Correct Answer: World Trade Organization and UNCTAD

International Trade Centre (ITC) is the joint agency of the United Nations and the World Trade Organization, fully dedicated to supporting small businesses of developing countries to trade. Originally created by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) in 1964, ITC has operated since 1968 under the joint aegis of GATT/WTO and the United Nations, the latter acting through the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). ITC is the focal point in the United Nations system for technical cooperation with developing countries and economies in transition, on trade promotion and export development.

 

While UNCTAD and WTO work principally with governments, ITC focuses on equipping micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) to become more competitive in global markets. In this context, ITC translates the business implications of multilateral trade agreements for businesses, so they can understand, shape and benefit from trade rules. ITC thereby helps to build vibrant, sustainable export sectors that provide entrepreneurial opportunities, particularly for women, youth and vulnerable communities.

Question 9
Match the following economic institutions with the year of their establishment: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2010)List- I(a) World Bank(b) International Finance Corporation(c) International Development Agency(d) Asian Development BankList- II(i) 1946(ii) 1956(iii) 1960(iv) 1966Codes:
  • A.a- i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv
  • B.a- i, b- iii, c- iv, d- ii
  • C.a- ii, b- i, c- iv, d- iii
  • D.a- iii, b- i, c- ii, d- iv
Correct Answer: a- i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The World Bank is an international financial institution that provides financial and technical assistance to developing countries around the world. The World Bank was established in 1944 and officially started operations in 1946. It is headquartered in Washington, D.C., United States.

 

The International Finance Corporation (IFC) is a member of the World Bank Group and is focused on promoting sustainable private sector investment in developing countries. The IFC was established in 1956 and is headquartered in Washington, D.C., USA.

 

The International Development Association (IDA) is the part of the World Bank that helps the world’s poorest countries. Established in 1960, IDA aims to reduce poverty by providing zero to low-interest loans (called “credits”) and grants for programs that boost economic growth, reduce inequalities, and improve people’s living conditions.

 

The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is an international financial institution dedicated to promoting economic and social development in Asia and the Pacific region. ADB was established in 1966, and its headquarters is located in Manila, Philippines.

Question 10
Match the following items of List-I with the List-II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)List – I(a) Bretton woods conference(b) General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs(c) ACCRA conference(d) United Nations Conference on Trade and DevelopmentList – II(i) 1947(ii) 1964(iii) 1944(iv) 2008Codes:
  • A.i-(b) ii-(d) iii-(a) iv-(c)
  • B.i-(b) ii-(d) iii-(c) iv-(a)
  • C.i-(b) ii-(c) iii-(d) iv-(a)
  • D.i-(c) ii-(a) iii-(b) iv-(d)
Correct Answer: i-(b) ii-(d) iii-(a) iv-(c)

Here's an explanation of the matching between List-I and List-II:

 

(a) Bretton Woods Conference - This conference took place in 1944, and it was a pivotal international gathering held in Bretton Woods, New Hampshire, USA. It resulted in the creation of the Bretton Woods system, which established the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), now part of the World Bank Group. The correct match is (iii) 1944.

 

(b) General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs - The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was established in 1947 as an international treaty aimed at reducing trade barriers and promoting global trade. It eventually evolved into the World Trade Organization (WTO). The correct match is (i) 1947.

 

(c) ACCRA conference - The ACCRA conference took place in 2008 in Accra, Ghana, and was related to development issues and aid effectiveness. The correct match is (iv) 2008.

 

(d) United Nations Conference on Trade and Development - UNCTAD was established in 1964 as an organ of the United Nations (UN) focused on trade and development issues, particularly for developing countries. The correct match is (ii) 1964.

 

So, the correct code for the matches is (A) (b) (d) (a) (c), accurately aligning each item in List-I with its corresponding year in List-II.

Question 11
Match the items given in List – I with the most appropriate items in List – II:List – I(a) UNCTAD(b) WTO(c) TRIMS(d) ITCList – II(i) Foreign investment(ii) Developing Countries(iii) UNDP(iv) General CouncilCodes:
  • A.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)

The correct matches are as follows:

 

(a) UNCTAD - UNCTAD, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, primarily focuses on trade, investment, and development issues related to developing countries. Therefore, it matches with (ii) Developing Countries.

 

(b) WTO - The World Trade Organization (WTO) is responsible for international trade-related matters and has a General Council as its highest-level decision-making body. So, it matches with (iv) General Council.

 

(c) TRIMS - The Agreement on Trade-Related Investment Measures (TRIMS) pertains to rules governing domestic regulations that affect foreign investment. Therefore, it matches with (i) Foreign investment.

 

(d) ITC - The International Trade Centre (ITC) is an organization jointly mandated by the WTO and UNCTAD to promote trade and development. It aligns with (iii) UNDP, which stands for the United Nations Development Programme, as both organizations work towards development goals.

 

So, the correct code for the matches is (A) (ii) (iv) (i) (iii), as it appropriately associates each item in List-I with the corresponding item in List-II.

Question 12
UNCTAD was established in:
  • A.Washington DC in 1947
  • B.Geneva in 1958
  • C.Geneva in 1964
  • D.New York in 1964
Correct Answer: Geneva in 1964

The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was established in 1964 as a permanent intergovernmental body. Its headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland.

Question 13
The UNCTAD members are divided into four lists, the division is based on United Nations Regional Groups. India is a member of:
  • A.List A
  • B.List B
  • C.List C
  • D.List D
Correct Answer: List A

UNCTAD members are divided into four lists, the division being based on United Nations Regional Groups. 

1. List A consists mostly of countries in the African and Asia-Pacific Groups of the UN. 

2. List B consists of countries of the Western European and Others Group. 

3. List C consists of countries of the Group of Latin American and Caribbean States (GRULAC). 

4. List D consists of countries of the Eastern European Group. 

India is member of List A.

Question 14
UNCTAD stands for _____________. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.United Nations Committee on Tariff and Development.
  • B.United Nations Conference on Trade and Deficit.
  • C.United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.
  • D.Union of Nations Cause for Trade and Development.
Correct Answer: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was established in 1964 as a permanent intergovernmental body. Its headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland.

Question 15
The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was set up in (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.1944
  • B.1954
  • C.1960
  • D.1964
Correct Answer: 1964

The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was established in 1964 as a permanent intergovernmental body. Its headquarters is in Geneva, Switzerland.

Quiz Attempt #119467

Total Questions: 44
Question 1
A written statement by the exporter ordering the importer to pay a specific amount of money upon presentation to drawee to whom it is addressed is known as a __________.
  • A.bill of lading
  • B.sight draft
  • C.time draft
  • D.letter of credit
Correct Answer: sight draft

A written statement by the exporter ordering the importer to pay a specific amount of money upon presentation to drawee to whom it is addressed is known as a sight draft.

Question 2
The exporting firm is termed 'rider' where the other firm with an established distribution channel in the target country is termed as 'Carrier'. This phenomenon is known as:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Counter Trade
  • B.Barter
  • C.Piggy Backing
  • D.Switch Trading
Correct Answer: Piggy Backing

Piggybacking, in the context of international business and exporting, refers to a strategy where one company (the rider) leverages the established distribution network of another company (the carrier) to sell its products in foreign markets. This arrangement is a form of strategic alliance that allows both companies to achieve mutual objectives that would be challenging to reach independently.

Question 3
In International Commercial Terms (INCOTERMES), identify the one under which the delivery of goods to the named place of destination (discharge) takes place at the seller's expense. Buyers assumes the cargo insurance; import custom clearance. payment of custom duties, taxes and other costs and risk.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)
  • A.Carriage and Insurance Paid To (CIP)
  • B.Cost, Insurance and Freight (CIF)
  • C.Carriage Paid To (CPT)
  • D.Cost and Freight (CFR)
Correct Answer: Carriage Paid To (CPT)

Under the CPT term, the seller is responsible for arranging and paying for the transportation of the goods to the named place of destination. However, the risk is transferred to the buyer once the goods are handed over to the first carrier. The buyer is responsible for the cargo insurance, import customs clearance, payment of customs duties, taxes, and any other costs and risks from that point onward.

 

Other INCOTERMS are explained as follows:

 

1. Carriage and Insurance Paid To (CIP): Similar to CPT, but the seller also pays for insurance coverage up to the named destination.

 

2. Cost, Insurance and Freight (CIF)

The seller pays for the cost of goods, insurance, and freight to bring the goods to the port of destination. However, the risk transfers to the buyer once the goods are loaded onto the vessel.

 

3. Cost and Freight (CFR)

The seller pays for the cost of goods and freight to bring the goods to the port of destination, but the risk transfers to the buyer once the goods are loaded onto the vessel, and the buyer is responsible for insurance.

 

Given the requirement that the seller pays for delivery to the named place of destination, and the buyer assumes cargo insurance, import customs clearance, payment of customs duties, taxes, and other costs and risks, CPT (Carriage Paid To) is the correct term.

Question 4
In international trade, factoring is widely used in short-term transactions as a continuous arrangement. Arrange the steps of export factoring operations in sequence -(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.The export factor transfers the invoice to the import factor, who, in return, assumes credit risk and undertakes administration of receivable.
  • B.The export factor pays cash in advance to the exporter against receivables until the payment is received from the importer.
  • C.The importer and exporterenter intoa sales contract and agree on the terms of sale.
  • D.The import factor presentsinvoicetoimporter, take payment and pays to the export factor.
Correct Answer: The import factor presentsinvoicetoimporter, take payment and pays to the export factor.

The correct answer is (D) C, E, B, A, D.

Here is the sequence of export factoring operations:

C. The importer and exporter enter into a sales contract and agree on the terms of sale.

E. The exporter ships the goods to the importer and submits the invoice to the export factor.

B. The export factor pays cash in advance to the exporter against receivables until the payment is received from the importer.

A. The export factor transfers the invoice to the import factor, who, in return, assumes credit risk and undertakes administration of receivable.

D. The import factor presents the invoice to the importer, collects the payment, and pays the export factor.

Question 5
Which one of the following is NOT a technique of foreign trade financing?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.Discounting
  • B.Banker’s Acceptance
  • C.Factoring
  • D.Forfeiting
Correct Answer: Discounting

The correct answer is (A) Discounting.

 

The techniques of foreign trade financing include:

Banker’s Acceptance: A short-term credit instrument used in international trade, where a bank guarantees payment at a future date.

Factoring: A financial transaction where a business sells its receivables to a third party (factor) at a discount to obtain immediate cash.

Forfeiting: A financing method where exporters sell their medium to long-term receivables to a forfeiter at a discount in exchange for immediate cash.

Discounting, while it is a financial practice where a bill of exchange is sold to a bank at a discount before its maturity, is not specifically classified as a technique of foreign trade financing. Thus, option A is the correct answer.

Question 6
Which of the following statements are not correct in relation to pre-shipment credit in foreign currency? (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)Statement I:It is a foreign currency loan available, both, to the importers and exporters.Statement II:It is self-liquidating in nature and can be liquidated by purchasing/ discounting of bills.Statement III:Refinance from RBI is available to banks against pre-shipment credit in foreign currency.Codes:
  • A.Statements I, II and III are not correct.
  • B.Statements I and III are not correct.
  • C.Statement II is not correct
  • D.Statement II and III are not correct.
Correct Answer: Statements I and III are not correct.

Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency is a financing facility provided to exporters to finance their production and shipment of goods before they are exported. Let's evaluate each statement:

 

Statement I: It is a foreign currency loan available, both, to the importers and exporters.

This statement is incorrect. Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency is specifically provided to exporters, not importers. Exporters use this credit to finance their working capital requirements for producing and processing goods that are meant for export.

 

Statement II: It is self-liquidating in nature and can be liquidated by purchasing/ discounting of bills.

This statement is correct. Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency is self-liquidating in nature because it is expected to be repaid when the exporter receives payment for the exported goods. The credit can be liquidated by the exporter by presenting the export bills to the bank, which can then purchase or discount those bills to recover the credit amount.

 

Statement III: Refinance from RBI is available to banks against pre-shipment credit in foreign currency.

This statement is incorrect. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) does not provide refinance to banks against pre-shipment credit in foreign currency. RBI provides refinance facilities for certain domestic financing requirements, but pre-shipment credit in foreign currency is not one of them.

Question 7
Which of the following is/are not true about linear shipping? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)(a) It is used for cargo with higher unit value and manufactured or semi-manufactured goods.(b) Its shipping lines offer slower shipping services.(c) It operates regularly on a fixed schedule.(d) Its document of transport contract is called ‘Charter Party’.Choose the correct option-
  • A.a and c
  • B.a, (b) and d
  • C.d only
  • D.b and d
Correct Answer: b and d

Linear shipping, also known as liner shipping, refers to a type of shipping service where vessels operate on a fixed schedule and predetermined routes, calling at specific ports along the way to load and unload cargo. Here's an explanation of each statement:

 

(a) It is used for cargo with higher unit value and manufactured or semi-manufactured goods.

This statement is true. Linear shipping is often preferred for transporting cargo with higher unit value or manufactured goods as it provides a reliable and scheduled service, suitable for time-sensitive and valuable products.

 

(b) Its shipping lines offer slower shipping services.

This statement is not true. Linear shipping lines generally offer regular and scheduled services, and they are known for their timely and efficient operations, not for slower services.

 

(c) It operates regularly on a fixed schedule.

This statement is true. As mentioned earlier, linear shipping operates on a fixed schedule, with vessels following predetermined routes and calling at specific ports as per the schedule.

 

(d) Its document of transport contract is called ‘Charter Party’.

This statement is not true. The document of transport contract used in linear shipping is called a "Bill of Lading," not a "Charter Party." A Charter Party is a document used in chartering, which is a different type of shipping arrangement.

Question 8
If a bank in India, SBI, has an account with Citibank,Newyork, and another Indian Bank, Allahabad Bank, wants to refer to that account while corresponding with Citibank,Newyork, the Allahabad Bank would refer to which one of the following accounts? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Loro account
  • B.Mirror account
  • C.Vostro account
  • D.Mix of Nostro and Vostro account
Correct Answer: Loro account

In the given scenario:

State Bank of India (SBI) has an account with Citibank, New York.

Allahabad Bank wants to refer to SBI's account while corresponding with Citibank, New York.

 

In this case, Allahabad Bank will refer to SBI's account as “LORO ACCOUNT”.

The terms Nostro (Our) and Vostro (Your) are used in the bilateral correspondence between the concerned two Banks ie the Bank maintaining the account and the Bank in whose book the account is maintained. But in such correspondence when third bank account is referred it is said as LORO account.

 

In above question when SBI is maintaining an account with CITI Bank in New York USA in USD when Allahabad refers the said account in correspondence with SBI, Now York it is said LORO account . LORO is an Italian word which literally means ‘Their’. Loro account means ‘Third Party Account.

Question 9
In international marketing, export documentation framework engulfs which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Export census documents compiled by the department of commerce
  • B.Shipper’s Export Declarations (SEDs)
  • C.Foreign commercial service including websites of individual countries
  • D.All ofthe above
Correct Answer: All ofthe above

In international marketing, the export documentation framework encompasses (D) All of the above.

 

1. Export census documents compiled by the department of commerce: These documents provide statistics and information about exports, including details about the types and quantities of goods being exported. Export census documents are essential for tracking and analyzing trade trends.

 

2. Shipper’s Export Declarations (SEDs): SEDs are official forms used to declare exports to the government authorities. They contain information about the exported goods, their destination, and other relevant details. SEDs are a crucial part of export documentation for regulatory and statistical purposes.

 

3. Foreign commercial service including websites of individual countries: Foreign commercial services and the websites of individual countries provide valuable information and resources for businesses engaged in international marketing. They offer market research, trade leads, and assistance in navigating foreign markets.

 

So, all of these elements are part of the export documentation framework in international marketing, making option (D) the correct choice.

Question 10
Match the items given in List – I with the items of List – II and indicate the code of correct matching: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)List – Ia. CIPb. CPTc. DAFd. CIFList – IIi. Carriageii. Insurance and carriageiii. Freight, cost, insuranceiv. FrontierCodes:
  • A.a-ii, b-i, c- iv, d- iii
  • B.a-i, b- ii, c-iii, d- iv
  • C.a- iii, b- ii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a- iv, b- iii, c- ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-i, c- iv, d- iii

In international trade, different trade terms are used to specify the responsibilities and costs between the buyer and seller during the shipment of goods. These trade terms are known as Incoterms, which are published by the International Chamber of Commerce (ICC).

 

CIF (Cost, Insurance and Freight): In addition to CFR, the seller must procure the marine insurance against the buyer’s risk of loss of or damage to the goods during the carriage. The seller must clear the goods for export.

 

CIP (Carriage and Insurance Paid To): Under this term, the seller pays the freight for the carriage of the goods to the named destination. The risk of loss of or damage to the goods, as well as any additional costs due to events occurring after the time the goods have been delivered to the carrier, is transferred from the seller to the buyer when the goods have been delivered into the custody of the carrier. In addition, the seller must procure cargo insurance against the buyer’s risk of loss of or damage to the goods during the carriage. The seller must clear the goods for export.

 

CPT (Carriage Paid To): Under this term, the seller pays the freight for the carriage of the goods to the named destination. The risk of loss of or damage to the goods, as well as any additional costs due to events occurring after the time the goods have been delivered to the carrier, is transferred from the seller to the buyer when the goods have been delivered into the custody of the carrier. The seller must clear the goods for export.

 

DAF (Delivered at Frontier (…at named place)): Under this term, the seller fulfills his obligation to deliver when the goods have been made available, cleared for export, at the named point and place at the frontier, but before the customs border of the adjoining country. Primarily used for rail or truck shipments.

Question 11
Which of these is not a form of pre-shipment finance? (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.Advance against export bills sent on collection.
  • B.Advances against incentives receivable from Government.
  • C.Packing credit.
  • D.Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency.
Correct Answer: Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency.

Pre-shipment finance refers to the financial assistance provided to exporters to meet their working capital needs before the actual shipment of goods. While options (A), (B), and (C) are forms of pre-shipment finance commonly used by exporters, option (D) "Pre-shipment credit in foreign currency" is not typically considered a form of pre-shipment finance.

 

Pre-shipment credit is usually provided in the exporter's domestic currency to cover various expenses related to the production, packaging, and transportation of goods for export. The other options listed (advance against export bills, advances against incentives, and packing credit) are more commonly associated with pre-shipment finance.

Question 12
Arrange the procedure followed for disbursement of export credit in a sequence from the first to the last. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)A. The bank releases the funds debiting to the packing credit amount and credit to the exporter’s account.B. The bank calculates the amount of packing credit to be granted.C. The exporter would be required to send the goods throughapprovedtransport and forwarding agency.D. The exporter is required to take adequate insurance.E. Submit evidence of exportChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, A, E, D, C
  • B.A, C, B, D, E
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.E, B, A, C, D
Correct Answer: E, B, A, C, D

The procedure for the disbursement of export credit, from the first step to the last, is as follows:

 

1. Submit an Evidence of Export

The process begins with the exporter submitting evidence of export to their bank. This evidence typically includes documents such as the bill of lading, invoice, shipping documents, and any other relevant export paperwork. This step serves as proof that the exporter has successfully shipped the goods to the international market.

 

2. The Bank Calculates the Amount of Packing Credit

Once the evidence of export is submitted, the bank reviews the documents and calculates the amount of packing credit to be granted to the exporter. Packing credit is a type of pre-shipment finance provided to exporters to help them meet expenses related to the packing, processing, and shipment of goods.

 

3. The Bank Releases the Funds, Debiting to the Packing Credit Amount, and Credits the Exporter's Account

After determining the packing credit amount, the bank disburses the funds to the exporter. The bank debits the disbursed amount to the exporter's packing credit account, creating a liability for the exporter. Simultaneously, the same amount is credited to the exporter's bank account, providing them with the necessary funds to cover the expenses associated with preparing the goods for export.

 

4. The Exporter Sends the Goods Through an Approved Transport and Forwarding Agency

With the funds in hand, the exporter proceeds to send the goods to the international market using an approved transport and forwarding agency. These agencies specialize in logistics and facilitate the efficient movement of goods from the exporter's location to the destination.

 

5. The Exporter Takes Adequate Insurance

Before shipping the goods, the exporter is typically required to arrange for adequate insurance coverage. Export insurance protects against potential risks, such as damage or loss of goods during transit, ensuring that the exporter's financial interests are safeguarded.

Question 13
Arrange the following steps in the process of concluding an export deal. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Confirm the export deal.b. Receive letter of credit.c. Identify and negotiate withimporter.d. Receive an export order.e. Examine thoroughly and ask for amendment.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c, e, d, b
  • B.c, a, d, e, b
  • C.b, e, a, c, d
  • D.d, a, b, c, e
Correct Answer: c, a, d, e, b

The process of concluding an export deal involves several sequential steps to ensure a successful and smooth transaction. Here's an explanation of each step in the correct sequence:

 

1. Identify and negotiate with the importer (Step c): In this initial phase, the exporter identifies potential importers in foreign markets and engages in negotiations to reach an agreement on the terms and conditions of the export deal. This includes discussions on product specifications, quantity, pricing, delivery terms, and payment conditions.

 

2. Confirm the export deal (Step a): Once negotiations are successful and both parties agree on the terms, the exporter confirms the export deal by formalizing the agreement. This step involves creating a formal contract or agreement that outlines all the details discussed during negotiations. It's essential to have a clear and legally binding document to avoid misunderstandings later in the process.

 

3. Receive an export order (Step d): After confirming the deal, the exporter receives an export order from the importer. This order serves as an official request for the specified quantity of goods and reiterates the agreed-upon terms. It is crucial to ensure that the export order matches the terms outlined in the agreement to avoid discrepancies.

 

4. Examine thoroughly and ask for an amendment (Step e): Upon receiving the export order, the exporter must carefully examine it to ensure that all the details are accurate and in line with the confirmed deal. If there are any discrepancies or issues, the exporter should promptly communicate with the importer to request necessary amendments or clarifications. This step helps prevent misunderstandings and disputes during the execution of the export.

 

5. Receive a letter of credit (Step b): To secure payment for the exported goods, the exporter may request the importer to open a letter of credit (LC) with a bank. The LC serves as a guarantee that the payment will be made once the goods are delivered as per the agreed terms. Receiving the LC provides financial security to the exporter and minimizes the risk of non-payment.

Question 14
NOSTRO Account: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2009)
  • A.Refers to a current account denominated in a foreign currency maintained by a bank in the currency of home country.
  • B.Carries no interest.
  • C.Provides for nominal interest on overnight investments.
  • D.All ofthe above.
Correct Answer: Refers to a current account denominated in a foreign currency maintained by a bank in the currency of home country.

A NOSTRO account, derived from the Latin word meaning "ours," is an account held by a bank in its foreign branch or with another foreign bank. It is denominated in a foreign currency and is maintained by the bank in the currency of its home country. For example, if an Indian bank in Mumbai maintains a US dollar account with its branch or a correspondent bank in New York, it is referred to as having a NOSTRO account with the New York branch or bank. Banks with international operations typically maintain several NOSTRO accounts in various currencies in the countries where those currencies are used.

 

VOSTRO Account (from Latin "yours") is maintained in rupees in the books of Indian banks when foreign banks hold accounts with them.

 

LORO Account involves a third party in addition to the bank maintaining the NOSTRO account and the bank with whom it is maintained.

 

Mirror Account is a reflection of the NOSTRO Account in the books of the principal bank, used for reconciliation purposes and maintained in both foreign currency and rupee.

Question 15
The document issued by the shipping company in exports is called:
  • A.letter of credit
  • B.bill of lading
  • C.commercial invoice
  • D.airway bill
Correct Answer: bill of lading

The document issued by the shipping company in exports is referred to as (B) Bill of lading.

 

A Bill of Lading (B/L) is a document provided by the shipping agency. It acknowledges the goods being transported from one place to another and is signed by the representatives of the carrying vessel. It represents the shipping company's commitment to transfer the goods to the destination port. The Bill of Lading is transferable and holds significance in sea transportation. For air transport, an Airway Bill is issued instead of the Bill of Lading.

Question 16
The process of importing goods and services for the purpose of re-export is known as:
  • A.export
  • B.leasing
  • C.countertrade
  • D.entrepôt trade
Correct Answer: entrepôt trade

The process of importing goods and services for the purpose of re-exporting is recognized as (D) Entrepôt trade

 

Entrepôt trade signifies the practice of re-exporting goods, with or without processing or re-packaging them, typically taking place at duty-free ports. This type of trade involves imported goods that are re-exported without additional import or export duties or taxes being imposed.

Question 17
A reciprocal buying agreement whereby one firm sells its products to another and is compensated in the form of the other’s products at some time in the future is known as —
  • A.build–operate–transfer
  • B.offset
  • C.counterpurchase
  • D.barter
Correct Answer: counterpurchase

A reciprocal buying arrangement in which one firm sells its products to another and is compensated in the form of the other's products at a later time is referred to as (C) Counter purchase.

 

Counter purchase refers to a specific type of international trade arrangement in which two parties, typically from different countries, engage in a reciprocal buying process. In this agreement, one party sells its goods or services to the other, and as compensation, it agrees to purchase a certain quantity of materials or products from the buying party in the future.

 

For example, Company A may sell a specific product to Company B in another country, and as part of the agreement, Company B commits to buying an agreed-upon amount of products or materials from Company A at a later date. This mechanism allows for a mutual exchange of goods or services and ensures a reciprocal flow of trade between the two parties.

Question 18
An agreement which contains two contracts tobuyand sell is called a(n) —
  • A.buyback
  • B.escrow
  • C.switch trading
  • D.contract manufacturing
Correct Answer: buyback

A "buyback" is an agreement that involves two contracts to buy and sell. In this arrangement, a firm typically constructs a plant, provides technology, equipment, training, or other services in a foreign country. As part of the agreement, the firm agrees to accept a portion of the plant's output as partial payment for the original contract. This mechanism allows the selling firm to buy back a certain percentage of the goods or services produced by the established plant as part of the overall deal.

Question 19
Assertion ‘A’:Indent may be open or closed. Open indent does not specify the price and other details of the goods. The closed indent specifies the brand, price, number, packing, shipping mode, insurance, etc.Reason ‘R’:This is required as a part of export procedures.Codes:
  • A.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are correct.
  • B.Both ‘A’ and ‘R’ are not correct.
  • C.‘A’ is true, but ‘R’ is false.
  • D.‘R’ is true, but ‘A’ is false.
Correct Answer: ‘A’ is true, but ‘R’ is false.

The correct answer is C. Indents are orders placed by importers with exporters for specific goods. They detail the description of the ordered goods, pricing, terms of delivery, packaging specifics, and delivery instructions. This is a crucial part of the import procedure (and not export procedure), essential for conducting international trade.

 

Indents come in various types:

Open indent: It grants the foreign agent discretionary power for selecting goods and other details.

Closed indent: It specifies full details of the exact goods required.

Confirmatory indent: It involves placing an order subject to confirmation by the importer's agent, adding a layer of verification in the process.

Question 20
From the following identify the one which is not a commercial countertrade?
  • A.Classical barter
  • B.Counter purchase
  • C.Pre-compensation
  • D.Buy-back agreement
Correct Answer: Buy-back agreement

Countertrade encompasses various forms of international trade arrangements that involve the exchange of goods or services in place of currency transactions.

 

The primary types include barter, counter purchase, and pre-compensation. Bartering involves the direct exchange of goods without monetary involvement. Counter purchase entails selling goods or services to an importer while agreeing to buy other goods from them within a set period through a trading firm. Pre-compensation trade combines hard currency and goods in the transaction.

 

However, a buyback, in contrast to the other forms, involves an agreement where one party, after establishing a manufacturing facility or providing services, agrees to receive a percentage of the plant's output as partial payment, differing from the direct exchange characteristic of other countertrade forms.

Question 21
The INCOTERMS is a set of international rules promulgated by the International Chamber of Commerce for the uniform interpretation of commonly used trade terms in foreign trade. The CPT stands for:
  • A.Cost Paid To
  • B.Carriage Paid To
  • C.Cost Paid Terminal
  • D.Carriage Paid Terminal
Correct Answer: Carriage Paid To

CPT (Carriage Paid To) is an INCOTERM specifying that the seller covers the cost of transporting the goods to the designated destination. This term involves the seller paying for the freight during the carriage, and the risk of damage or loss, along with additional expenses after delivery to the carrier, transfers to the buyer. Additionally, the responsibility of clearing the goods for export rests with the seller.

Question 22
Which of the following is an arrangement, whereby a bank (the Issuing bank) acting at the request and on the instructions of a customer (the Applicant) or on its own behalf, to make a payment to or to the order third party (the beneficiary) or is to accept bills of exchange (drafts) drawn by the beneficiary.
  • A.Bill of Credit
  • B.Bill of Guarantee
  • C.Letter of Credit
  • D.Letter of Guarantee
Correct Answer: Letter of Credit

A Letter of Credit (LC) is a financial arrangement where a bank, acting at the request of a customer (the applicant) or on its own behalf, agrees to make payments to a third party (the beneficiary) or accept bills of exchange (drafts) drawn by the beneficiary. The LC serves as a guarantee from the bank that the beneficiary will receive payment as long as the terms and conditions specified in the LC are met. This financial instrument is widely used in international trade to ensure secure and reliable payment for goods or services provided.

Question 23
The _______________ account means ‘our account with you’. It is an account maintained by a bank with its branch or another bank at overseas centre and the account is maintained in foreign currency.
  • A.VOSTRO Account
  • B.NOSTRO Account
  • C.LORO Account
  • D.Mirror Account
Correct Answer: NOSTRO Account

The term "NOSTRO" originates from Latin, meaning "our." A NOSTRO account refers to "our account with you," maintained by a bank with its branch or another bank in a foreign country, typically in a foreign currency. This account is crucial for international banking operations, allowing banks to manage funds in overseas centers.

 

For instance, an Indian bank operating in Mumbai maintaining a US dollar account with its branch or a correspondent bank in New York is considered to have a NOSTRO account with the New York branch or bank. This system necessitates multiple NOSTRO accounts in various currencies corresponding to different countries in international banking.

Question 24
Which of the following documents are not required for obtaining an export license?
  • A.IEC number
  • B.Letter of credit
  • C.Registration cum membership certificate
  • D.Bank account number
Correct Answer: Letter of credit

Before exporting goods, it is mandatory for exporters and export firms to fulfill the legal formalities, including securing an export license.

 

The following are the formalities to obtain an export license.

1. Bank account number: An exporter must open an account in a bank authorised by the RBI and get an account number.

2. IEC code: An export firm must obtain an IEC (Importer Exporter Code) from the Directorate General for Foreign Trade (DGFT) or the Regional Import Export Licensing Authority by submitting documents such as the exporter’s profile, prescribed certificates, two attested photographs and details of non-resident interest. It is a 10 digit number.

3. Registration-cum-membership certificate: An export firm should get itself registered with the appropriate Export Promotion Council, such as the Engineering Export Promotion Council (EEPC) and the Apparel Export Promotion Council (AEPC), and obtain a Registration Cum Membership Certificate (RCMC).

4. Registration with ECGC: An export firm must also get itself registered with the ECGC (Export Credit and Guarantee Corporation) in order to protect itself from any uncertainties in payments brought upon by political or commercial risks.

 

Hence the correct answer is B.

Question 25
Which one of the following is not a document related to fulfil the customs formalities:
  • A.Shipping bill
  • B.Export license
  • C.Letter of insurance
  • D.Pro-forma invoice
Correct Answer: Pro-forma invoice

Before the final loading of goods for export, it is necessary for the exporter to get the goods cleared by customs. This is known as Securing Customs Clearance. In this regard, an exporter first requires to submit the following documents to the customs appraiser at the Customs House:

1. Shipping bill

2. Export order

3. Letter of credit
