4. Commercial invoice

5. Certificate of origin

6. Certificate of inspection, if necessary

7. Marine insurance policy.

Question 26
A receipt issued by the commanding officer of the ship when the cargo is loaded on the ship is known as:
  • A.shipping receipt
  • B.mate receipt
  • C.cargo receipt
  • D.charter receipt
Correct Answer: mate receipt

The document known as the "Mate's Receipt" is issued by the captain or commanding officer of a ship to an exporter. It serves as evidence that the exporter's cargo has been loaded onto the vessel. This receipt contains crucial details including the name of the ship, its berth, the date of shipment, the condition of the cargo during loading, a description of the cargo packages, their number, and package marks. After the port dues are received, the port superintendent provides the Mate’s Receipt to the C and F (Clearing and Forwarding) agent involved. This receipt is a prerequisite for the shipping company to issue the bill of lading.

Question 27
The document containing the guarantee of a bank to honour drafts drawn on it by an exporter is:
  • A.letter of hypothecation
  • B.letter of credit
  • C.bill of lading
  • D.bill of exchange
Correct Answer: letter of credit

A letter of credit (LC) is a financial document issued by a bank to assure the payment of a specified amount to a seller/exporter once the seller fulfills the obligations mentioned in the agreement. It acts as a guarantee of payment, assuring the exporter that they will be paid when certain conditions are met, typically after shipping the goods and presenting the required documents as per the terms agreed upon. For importers, an LC helps establish credibility and trust, as the exporter gains assurance of payment upon complying with the agreed-upon conditions. This method is a secure and common way to conduct international trade, reducing the risk of non-payment for exported goods.

Question 28
Which of the following document is prepared by the exporter and includes details of the cargo in terms of theshippersname, the number of packages, the shipping bill, port of destination, name of the vehicle carrying the cargo?
  • A.Shipping bill
  • B.Packaging list
  • C.Mate receipt
  • D.Bill of exchange
Correct Answer: Shipping bill

The document prepared by the exporter, containing comprehensive details of the cargo to be exported, including specifics about the shipper, package quantity, shipping details, and more, is known as the Shipping Bill (option A). This document is a fundamental requirement for export transactions, providing vital information that helps customs authorities grant clearance for the export. It encompasses details like the exporter’s information, destination port, name of the vessel, and the country of final destination for the goods.

Question 29
What is the primary purpose of INCOTERMs in international trade?
  • A.To establish international shipping regulations
  • B.To standardize trade documentation
  • C.To determine the mode of transportation
  • D.To enforce customs duties
Correct Answer: To standardize trade documentation

INCOTERMs are used to standardize trade terms and define the responsibilities of buyers and sellers in international trade transactions.

Question 30
What does the CIP (Carriage and Insurance Paid To) trade term require the seller to do?
  • A.Pay for the freight to the named destination
  • B.Procure cargo insurance for the buyer
  • C.Clear the goods for export
  • D.Pay customs duties
Correct Answer: Procure cargo insurance for the buyer

In CIP, the seller must pay for the freight to the named destination and also procure cargo insurance against the buyer's risk of loss or damage to the goods during the carriage.

Question 31
Under which trade term does the sellerfulfilltheir obligation to deliver when the goods are made available to the buyer at the named place in the country of importation, with all costs and risks borne by the seller?
  • A.DAF (Delivered at Frontier)
  • B.DDU (Delivered Duty Unpaid)
  • C.DEQ (Delivered Ex Quay)
  • D.DES (Delivered Ex Ship)
Correct Answer: DAF (Delivered at Frontier)

DAF (Delivered at Frontier) requires the seller to deliver the goods at the named point and place at the frontier, with all costs and risks borne by the seller except duties, taxes, and other official charges payable upon importation.

Question 32
Under which INCOTERM does the seller have the minimum obligation for delivery, making the goods available at their own premises for collection by the buyer?
  • A.EXW (Ex Works)
  • B.FOB (FreeOnBoard)
  • C.CIF (Cost, Insurance, and Freight)
  • D.DDP (Delivered Duty Paid)
Correct Answer: EXW (Ex Works)

EXW is the INCOTERM where the seller's obligation is the minimum. The seller makes the goods available at their own premises to the buyer, and the buyer is responsible for all costs and risks involved in transporting the goods from the seller's premises to the desired destination.

Question 33
In which INCOTERM does the seller take responsibility for delivering goods cleared for export into the charge of the carrier named by the buyer?
  • A.CFR (Cost and Freight)
  • B.FCA (Free Carrier)
  • C.DDP (Delivered Duty Paid)
  • D.DAF (Delivered at Frontier)
Correct Answer: FCA (Free Carrier)

FCA (Free Carrier) is where the seller fulfills the obligation by handing over the goods, cleared for export, to the carrier named by the buyer at the agreed place or point.

Question 34
Under which INCOTERM does the seller assume the highest obligation for delivery, bearing all costs and risks, including duties, taxes, and charges, until the goods are made available at the buyer's named place in the country of importation?
  • A.DDP (Delivered Duty Paid)
  • B.DDU (Delivered Duty Unpaid)
  • C.CIF (Cost, Insurance, and Freight)
  • D.DES (Delivered Ex Ship)
Correct Answer: DDP (Delivered Duty Paid)

DDP (Delivered Duty Paid) represents the maximum obligation to the seller. The seller is responsible for all costs and risks, including duties, taxes, and charges, until the goods are delivered to the buyer at the named place in the country of importation.

Question 35
A written statement by the exporter ordering the importer to pay a specific amount of money at a specified future date is known as a __________.
  • A.bill of lading
  • B.sight draft
  • C.time draft
  • D.letter of credit
Correct Answer: time draft

A written statement by the exporter ordering the importer to pay a specific amount of money at a specified future date is known as a time draft. A sight draft is payable on presentation to the party to whom the draft is addressed.

Question 36
A shipping document indicating the details of the shipment and delivery of goods and their ownership is a __________.
  • A.bill of lading
  • B.sight draft
  • C.time draft
  • D.letter of credit
Correct Answer: bill of lading

A shipping document indicating the details of the shipment and delivery of goods and their ownership is a bill of lading.

Question 37
Amish is an exporter who has sold outright their accounts receivable to another institution. This is an example of __________.
  • A.export factoring
  • B.forfaiting
  • C.striding
  • D.countertrade
Correct Answer: export factoring

Export factoring involves the outright sale of the exporting firm’s accounts receivable to a factoring institution, called a factor.

Question 38
The process of converting a non‐productive, inactive asset into a productive asset by selling receivables to a company that specializes in their collection and administration, is described as (UGC NET Management Jun 2021)
  • A.Credit administration
  • B.Factoring
  • C.Receivables management
  • D.Credit rating
Correct Answer: Factoring

The process of converting non-productive, inactive assets, such as receivables, into productive assets by selling them to a specialized company for collection and administration is described as (B) Factoring.

 

Factoring is a financial transaction where a business sells its accounts receivable (invoices) to a third party (called a factor) at a discount. The factor then collects the receivables from the debtor and assumes responsibility for managing the associated credit risks and collections. This allows the business to access immediate cash flow by converting its accounts receivable into cash without waiting for customers to pay their invoices.

 

The other options are related concepts but do not specifically describe the process mentioned in the question:

 

(A) Credit administration: Credit administration involves managing the credit policies and procedures of a company, including assessing creditworthiness, setting credit limits, and monitoring credit risk. It does not specifically involve converting receivables into cash through selling them to a third party.

(C) Receivables management: Receivables management refers to the process of managing a company's accounts receivable, including billing customers, collecting payments, and managing credit risks. While factoring is a method used in receivables management, the term itself does not specifically describe the process mentioned in the question.

(D) Credit rating: Credit rating is the assessment of the creditworthiness of a borrower or issuer of debt securities. It involves evaluating the likelihood of default and assigning a rating based on the borrower's ability to repay debt obligations. It is not directly related to converting receivables into cash through factoring.

Question 39
Match the types of factoring given in List —I with its characteristics given in List — II: (UGC NET Management Dec 2014)List — Ii. Full-service non-recourse factoringii. Full-service resource factoringiii. Bulk factoringiv.Non-notificationfactoringList - IIa. Clients are not informed about the factoring arrangementb. Bad-debt protection to clientc. No bad-debt protection to clientd. Client continues to administer credit and to operate sales ledgerCodes:
  • A.i-a, ii-b, iii-c, iv-d
  • B.i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a
  • C.i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b
  • D.i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-c
Correct Answer: i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a

Let us break down each type of factoring:

 

i. Full-service non-recourse factoring: In this arrangement, the factoring company provides bad-debt protection to the client. This means that if a customer fails to pay due to insolvency or other specified reasons, the factoring company absorbs the loss, and the client is not held responsible. This type of factoring provides a higher level of security for the client, as they are protected from credit risk.

 

ii. Full-service recourse factoring: In contrast to non-recourse factoring, in recourse factoring, the factoring company does not provide bad-debt protection to the client. If a customer fails to pay, the client is responsible for repaying the advance to the factoring company. This type of factoring typically involves lower fees for the client but carries higher risk, as the client is liable for any unpaid invoices.

 

iii. Bulk factoring: In bulk factoring, the client retains control over administering credit and managing the sales ledger. The factoring company purchases a batch or "bulk" of the client's accounts receivable, but the client continues to handle collections and customer relationships. This arrangement provides flexibility for the client to maintain direct communication with their customers.

 

iv. Non-notification factoring: In this type of factoring, clients are not informed about the factoring arrangement. The factoring company purchases the accounts receivable without notifying the clients' customers. This allows the client to maintain control over customer relationships and collections processes. Non-notification factoring is often used when the client prefers to keep the factoring arrangement confidential for strategic or other reasons.

Question 40
Countertrade means: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.A sort of bilateral trade where one set of goods is exchanged for another set of goods and a seller provides a buyer with deliveries.
  • B.A company takes full responsibility for making its goods available in the target market by selling directly to the end-users.
  • C.The companies in two separate sovereigns agree to exchange one set of goods for another set of goods.
  • D.A set of multilateral trade where one of goods and services may be exchanged for another set of goods and services among the trading partners.
Correct Answer: A sort of bilateral trade where one set of goods is exchanged for another set of goods and a seller provides a buyer with deliveries.

Option A is correct.

Countertrade is a type of international trade arrangement where goods or services are exchanged directly for other goods or services, instead of using money as a medium of exchange. This practice is often employed when conventional currency-based transactions are not feasible due to various reasons such as foreign exchange regulations, currency shortages, or lack of creditworthiness.

 

Option (A) accurately describes countertrade as a bilateral trade arrangement involving the exchange of goods for goods, with the seller providing deliveries to the buyer. This means that instead of paying with currency, the parties agree to trade goods or services directly, typically based on an agreed-upon value or quantity.

 

Countertrade arrangements can take various forms, including barter trade, counter-purchase, buyback, offset, and switch trading. These arrangements allow businesses to overcome obstacles such as foreign currency restrictions, balance of payment issues, or limited access to credit, enabling them to engage in international trade even in challenging economic environments.

Question 41
From the following identify the one which is not a commercial counter trade? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Classical barter
  • B.Counter purchase
  • C.Pre-compensation
  • D.Buy-back agreement
Correct Answer: Buy-back agreement

The correct answer is (C) Pre-compensation

Let's briefly explain the other options:

(A) Classical barter: In classical barter, goods or services are directly exchanged for other goods or services without the use of money.

(B) Counter purchase: In counter purchase, a firm agrees to purchase a certain amount of materials or goods from a country in exchange for selling a specified amount of products to that country.

(D)Buy-back agreement: In a buy-back agreement, a seller agrees to supply technology, equipment, or machinery to a buyer in exchange for a commitment from the buyer to purchase a specified quantity of products produced using the supplied technology or equipment.

Question 42
A trade agreement in which a domestic firm accepts whiskey for full payment on a sale of computer equipment is an example of __________.
  • A.export factoring
  • B.forfaiting
  • C.a scene from the classic movie "Animal House"
  • D.countertrade
Correct Answer: countertrade

A trade agreement in which a domestic firm accepts whiskey for full payment on a sale of computer equipment is an example of countertrade. In countertrade agreement the selling party accepts payment in the form of goods instead of currency.

Question 43
Which of the following is not a characteristic of bartering internationally? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Bartering can be time – consuming.
  • B.Bartering can be expensive.
  • C.Bartering is a type of service export and import.
  • D.Bartering can be risky.
Correct Answer: Bartering is a type of service export and import.

The correct answer is (C) Bartering is a type of service export and import.

 

Bartering internationally refers to the exchange of goods or services directly for other goods or services without using money as a medium of exchange. The other characteristics mentioned in the options are typical of international bartering:

(A) Bartering can be time-consuming: Negotiating the terms of exchange, finding suitable trading partners, and arranging the logistics of transporting goods or delivering services can indeed be time-consuming.

(B) Bartering can be expensive: Despite the absence of monetary exchange, there can still be costs associated with transporting goods, storage, insurance, and other logistics involved in the bartering process.

(D) Bartering can be risky: Bartering involves risks such as the quality of goods or services exchanged, the reliability of trading partners, and fluctuations in the value of goods or services over time.

Option (C) suggests that bartering is a type of service export and import, which is incorrect. Bartering typically involves the exchange of tangible goods or physical services, rather than purely services. Therefore, option (C) is not a characteristic of bartering internationally.

Question 44
Which of the following is not an example of an international trade draft?
  • A.Time draft.
  • B.Sight draft.
  • C.Both the first and second answers are correct.
  • D.None of the answers given are correct.
Correct Answer: Both the first and second answers are correct.

The international trade draft, sometimes called a bill of exchange, is simply a written statement by the exporter ordering the importer to pay a specific amount of money at a specific time. The draft may be either a sight draft or a time draft. A sight draft is payable on presentation to the party to whom the draft is addressed. A time draft is not payable until a specified future date.

Quiz Attempt #119468

Total Questions: 38
Question 1
Regional Economic Integration is an attempt to achieve economic gains from the free flow of trade and investment between countries. One such association is NAFTA. NAFTA comprises of the following countries:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.USA, Canada, Mexico
  • B.USA, Canada, Brazil
  • C.USA, Mexico, Brazil
  • D.Canada, Mexico, Panama
Correct Answer: USA, Canada, Mexico

Option A is the correct answer.

 

NAFTA, which stands for the North American Free Trade Agreement, was a trade agreement between the United States, Canada, and Mexico. It came into effect on January 1, 1994, and its primary goal was to eliminate barriers to trade and investment among the three countries. NAFTA marked a significant milestone in regional economic cooperation, creating one of the world's largest free-trade zones.

Question 2
Which one group of the following countries are members of ASEAN?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Laos, Cambodia. Brunei
  • B.Malaysia, Thailand, Taiwan
  • C.Myanmar. Singapore. Hong Kong
  • D.Fiji. Laos, Cambodia
Correct Answer: Laos, Cambodia. Brunei

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations is a regional organization which was established to promote political and social stability amid rising tensions among the Asia-Pacific’s post-colonial states. The motto of ASEAN is “One Vision, One Identity, One Community”.

 

Member Nations – Indonesia; Malaysia; Philippines; Singapore; Thailand; Brunei; Vietnam; Laos; Myanmar; Cambodia

Question 3
SAFTA (South Asian Free Trade Agreement) categorises member nations as Non-Least Developed Contracting States (NLDCS) and Least Developed Contracting States (LDCS). Identify the NLDSC states from the following.(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Bangladeshb. Pakistanc. Bhutand. Indiae. Sri LankaChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.a, b and d only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.e, a and b only
  • D.e, d and b only
Correct Answer: e, d and b only

The South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) is the free trade arrangement of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC). The agreement came into force in 2006, succeeding the 1993 SAARC Preferential Trading Arrangement. SAFTA signatory countries are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

 

SAFTA categorized Bangladesh, Bhutan, Maldives, and Nepal as Least Developed Contracting States (LDCs), and India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka as Non-Least Developed Contracting States (NLDCs). Based on these categorizations, SAFTA began its phased tariff liberalization program (TPL), wherein all LDCs were expected to bring down their tariffs to 30 percent, and all NLDCs to 20 percent. Both the NDLCs and the LDCs were expected to lower the tariffs to zero to five percent within the next eight and five years, respectively; this was six years for Sri Lanka.

Question 4
Match the LIST-I with LIST-II(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)LIST-I (Institution)A. UNCTADB. WTOC. NAFTAD. ASEANLIST-II (Year of Establishment)I. 1967II. 1994III. 1964IV. 1995Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • C.A-I, B-III, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I

The correct match is given below.

 

UNCTAD (1964) – The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) was established to promote international trade, especially for developing countries.

WTO (1995) – The World Trade Organization (WTO) replaced GATT to regulate global trade and resolve trade disputes.

NAFTA (1994) – The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was a trade bloc between the US, Canada, and Mexico, later replaced by USMCA in 2020.

ASEAN (1967) – The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) was formed to promote economic and political cooperation among Southeast Asian countries.

Question 5
Match List – I and List – II relating to WTO: (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)List – I (Agreements)(a) SAFTA(b) FTA (with EHS)(c) CECA(d) GSTPList – II (Signing dates)(i) 9thOctober 2003(ii) 13thAugust 2009(iii) 1stJanuary 2004(iv) 13thApril 1988Codes :
  • A.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • C.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv

Correct answer is option B.

 

(a) SAFTA - (iii) 1st January 2004

(b) FTA (with EHS) - (i) 9th October 2003

(c) CECA - (ii) 13th August 2009

(d) GSTP - (iv) 13th April 1988

 

The South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) is the free trade arrangement of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC). The agreement came into force in 2006, succeeding the 1993 SAARC Preferential Trading Arrangement.

 

The India-Thailand Free Trade Agreement (FTA) Early Harvest Scheme (EHS) is a bilateral trade agreement between India and Thailand. The EHS is a specific component of this broader FTA, and it is designed to provide some immediate benefits to the two countries even before the full FTA is implemented.

 

The Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) between India and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a regional trade agreement that aims to promote economic cooperation and enhance trade and investment between India and the ASEAN member states. The agreement is part of India's efforts to strengthen economic ties with Southeast Asian countries.

 

GSTP means the agreement on Global System of Trade Preferences among Developing Countries signed by developing countries at Belgrade, Yugoslavia on the 13th April, 1988.

Question 6
Which trade group, among the following holds ‘Tamil’ as one of its official languages? (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.ASEAN
  • B.SAARC
  • C.BRICS
  • D.MINT
Correct Answer: ASEAN

ASEAN stands for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. It is a regional intergovernmental organization comprising ten Southeast Asian countries, which are Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, Brunei, Vietnam, Laos, Myanmar (Burma), and Cambodia.

 

Among these member countries, Tamil is one of the official languages of Singapore. Singapore is a member of ASEAN, and alongside English, Malay, and Mandarin Chinese, Tamil is recognized as an official language in the country.

 

Therefore, ASEAN is the trade group that holds Tamil as one of its official languages due to the presence of Singapore as a member country.

Question 7
Member Countries of NAFTA are (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)
  • A.Brazil, USA and Canada
  • B.Canada, USA and Mexico
  • C.USA, Argentina and Canada
  • D.Panama, USA and Canada
Correct Answer: Canada, USA and Mexico

NAFTA stands for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was an agreement signed between three countries: Canada, the United States, and Mexico. It came into effect on January 1, 1994, with the goal of promoting trade and economic cooperation among the three member countries.

Question 8
Treaties of Rome (1957) was responsible for creation of which one of the following? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.European Economic Community (EEC)
  • B.General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT)
  • C.WTO
  • D.General Agreement on Trade in Services (GATS)
Correct Answer: European Economic Community (EEC)

The Treaties of Rome, signed in 1957, were two international agreements that led to the creation of the European Economic Community (EEC) and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM). These treaties marked a significant step towards economic integration and cooperation among European countries.

 

The European Economic Community (EEC) aimed to establish a customs union among its member states, promoting the free movement of goods, services, capital, and labor within the community. Over time, the EEC evolved into what is now known as the European Union (EU), which encompasses not only economic cooperation but also political, social, and legal integration among its member countries.

 

Option (A) European Economic Community (EEC) is the correct answer as it represents the main outcome of the Treaties of Rome and the precursor to the modern European Union.

Question 9
Which one of the following FTA was signed in February 2022 and came into force in May 2022? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.AI-ECTA Australia - India Economic Cooperation and Trade Agreement
  • B.India-UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA)
  • C.India-Nepal Treaty of Trade
  • D.India-Singapore Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA)
Correct Answer: India-UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA)

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The historic India-UAE Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) was signed between the two nations on 18th February 2022 and was entered into force on 1st May 2022. Government also flagged off the first consignment of goods comprising of Jewellery products from India to UAE under the India-UAE CEPA.

Question 10
Who among the following is not an observer country of the SAARC? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Iran
  • B.Canada
  • C.China
  • D.USA
Correct Answer: Canada

Canada is not an observer country of the SAARC.

 

South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation (SAARC) is an economic and political regional organisation of countries in South Asia set up in 1985. It aims to accelerate the process of economic and social development in its member states through increased intra-regional cooperation.

 

SAARC has eight member countries (Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri-Lanka) and nine observer status countries (Australia, China, the European Union, Iran, Japan, South Korea, Mauritius, Burma/Myanmar and the United States of America). SAARC Heads of State are scheduled to meet at annual Summits.

Question 11
One belt, one road initiative (BRI) is NOT intended to (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.trade protectionism
  • B.strengthening logistic and supply chain
  • C.improve cost competitiveness
  • D.rebalance trade dominance
Correct Answer: trade protectionism

The One Belt, One Road (OBOR) initiative, also known as the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), is a large-scale infrastructure and economic development project initiated by China. The main objectives of the BRI are to strengthen logistics and supply chains, improve cost competitiveness, and rebalance trade dominance in favor of the countries involved in the initiative. It aims to enhance connectivity and promote economic cooperation between China and other countries in Asia, Europe, Africa, and beyond.

 

The BRI is not intended to promote trade protectionism. On the contrary, it aims to foster greater economic openness, connectivity, and cooperation among participating countries by investing in infrastructure, trade facilitation, and people-to-people exchanges. It seeks to create a more interconnected and integrated global economy, encouraging trade and investment flows between the participating nations.

Question 12
Mercosur, a South American Trade block is a: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Free Trade Area
  • B.Common Market
  • C.Custom Union
  • D.Economic Cooperation
Correct Answer: Common Market

The Southern Common Market (MERCOSUR for its Spanish initials) is a regional integration process, initially established by Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay, and subsequently joined by Venezuela and Bolivia, the latter still complying with the accession procedure.

 

In 1994, the group signed the Protocol of OuroPreto, formalizing its status as a customs union. The bloc’s highest decision-making body, the Common Market Council, provides a high-level forum for coordinating foreign and economic policy.

Question 13
The headquarters of the ASEANis located inwhich of the following countries? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.Indonesia
  • B.Vietnam
  • C.Thailand
  • D.Singapore
Correct Answer: Indonesia

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations ASEAN was established on 8 August 1967 in Bangkok by the five original member countries: Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand. Brunei, Darussalam joined on 8 January 1984, Vietnam on 28 July 1995, Laos and Myanmar on 23 July 1997, and Cambodia on 30 April 1999. Currently there are 10 permanent members of this association.  The headquarter is in Jakarta (Indonesia).

Question 14
Which of the following treaties marked the establishment of the European Union?
  • A.Maastricht Treaty
  • B.Berlin Treaty
  • C.Treaty of Lisbon
  • D.Treaty of London
Correct Answer: Maastricht Treaty

The implementation of the Maastricht Treaty in 1993 marked a pivotal moment in establishing the European Union (EU) and introducing European citizenship. It formalized the structure of the EU, emphasizing economic and political cooperation among European nations. The treaty's enforcement led to the consolidation of the EU's framework, bringing forth significant aspects of European unity and integration, such as a common foreign policy and the adoption of a single currency in participating member states.

Question 15
The European Commission is headquartered in —
  • A.Paris
  • B.Geneva
  • C.Brussels
  • D.London
Correct Answer: Brussels

The EU has no official capital, and no plans to declare one, but Brussels hosts the official seats of the European Commission, Council of the European Union, and European Council, as well as a seat (officially the second seat but de facto the most important one) of the European Parliament.

Question 16
Which of the following is not a member of SAARC?
  • A.Nepal
  • B.Afghanistan
  • C.Mauritius
  • D.the Maldives
Correct Answer: Mauritius

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) is the regional intergovernmental organization and geopolitical union of states in South Asia. Its member states are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

Question 17
SAARC is headquartered in —
  • A.Kathmandu
  • B.New Delhi
  • C.Islamabad
  • D.Colombo
Correct Answer: Kathmandu

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) is the regional intergovernmental organization and geopolitical union of states in South Asia. Its member states are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, the Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. It is headquartered in Kathmandu.

Question 18
NAFTA is an example of a(n)—
  • A.customs union
  • B.economic union
  • C.FTA
  • D.common market
Correct Answer: FTA

NAFTA (North America Free Trade Zone) is an example of Free Trade Zone.

Question 19
The Multi-Fibre Arrangement was an agreementin the area of—
  • A.coffee
  • B.petroleum
  • C.textiles
  • D.bananas
Correct Answer: textiles

The Multi Fibre Arrangement (MFA) governed the world trade in textiles and garments from 1974 through 1994, imposing quotas on the amount developing countries could export to developed countries. Its successor, the Agreement on Textiles and Clothing (ATC), expired on 1 January 2005.

Question 20
Which of the following is not a founding member of the OPEC?
  • A.Venezuela
  • B.Kuwait
  • C.Iran
  • D.Brazil
Correct Answer: Brazil

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) was founded in Baghdad, Iraq, with the signing of an agreement in September 1960 by five countries namely Islamic Republic of Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela. They were to become the Founder Members of the Organization.

Question 21
CARICOM was established under which of the following treaties?
  • A.Treaty of Venice
  • B.Treaty of Rome
  • C.Coal and Steel Treaty
  • D.Treaty of Chaguaramas
Correct Answer: Treaty of Chaguaramas

The Caribbean Community (CARICOM) is a grouping of   twenty countries: fifteen Member States and 5 Associate Members. It is home to approximately sixteen million citizens, 60% of whom are under the age of 30, and from the main ethnic groups of Indigenous Peoples, Africans, Indians, Europeans, Chinese, Portuguese and Javanese. The Community is multi-lingual; with English as the major language complemented by French and Dutch and variations of these, as well as African and Asian expressions.

 

CARICOM came into being on 4 July 1973 with the signing of the Treaty of Chaguaramas by Prime Ministers Errol Barrow for Barbados, Forbes Burnham for Guyana, Michael Manley for Jamaica and Eric Williams for Trinidad and Tobago. The Treaty was later revised in 2002 to allow for the eventual establishment of a single market and a single economy.

Question 22
MERCOSUR originated as free-trade pact between —
  • A.Brazil and Argentina
  • B.Brazil and Venezuela
  • C.Argentina and Chile
  • D.Uruguay and Peru
Correct Answer: Brazil and Argentina

Mercosur (in Spanish), Mercosul (in Portuguese) officially Southern Common Market,[a] is a South American trade bloc established by the Treaty of Asunción in 1991 and Protocol of Ouro Preto in 1994. Its full members are Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, and Uruguay. Venezuela is a full member but has been suspended since 1 December 2016. Associate countries are Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Guyana, Peru and Suriname.

Question 23
Which of the following is a trade agreement between countries of the developed and developing world?
  • A.NAFTA
  • B.LAFTA
  • C.MERCOSUR
  • D.ALADI
Correct Answer: NAFTA

The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was a treaty between Canada, Mexico, and the United States that eliminated most tariffs between the counties. It was replaced by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) on July 1, 2020.

Question 24
The genesis of the European Union is in the —
  • A.Treaty of Maastricht
  • B.Treaty of Rome
  • C.Schengen Agreement
  • D.Coal and Steel Treaty
Correct Answer: Treaty of Maastricht

The EU and European citizenship were established when the Maastricht Treaty came into force in 1993. The EU traces its origins to the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) and the European Economic Community (EEC), established, respectively, by the 1951 Treaty of Paris and 1957 Treaty of Rome. The original members of what came to be known as the European Communities were the Inner Six: Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, and West Germany.

Question 25
The ANDEAN Pact is a —
  • A.FTA
  • B.common market
  • C.customs union
  • D.political union
Correct Answer: customs union

The Andean Community is a free trade area with the objective of creating a customs union comprising the South American countries of Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, and Peru. The trade bloc was called the Andean Pact until 1969 and came into existence when the Cartagena Agreement was signed in 1996. Its headquarters are in Lima, Peru.

 

The Andean Community has 98 million inhabitants who live in an area of 4.700.000 km². Its GDP has gone up to US$745.300 million in 2005 that is including Venezuela who was a member at the time. Its estimated PPP of GDP for 2011 amounts to US $902.86 million, excluding Venezuela.

Question 26
India is not associated with
  • A.SAARC
  • B.NAFTA
  • C.BRICS
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: NAFTA

South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) was established with the signing of the SAARC Charter in Dhaka on 8 December 1985. SAARC comprises of eight Member States: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

 

North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) entered into force on 1st January, 1994 by government of Canada, Mexico and U.S.A to create a tri- lateral trade bloc in North America.

 

BRIC is the economic initialization for the countries of Brazil, Russia, India, and China. Economists believe these four nations will become dominant suppliers of manufactured goods, services and raw material by 2050. China and India will become the world's dominant suppliers of manufactured goods and services, respectively, while Brazil and Russia will become similarly dominant as suppliers of raw materials. This organisation later included South Africa and became BRICS.

Question 27
BRICS includes (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Bhutan, Romania, Indonesia, Chile and South Korea
  • B.Brazil, Russia, Indonesia, Chile and Sudan
  • C.Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa
  • D.Britain, Russia, India, Czechoslovakia, Sri Lanka
Correct Answer: Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa

BRICS is an annual summit of five nations viz. Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa. First such formal summit was held at Yekaterinburg on June 16, 2009. The BRIC nations formally invited South Africa to join the group and on December 24, 2010, the group was renamed as BRICS. It is headquartered at Shanghai, China. The objective of the association involves myriad of goals ranging from supporting China’s one belt and road initiative (OBOR) to trade, communication, regional security, human security, human development, technological development, eradication of terrorism and alleviation of social and economic evils from the region.

Question 28
Which one of the following matches correspond to the Member and Observer countries of the SAARC? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)(i) India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, Maldives(ii) Iran, China, Japan, USA, South Korea, European Union(iii) Pakistan, Nepal, India, Bangladesh, Iran(iv) UK, USA, North Korea, South Africa
  • A.(iii) and (iv)
  • B.(ii) and (iv)
  • C.(i) and (ii)
  • D.(ii) and (iii)
Correct Answer: (i) and (ii)

SAARC has eight member countries - Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri-Lanka and nine observer status countries -China, the European Union, Iran, Japan, South Korea, Mauritius, Burma/Myanmar, Australia and the United States of America. SAARC Heads of State are scheduled to meet at annual Summits.

Question 29
As per the South Asia Free Trade Agreement, 1993 of SAARC, the member countrieshave tobring their duties down to
  • A.25 percent by 2006
  • B.15 percent by 2006
  • C.10 percent by 2007
  • D.20 percent by 2007
Correct Answer: 20 percent by 2007

In 1993, SAARC countries signed an agreement to gradually lower tariffs within the region, in Dhaka. Eleven years later, at the 12th SAARC Summit at Islamabad, SAARC countries devised the South Asia Free Trade Agreement which created a framework for the establishment of a free trade area covering 1.4 billion people. This agreement went into force on January 1, 2006. Under this agreement, SAARC members were supposed to bring their duties down to 20 per cent by 2007.

Question 30
Match the items of List – I with List – II: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)List – I (International Economic Groups)a. European Union (EU)b. European Free Trade Association (EFTA)c. Caribbean Community (CARICOM)d. South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC)List – II (Year of Establishment)i. 1973ii. 1992iii. 1985iv. 1960Codes:
  • A.a-ii, b-iv c-iii, d-i
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

The European Union (EU) was created by the Maastricht Treaty, which entered into force on November 1, 1993 at Maastricht, Netherlands.

 

The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) is the intergovernmental organisation of Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland. It was set up in 1960 by its then seven Member States for the promotion of free trade and economic integration between its members.

 

The Caribbean Community and Common Market (CARICOM) brings together 15 member states and 5 associate member states in the Caribbean. Member states include Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Belize, Dominica, Haiti, Jamaica, Grenada, Guyana, Montserrat, St. Lucia, Suriname, St. Kitts and Nevis, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago. It was established by the Treaty of Chaguaramas, and was signed by Barbados, Jamaica, Guyana and Trinidad & Tobago on August 1, 1973. CARICOM rests on four main pillars: economic integration; foreign policy coordination; human and social development; and security. 

 

The South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) was established with the signing of the SAARC Charter in Dhaka on 8 December 1985.

Question 31
Which one of the following is not a member country in the Association of South-East Asian Nations (ASEAN)? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Singapore
  • B.Malaysia
  • C.Thailand
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: None of above

Association of Southeast Asian Nation (ASEAN) was established on 8th August 1967 in Bangkok (Thailand) with the signing of the ASEAN Declaration (Bangkok Declaration) by the Founding Fathers of ASEAN, namely Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.. The objective was:

1. To accelerate economic growth, social progress & cultural development in the region. 

2. To promote regional peace and stability.

3. To promote active collaboration and mutual assistance.

4. To provide assistance to each other in the form of training and research facilities.

5. To promote Southeast Asian studies.

 

ASEAN fundamental principles are contained in the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia (TAC) of 1976 which was signed at first ASEAN Summit.

 

Member states include: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Question 32
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II and select the correct answer with the codes given below (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)List – I(a) SAARC(b) ASEAN(c) EU(d) NAFTAList – II(i) Philippines(ii) Canada(iii) Afghanistan(iv) HungaryCodes:
  • A.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(ii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)

Economic Integration with their member states:

SAARC – Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka

ASEAN - Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand, and Vietnam.

European Union – Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom*( * UK exited after BREXIT))

NAFTA - Canada, Mexico and United States.

Question 33
The Maastricht Treaty ofFebruary,1992 renamed the European Community (EC) as:
  • A.the European Union (EU)
  • B.the European Economic Union (EEU)
  • C.the European Monetary Union (EMU)
  • D.the European Economic Community (EEC)
Correct Answer: the European Union (EU)

Maastricht Treaty, formally Treaty on European Union is an international agreement approved by the heads of government of the states of the European Community (EC) in Maastricht, Netherlands, in December 1991. The treaty established a European Union (EU), with EU citizenship granted to every person who was a citizen of a member state.

Question 34
NAFTA came into force fromJanuary,1994 embracing: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.The USA, Canada, Cuba, Trinidad and Tobago
  • B.The USA, Canada, Mexico
  • C.Cuba, Mexico, USA, Havana
  • D.Trinidad, The USA, Mexico
Correct Answer: The USA, Canada, Mexico

North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) entered into force on 1st January, 1994 by government of Canada, Mexico and U.S.A to create a tri- lateral trade bloc in North America. It was supplemented by two other regulations:

1. North American Agreement on Environmental Co-operation (NAAEC).

2. North American Agreement on Labour Co-operation (NAALC)

These side agreements were intended to prevent businesses from relocating to other countries to exploit lower wages, more lenient worker health and safety regulations, and looser environmental regulations. 

Article 102 of NAFTA agreement states the purpose:

1. Most Favoured Nation Status to Signatories.

2. Eliminate barriers to trade & facilitate cross border movement.

3. Fair Competition and increase in investment opportunities.

4. Protection of IPR, procedure for resolution of trade dispute.

Question 35
From the following, identify the trading blocks in the world and choose the correct code:(a) European Union(b) North American Free Trade Agreements(c) South Asian Association of Regional Co-operation(d) Central American Common Market(e) Central African Customs UnionCodes:
  • A.(a), (b) and (c)
  • B.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
  • C.(a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)
  • D.(a), (b) and (e)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e)

All the above given organisation comes under the ambit of trading blocks of the world. 

 

1. European Union (EU) is an international organization comprising 28 European countries. The EU was created by the Maastricht Treaty, which entered into force on November 1, 1993. The treaty was designed to enhance European political and economic integration by creating a single currency (the euro), a unified foreign and security policy, and common citizenship rights and by advancing cooperation in the areas of immigration, asylum, and judicial affairs. The EU was awarded the Nobel Prize for Peace in 2012, in recognition of the organization’s efforts to promote peace and democracy in Europe.

 

2. North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) entered into force on 1st January, 1994 by government of Canada, Mexico and U.S.A to create a tri- lateral trade bloc in North America. It was supplemented by two other regulations:

i. North American Agreement on Environmental Co-operation (NAAEC).

ii. North American Agreement on Labour Co-operation (NAALC)

These side agreements were intended to prevent businesses from relocating to other countries to exploit lower wages, more lenient worker health and safety regulations, and looser environmental regulations. 

 

3. South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC) was established with the signing of the SAARC Charter in Dhaka on 8 December 1985. SAARC comprises of eight Member States: Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. The Secretariat of the Association (headquarter) was set up in Kathmandu. It is dedicated towards economic, social, technological, cultural development. Under SAARC discussions regarding multilateral issues are discussed and no unilateral issues are dealt with. 

 

4. Central American Common Market (CACM) is an association of five Central American nations that was formed to facilitate regional economic development through free trade and economic integration. It was established by the General Treaty on Central American Economic Integration signed by Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, and Nicaragua in December 1960, its membership expanded to include Costa Rica in July 1962. The CACM is headquartered in Guatemala City.

 

5. Central African Customs Union also called the Customs and Economic Union of Central Africa (or UDEAC) was established by the Brazzaville Treaty in 1964. It formed a customs union with free trade between members and a common external tariff for imports from other countries. The treaty became effective in 1966 after it was ratified by the then five member countries—Cameroon, the Central African Republic, Chad, the Republic of Congo, and Gabon. Equatorial Guinea joined the Union later. UDEAC signed a treaty for the establishment of an Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa (CEMAC) to promote the entire process of sub regional integration through the forming of monetary union with the Central Africa (CFA franc as a common currency); it was officially superseded by CEMAC in June 1999 (through agreement from 1994). CEMAC currently operates a customs union and monetary union. The common market is in place, but many exceptions to the tariff free regime still exist.

Question 36
Which among the following are full member countries of ASEAN? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)(a) Brunei Darussalam(b) Cambodia(c) Vietnam(d) Myanmar(e) Sri LankaCodes:
  • A.(a), (b) and (e)
  • B.(a), (b), (c) and (e)
  • C.(b), (c), (d) and (e)
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c) and (d)

Association of Southeast Asian Nation (ASEAN) was established on 8th August 1967 in Bangkok (Thailand) with the signing of the ASEAN Declaration (Bangkok Declaration) by the Founding Fathers of ASEAN, namely Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand.. The objective was:

1. To accelerate economic growth, social progress & cultural development in the region. 

2. To promote regional peace and stability.

3. To promote active collaboration and mutual assistance.

4. To provide assistance to each other in the form of training and research facilities.

5. To promote Southeast Asian studies.

 

ASEAN fundamental principles are contained in the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia (TAC) of 1976 which was signed at first ASEAN Summit.

 

Member states include: Brunei Darussalam, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao PDR, Malaysia, Myanmar, Singapore, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam.

Question 37
Which of the following is not a Trading block? (UGC NET MANAGEMENT DEC 2012)
  • A.NAFTA
  • B.ASEAN
  • C.SAARC
  • D.IMF
Correct Answer: IMF

Trading blocs are usually groups of countries in specific regions that manage and promote trade activities. Trading blocs lead to trade liberalisation and trade creation between members, since they are treated favourably in comparison to non-members.

 

The World Trade Organisation (WTO) permits the existence of trading blocs, provided that they result in lower protection against outside countries than existed before the creation of the trading bloc.

 

The most significant trading blocs currently are:

European Union (EU) – a customs union, a single market and now with a single currency

European Free Trade Area (EFTA)

North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) between the USA, Canada and Mexico

MERCUSOR - a customs union between Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay and Venezuela

Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Free Trade Area (AFTA)

Common Market of Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) created in 2006 with countries such as India and Pakistan

Pacific Alliance – 2013 – a regional trade agreement between Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru

 

IMF-The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is an organization of 189 countries, headquartered at Washington D.C, working to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world. The IMF's primary purpose is to ensure the stability of the international monetary system—the system of exchange rates and international payments that enables countries (and their citizens) to transact with each other. The Fund's mandate was updated in 2012 to include all macroeconomic and financial sector issues that bear on global stability.

Question 38
In December 1999, European commission members signed a treaty that committed them to adopting a common currency known as Euro. This is better known as: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Treaty of Rome
  • B.Treaty of Maastricht
  • C.Treaty of Lisbon
  • D.Treaty of London
Correct Answer: Treaty of Maastricht

In December 1999, European commission members signed a treaty that committed them to adopting a common currency known as Euro. This is better known as the Treaty of Maastricht.

Quiz Attempt #119469

Total Questions: 49
Question 1
A letter of acceptance sufficiently stamped and duly addressed is put into course of transmission. There is a ___________.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Contract voidable at the option of acceptor
  • B.Contract voidable at the option of offeror
  • C.No contract at all
  • D.Valid contract
Correct Answer: Valid contract

In the context of contract law, as per Section 4 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, the communication of an acceptance is complete when it is put into the course of transmission to the offeror (i.e., when the letter of acceptance is posted), provided it is correctly addressed, sufficiently stamped, and duly posted.

 

Even if the letter of acceptance is delayed or lost in transit, the contract is still valid as long as the letter was posted with the necessary conditions (correct address, sufficient postage, etc.). The acceptor becomes bound by the contract once the letter of acceptance is posted, and the offeror becomes bound when they receive the letter.

 

Therefore, once the letter of acceptance is posted correctly, a valid contract is formed, and the acceptor cannot withdraw from it.

 

Thus, the correct answer is (D) Valid contract.

Question 2
On attaining the age of majority, a minor's agreement ____________.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Can be ratified by him
  • B.Cannot be ratified by him
  • C.Becomes void
  • D.Becomes valid
Correct Answer: Cannot be ratified by him

On attaining the age of majority, a minor's agreement cannot be ratified by him. A contract made with or by a minor is void ab-initio: A minor is not competent to contract and any agreement with or by a minor is void from the very beginning. A minor cannot ratify the agreement on attaining majority as the original agreement is void ab initio and a void agreement can never be ratified.

Question 3
In which of the following cases, the agreement isvoid ab-initio?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)A. Mistake is caused by fraud or misrepresentationB. Mistake as to the identify of person contracted withC. Mistake as to the nature and character of a written documentD. Bilateral mistakeE. Unilateral mistakeChoose the most appropriate answer from the option below:
  • A.C, D, E only
  • B.A, C, E only
  • C.B, C, D only
  • D.D, E, B only
Correct Answer: B, C, D only

Mistake may be defined as an innocent or erroneous belief which leads the party to misunderstand others. It is essential for the creation of a contract that both the parties should agree to the same thing in the same sense. Thus, if two persons enter into a contract, each of them thinking about a different subject matter, no contract will arise. As a result, a mistake may lead a contract towards voidness.

 

The following mistakes are void-ab-initio:

 

(i) Mistake as to the Identity of the Person Contracted With

A mistake regarding the identity of the person with whom one is contracting can make a contract void ab initio. This is particularly true when the identity of the person is essential to the contract. For example, if someone enters into a contract believing they are dealing with a well-known, creditworthy individual, but they are actually dealing with someone else, the contract can be voided because the identity was a crucial element in the decision to enter into the contract. The key here is that the mistake must be about the identity, not just characteristics or attributes of the other party.

 

(ii) Mistake as to the Nature and Character of a Written Document

A mistake about the fundamental nature and character of a document can render a contract void ab initio. This occurs when one party is misled about what they are actually signing. For example, if an elderly person is asked to sign what they believe is a lease agreement but it is actually a gift deed transferring their property, the contract is void ab initio because there was no true consent given to the actual terms of the document. This is known as non est factum (it is not my deed), where a person is mistaken about the nature of the document they signed.

 

(iii) Bilateral Mistake

A bilateral mistake occurs when both parties to a contract are mistaken about a fundamental fact that is essential to the agreement. In such cases, there is no "meeting of the minds," which is essential for a valid contract. For example, if both parties believe they are contracting for the sale of a specific piece of land, but the land has already been sold to someone else, the contract is void because the subject matter does not exist as both parties understood it. The lack of agreement on a fundamental fact makes the contract void ab initio.

Question 4
Given below are twostatement: one is labelled as AssertionAand the other is labelled as Reason R(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)Assertion A: “Promise is an agreement”Reason R:“ Anagreement is the sum total is the sum total of offer and“ acceptance”In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R arecorrectbut R is NOT the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is not correct
  • D.Aisnot correctbut R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R arecorrectand R is the correct explanation of A

Assertion A: “Promise is an agreement”, this assertion is correct.

The Indian Contract Act 1872 defines the term promise under Section 2(b) as “when the person to whom the proposal is made, signifies his assent there to, the proposal is said to be accepted. Proposal when accepted, becomes a promise”. In other words, when the person to whom the proposal is made agrees to it, that means the proposal is accepted. Once a proposal is accepted, it turns into a promise.

 

For example, Anita tells Simran that she is willing to sell her Maruti Alto Car for Rs 75,000. Simran agrees to buy Anita's car for Rs. 75,000, indicating her assent to the proposal. This acceptance is now a promise.

 

Reason R: “An agreement is the sum total of offer and acceptance.”, this reason is correct.

 

The Indian Contract Act also defines agreement under Section 2(e) as “every promise and every set of promises, forming the consideration for each other”.

 

 

Continuing with the above example, Anita's promise to sell her car for Rs 75,000 and Simran's promise to buy it for the same amount create an agreement. In this case, their promises are connected and form the consideration for each other. So, under the Indian Contract Act, their mutual promises constitute an agreement.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct answer.

Question 5
Match List I withtheList II:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)List I (Features)a. Breach of promise to marryb. Part performance (as much as earned)c.Absolvationfrom all obligationsd. Mode of securing the specific performance of negative terms of contractList II (Remedies for breach of contract)i. Suit for injunctionii. Rescission of contractiii. Sue for quantum meruitiv. Vindictive damageChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

The correct match is as follows.

 

List I – List II

(Features) - (Remedies for breach of contract)

a. Breach of promise to marry - Vindictive damage

When there's a breach of promise to marry, the innocent party may suffer emotional distress or other damages. Vindictive damages, also known as punitive damages, are awarded to punish the party at fault and deter similar conduct in the future.

 

b. Part performance (as much as earned) - Sue for quantum meruit

If one party performs part of the contract but the other party breaches it, the performing party can sue for quantum meruit. Quantum meruit is a legal principle that allows a party to recover the reasonable value of services rendered or work performed.

 

c. Absolvation from all obligations - Rescission of contract

When one party seeks absolution from all obligations under the contract, they may seek rescission of the contract. Rescission of contract cancels the contract, releasing both parties from their obligations and restoring them to their pre-contractual positions.

 

d. Mode of securing the specific performance of negative terms of contract - Suit for injuction

When one party wants to secure the specific performance of negative terms of the contract (such as restraining the other party from doing something they agreed not to do), they can file a suit for injunction. An injunction is a court order that requires a party to do or refrain from doing a specific action.

Question 6
In which of the following cases, undue influence is presumed:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Creditor and debtor
  • B.Landlord and tenant
  • C.Husband and Wife
  • D.Parent and Child
Correct Answer: Parent and Child

A contract is said to be induced by “undue influence” where the relations subsisting between the parties are such that one of the parties is in a position to dominate the will of the other and uses that position to obtain an unfair advantage over the other.

 

In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing principle, a person is deemed

to be in a position to dominate the will of another—

(a) where he holds a real or apparent authority over the other, or where he stands in a fiduciary relation to the other; or

(b) where he makes a contract with a person whose mental capacity is temporarily or permanently

affected by reason of age, illness, or mental or bodily distress.

 

Where a person who is in a position to dominate the will of another, enters into a contract with him, and the transaction appears, on the face of it or on the evidence adduced, to be unconscionable, the

burden of proving that such contract was not induced by undue influence shall lie upon the person in a position to dominate the will of the other.

The relationships that raise presumptions of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872 are:

(i) Parent and child

(ii) Doctor and patient

(iii) Fiance and fiancée.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (D). It is important to note that although the relationship between husband and wife is inherently fiduciary, it does not raise a presumption of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872.

 

If a presumption of undue influence is raised, the burden of proof shifts to the party in the dominant position to prove that the contract was entered into freely and voluntarily by the other party, without any undue influence.

Question 7
Arrange the following points (Section wise from Section 14 to 18) of the Indian Contract Act(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)A. Definition of free consentB. MisrepresentationC. FraudD. Undue influenceE. CoercionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, D, C, B, A
  • B.D, E, C, A, B
  • C.B, D, E, A, C
  • D.A, E, D, C, B
Correct Answer: A, E, D, C, B

As per Indian Contract Act 1872,

Sec. 14: “Free consent” defined.

Sec. 15: “Coercion” defined.

Sec. 16: “Undue influence” defined.

Sec. 17: “Fraud” defined.

Sec. 18: “Misrepresentation” defined

Question 8
Quasi contracts are based on the doctrine of:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)
  • A.Unjust enrichment
  • B.Just enrichment
  • C.UnjustRichment
  • D.Misrepresentation
Correct Answer: Unjust enrichment

Quasi contracts are not actual contracts but are imposed by law to prevent unjust enrichment of one party at the expense of another.

 

The doctrine of unjust enrichment states that no one should be allowed to profit unfairly at another’s expense without compensation.

 

Example: If a person mistakenly pays money to another person without any obligation, the law requires the recipient to return it, even though no formal contract exists.

 

The correct answer is option (A).

Question 9
If a new contract is substituted in place of an existing contract, it is called:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)
  • A.Waiver
  • B.Remission
  • C.Novation
  • D.Alteration
Correct Answer: Novation

When a new contract is substituted in place of an existing contract, it is called Novation. Novation occurs when a new contract replaces an old contract with mutual consent. This can involve changing parties, terms, or obligations while discharging the original contract.

Question 10
'N Minor takes a loan ofRs. 4,000/- from 'B' during his minority, on attaining majority, he applies to 'B' for a further loan ofRs. 3,000/- 'B' gives this loan and obtains from 'A' a combined promissory note ofRs. 7,000/- for the two loans. This is considered as: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Void Contract
  • B.Valid Contract
  • C.Illegal Contract
  • D.Unilateral Contract
Correct Answer: Valid Contract

The given case in the question will be considered as valid contract because the promissory note of Rs. 7,000 is given by ‘N’ on attaining majority, which means he is acknowledging the receipt of both the debts on attaining majority.

Question 11
Match List I withtheList II: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)List I(a) Ordinary damages(b) Special damages(c) Exemplary damages(d) Nominal damagesList II(i) Never granted by way of compensation for the loss(ii) They are quite heavy in amount and are awarded by way of punishment only(iii) Arise in the ordinary course of events from the breach of contract(iv) They constitute indirect loss suffered by the aggrieved party on account of breach of contractChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

List I – List II

(a) Ordinary damages - Arise in the ordinary course of events from the breach of contract

(b) Special damages - They constitute indirect loss suffered by the aggrieved party on account of breach of contract

(c) Exemplary damages - They are quite heavy in amount and are awarded by way of punishment only

(d) Nominal damages - Never granted by way of compensation for the loss

Question 12
A claim for quantummeruit’ cannot succeed:(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.whena divisible contract is partly performed.
  • B.whenan indivisible contract for alumpsumis partly performed.
  • C.whena contract is discovered to be unenforceable due to some technical defect.
  • D.In the case of breach of contract, the aggrieved party can claim reasonable compensation for what he has done under the contract.
Correct Answer: whenan indivisible contract for alumpsumis partly performed.

Quantum Meruit covers a case in which the party who gives the service has fulfilled a part, but not all of the work that he was bound to do and seeks compensation for the value of the work done.

 

Quantum meruit is a claim under a quasi-contract. The claim of quantum meruit arises when the actual contract is discharged.

 

The several cases in which quantum meruit arise are as follows:

 

1. In the case of void agreement or contracts that become void (section 65 of the Indian Contract Act 1872): It talks about the circumstance where work has been done in the execution of the contract but later it is discovered that the contract is void or it becomes void.

2. When the contract is implied or expressed to render services but there is no agreement with regard to remuneration: In such a case, a reasonable remuneration is payable and what is a reasonable remuneration will be determined by the Court and this reasonable remuneration is the quantum meruit.

3. In case of a non-gratuitous act: Where a person enjoys the benefit of a non-gratuitous act (given or received without payment but where the party was obliged to pay) despite the fact that there is no express agreement between the parties, then the person who has enjoyed the benefit has to compensate the other party or restore the thing so delivered.

4. In the case of a divisible contract: Where the contract is divisible, and a party to the contract has done its part, he may sue other parties who have not performed for quantum meruit. The following 2 conditions should be fulfilled for that:

(a) The contract must be divisible; and

(b) The other party must have enjoyed the benefit of the part which has been performed, although he had the option of declining it.

5. In case of act preventing the completion of the contract: Where work has been done by one party in the execution of a contract but the other party refuses to perform his part or prevents the person to perform the contract.

6. In the case of an indivisible contract performed completely but badly: Where the contract is indivisible and performed in a bad way; the party at default can claim a lump sum amount and can reduce the amount for the bad work done if the following conditions are fulfilled:

(a) The contract should be indivisible,

(b) The contract should be for a lump sum,

(c) The contract should be completely performed and,

(d) The contract was performed badly.

 

Thus, a claim for quantum meruit’ cannot succeed when an indivisible contract for a lumpsum is partly performed.

Question 13
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)Statement I: Contracts whose objects or consideration are unlawful are void.Statement II: Contracts in restraint of legal proceedings are voidIn the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

Both Statement I and II are correct.

 

A void contract is a contract that isn’t legally enforceable; starting from the time it was created. While both a void and voidable contract are null, a void contract cannot be ratified. In a legal sense, a void contract is treated as if it was never created and becomes unenforceable in court.

 

Void contract causes are incompetence, inclusion of an unlawful object or consideration, impossibility of performance.

Question 14
Which one is the correct sequence implied in the Indian Contract Act 1872?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Offer of proposalII. ContractIII. PromiseIV. AgreementV. AcceptanceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.III, V, I, IV, I
  • B.IV, II, III, I, V
  • C.II, IV, III, V, I
  • D.I, V, III, IV, II
Correct Answer: I, V, III, IV, II

The correct sequence implied in the Indian Contract Act, 1872 is:

I. Offer of proposal (section 3)

II. Acceptance (section 7)

III. Promise (section 9)

IV. Agreement (section 10)

V. Contract (section 10)

 

(a)

When one person signifies to another his willingness to do or to abstain from doing anything, with a view to obtaining the assent of that other to such act or abstinence, he is said to make a proposal;

(b)

When the person to whom the proposal is made, signifies his assent thereto, the proposal is said to be accepted. A proposal, when accepted, becomes a promise;

(c)

The person making the proposal is called the "promisor", and the person accepting the proposal is called "promisee";

(d)

When, at the desire of the promisor, the promisee or any other person has done or abstained from doing, or does or abstains from doing, or promises to do or to abstain from doing, something, such act or abstinence or promise is called a consideration for the promise;

(e)

Every promise and every set of promises, forming the consideration for each other, is an agreement;

(f)

Promises which form the consideration or part of the consideration for each other, are called reciprocal promises;

(g)

An agreement not enforceable by law is said to be void;

(h)

An agreement enforceable by law is a contract;

(i)

An agreement which is enforceable by law at the option of one or more of the parties thereto, but not at the option of the other or others, is a voidable contract;

(j)

A contract which ceases to be enforceable by law becomes void when it ceases to be enforceable.

 

Question 15
Which one is False as per the relevant provisions of Indian Contract Act, 1872? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)
  • A.A void agreement is one that is not enforceable by law.
  • B.Assignment is the obvious mode of discharge of contract.
  • C.Where a party waives its rights under the contract, the other party is released of its obligations under the contract.
  • D.Where the subject matter of a contract is destroyed for no fault of the promisor, the contract does not become void by impossibility of performance.
Correct Answer: Assignment is the obvious mode of discharge of contract.

Statement B is false about the Indian Contract Act. 1872 as assignment is not a mode of discharge of contract.

 

All agreements are contracts if they are made by the free consent of parties competent to contract, for a lawful consideration and with a lawful object, and are not hereby expressly declared to be void.

 

The 6 types through which discharge of contract through agreement or consent could take place are: Novation, Rescission, Alteration, Remission, Waiver, Merger, Accord and Satisfaction.

 

When a party to a contract has refused to perform, or disabled himself from performing, his promise in its entirety, the promisee may put an end to the contract, unless he has signified, by words or conduct, his acquiescence in its continuance.

 

Contingent agreements to do or not to do anything, if an impossible event happens, are void, whether the impossibility of the event is known or not to the parties to the agreement at the time when it is made.

Question 16
Which one of the following is a void contract? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.Unilateral contract
  • B.A contract which ceases to be enforceable by law
  • C.Implied contract
  • D.Express contract
Correct Answer: A contract which ceases to be enforceable by law

An agreement not enforceable by law is said to be void.

 

Implied Contracts: Implied contracts in contrast come into existence by implication. Most often, the implication is by law and or by action.

 

A contract would be an express contract if the terms are expressed by words or in writing. The Act provides that if a proposal or acceptance of any promise is made in words the promise is said to be express.

 

Unilateral contract is a one-sided contract in which one party has performed his duty or obligation and the other party’s obligation is outstanding. For example, M advertises payment of award of Rs. 5000 to anyone who finds his missing boy and brings him. As soon as B traces the boy, there comes into existence an executed contract because B has performed his share of obligation and it remains for M to pay the amount of reward to B. This type of Executory contract is also called unilateral contract.

Question 17
Arrange the following in order of their manifestations: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)(a) Offer(b) Acceptance(c) Breach of contract(d) ContractChoose the correct option from the following:
  • A.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
  • B.(a), (b), (d) and (c)
  • C.(b), (c), (a) and (d)
  • D.(a), (d), (c) and (b)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (d) and (c)

According to section 2(e), every promise and set of promises (two or more promises) forming the consideration for each other is an agreement.

According to Section 2(b), Promise is defined as when the person to whom the proposal is made signifies his assent thereto, the proposal is said to be accepted. A proposal when accepted becomes a promise.

Therefore, every agreement is composed of a proposal (offer) from one side and its acceptance from the other side.

Thus, Agreement = Offer or Proposal + Acceptance of Offer.

A Contract arises when an agreement gives rise to legal obligation i.e. it is enforceable by law.

When any party to a contract, whether oral or written, fails to perform any of the contract’s terms, they may be found in breach of contract.

According to above explanation, correct order of manifestation would be:

Offer > Acceptance > Contract > Breach of Contract

Question 18
Statement I: Agreement without consideration is always valid.Statement II: All contacts are agreements but all agreements are not contracts.In the context of the other two statements, which one of the following codes is correct? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Statements I and II both are correct
  • B.Both Statements I and II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
  • D.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct

Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.

 

For any agreement to be called as Contract, it must give rise to legal obligation i.e. it should be enforceable by law. It is one of the essential elements of a valid contract that there should be an intention on the part of parties to the agreement to create a legal relationship. If this condition is not fulfilled (in case of agreements creating social, religious or moral obligation) then an agreement cannot be called a contract. Therefore, all contracts are agreements but not all agreements are contracts. Hence, Statement II is correct.

 

Another essential element of a valid contract is lawful consideration i.e. the agreement must be supported by a lawful consideration on both the sides. In other words, in absence of consideration an agreement is always invalid. Therefore, Statement I is incorrect.

Question 19
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)Assertion A: A the owner of a ship by fraudulently representing her to be seaworthy induces B. on underwriter to insure the ship.Reason R: B can obtain cancellation of the policy, as it is a fraud on account of fraudulent misrepresentation under the contract act.In the light of the above statements. choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true and R is NOT the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

According to the provisions of Section 26 of the Specific Relief Act, 1963, when through fraud or a mutual mistake of the parties, a contract or other instrument does not express their real intention, either party may institute a suit to have the instrument rectified.
